story:
FED's vision

As the first food-focused EcoDistrict in North America, the Food Eco District (FED) has a vision to create a downtown hub that celebrates food and sustainability. Located in the heart of downtown Victoria (between Douglas and Quadra St, from Broughton to Blanshard), the District encompasses a neighbourhood recognized for its vibrant small businesses and outstanding local food options. FED currently has 7 restaurant members in the 4 by 3-block area, and one "satellite member" located nearby in Cook St. Village. 

How you can help

FED is one of the twelve teams from across North America that has been accepted to attend the 2015 EcoDistricts Incubator in Portland, OR! This three-day intensive, project-based workshop is designed to accelerate district-scale sustainability in neighbourhoods across the continent. For more info, visit http://ecodistricts.org/incubator/.
In order to take advantage of this incredible opportunity, FED's team of dedicated volunteers need your help! 
  • The workshop costs $6,450 for our team of 7 (this includes conference fees and meals, but not travel and accommodation).

The impact

FED is working with restaurants to expand public green spaces and facilitate urban agriculture projects, increasing community engagement and raising awareness about food security on Vancouver Island. FED also hopes the district will be an exciting new tourist attraction, driving tourist traffic up from Government St and helping to position Victoria as a leading tourism destination in the Pacific Northwest.

The EcoDistricts Incubator will:

  • Help us accelerate the implementation of our goals by providing us with a customized Road Map for EcoDistrict success!
  • Bring neighbourhood-level sustainability expertise back from the place where it all started; Portland, OR.
  • Put FED on the map along with other innovative EcoDistrict projects across North America

Can't donate today?

Spread the word about FED! Visit www.get-fed.com

story:
We all know that oceans are rising, acidifying, and brimming with trash.  The situation is desperate.  It overwhelms most of us, but who is doing something about it?  Little ones.

In 2014, three tiny spring snails competed in a beauty pageant that spotlighted the plight of these native creatures.  Hundreds of school children across the state of New Mexico heard their story and took it to heart.  The children told their parents, who told their friends, who told theirs, rippling out… Concerned citizens across the Gila and Rio Grande Valleys now know about Miss Gila and the drought, contamination, and development her spring faces.  It’s big news.

Today a group of Spanish rock snails are taking on an even bigger topic—entire ocean ecologies! In two weeks time, these marine mollusks compete for the Miss Murex crown while engaging local kids in water conservation conversations.  The little ones often have the best solutions to big problems.  And when they speak out, big people listen.

Beyond the glitz and glamor of snail runways, pageants shine a light on important and meaningful issues in compelling ways.  No one who sets eyes a stomach-footed beauty queen ever forgets the experience.  Why, there are New Mexican lawmakers and Interstate Stream Commissioners who still quake in their boots at the thought of Miss Gila and her entourage of small, powerful voices.

With your donation helps finance a pageant at a school in Spain and empowers a new generation of rabble-rousers with a cause.  The behind-the-scenes labor and expense for making these little critters and other props is formidable.  Just one sculpted, molded, collaged, sealed, stitched, stuffed, and painted contestant takes 25 hours to complete.  So consider lending a hand today and sharing Miss Murex’ story with a friend tomorrow.

story:
My husband is not receiving any disability assistance yet, he still has to go through a ton of tests and red tape.  In the meantime my unemployment benefits have run out and we are trying to keep a roof over our heads.  I have thousands of resumes out there but still no bites, it's been a year and a half of great struggles..  The last year and a half has completely wiped us out financially, cost of home, expenses, and medical bills, etc.. If you can help we would geratly appreciate it and will pass on the blessing when we get back on our feet.  Thank you all so much.

 

Sue & Mike

Sue & Mike

story:
About David and TooMuchTooMany

David’s is concerned about the impact of increasing human consumption and increasing human population size (what he calls “Human Impact”). He has spent the last 9 months researching Human Impacts, not only on the residents of South African communities, but also on South African landscapes and wildlife. He’s identified around 100 Human Impact sub-topics and 100 locations around South Africa demonstrating them. In March 2013 he’ll commence a 3 month nationwide journey visiting and writing about these locations and issues.

He’ll publicise human rights, women’s rights and environmental issues affected by Human Impacts, publicise the work of well-known organisations (such as Marie Stopes and the Endangered Wildlife Trust) but also highlight small community based organisations working with children, HIV and other relevant topics. TooMuchTooMany will cover topics from the housing crisis to contraception, biodiversity to healthcare and immigration to endangered species.

David wants to look at Human Impacts differently and conclude with systemic solutions to South Africa’s problems which do not treat human rights, women’s rights and environmental issues as separate subjects, but rather find solutions which address all these concerns together.

Read more on: www.TooMuchTooMany.co.za

Why TooMuchTooMany, why South Africa?

The existing overconsumption v. population growth debate acts as a negative way to frame a debate by seeking to make one group of people more to blame than another. We all need to accept that we all have some responsibility, in different ways, and focus on our own impacts. TooMuchTooMany will have a new approach.

Human Impact literature is often academic, focusing on statistics not impacts on the ground. As a result, a fascinating topic is not given the coverage it deserves. TooMuchTooMany will use a new approach, using social media to engage the public and not treat people merely as statistics, but seek to tell their stories.

Some Human Impact literature pits the interests of humans (and their living standards) against the interests of nature. However, increased Human Impacts generally have negative implications for both. A more fruitful debate might be had by joining these two concerns, looking at common threats to human living standards and nature from Human Impacts and working out ways to ease them. TooMuchTooMany will have a new approach.

South Africa is neither a country with a notably high population for its size nor one with of one Africa’s higher population growth rates. With a population of around 50 million, South Africa’s population is about ten million fewer than that of the UK (and South Africa is five times the size). This means South Africa still has an opportunity of saving aspects of the country which have been lost in the UK and other more densely populated countries. TooMuchTooMany seeks to find solutions whilst they can still be implemented.

Read more on: www.TooMuchTooMany.co.za

What TooMuchTooMany needs

The 9 month research phase (June 2012 – February 2013) has been funded by David and existing TooMuchTooMany supporters but the total project costs for the journey phase (March 2013 – May 2013) publicising the 100 articles amounts to £11,000. A full budget can be supplied, costs relate to accommodation, travel, subsistence, communications, insurance and publicity.

Read more on: www.TooMuchTooMany.co.za

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow the TooMuchTooMany project and spread the word:

Have a look on the TooMuchTooMany website here for more information.

Like the TooMuchTooMany Facebook page by clicking here.

Follow David on Twitter by clicking here.

story:
Send Brittany to Costa Rica's Sloth Sanctuary!

Our pal Brittany was accepted into Costa Rica's Sloth Sanctuary volunteer program awhile back. She booked her flight, took the vacation time and was all set to go ... until she got laid off. Now the money she set aside for volunteering is needed to support herself until she lands another gig. We want to help Brit cover her volunteer costs so she can follow through on the volunteer experience she signed up for.
 
The Sloth Sanctuary of Costa Rica has been rehabilitating orphaned and injured sloths for more than 20 years. In addition, the sanctuary's outreach program teaches local people and tourists that baby sloths are bad pet choices and raises awareness about poaching and habitat destruction. It has since become a place and international hub for sloth research.
 
You can read more about the Sloth Sanctuary here:
http://www.slothsanctuary.com/

 

What Brittany Needs

Brittany has taken care of her travel expenses to Costa Rica, however, each volunteer pays  $65/day during the volunteer's two week stay. We're looking to cover the cost of:

  • All meals are included: Breakfast is a do it yourself meal. Lunch and Dinner are cooked by a Sanctuary Staff member.
  • Board: A room (dorm style) will be provided with an in room bathroom and a shower. We have some double rooms and rooms that hold up to 6-8  people)
  • One towel is provided for each volunteer
  • Bedding and one pillow is also provided per volunteer
  • Laundry gets done once a week (Wednesday) free of charge.
  • Free WiFi in public spaces. Some rooms receive signals, but not all.

Any additional funds raised beyond the $1200 goal will be donated to the sanctuary.

 

Why You Should Help Brittany

There are hundreds and thousands of people in the US without jobs, so, why should you help Brittany? If you're a friend of Brittany's, well you probably don't need much convincing. Brittany has a track record of altruism—she was down in NOLA after Katrina to help with clean-up and returned again to Mississippi after the oil spill, while on the arts side, she's volunteered time with the Seattle International and Sundance Film Festivals. This isn't some Costa Rican vacation you're funding; Brittany will be down there doing the work most of us wouldn't give up the time for.


Sometimes, you need the universe to give you a high-five. That's what Brit needs. Or in this case, a two-toed salute.

Oh, and this:
http://youtu.be/YRJlj8bkx4c

story:
Hi! My name is Tara, and I'm obsessed with honey bees. After learning about current practices in conventional beekeeping, the disappearance of our bees was no longer a mystery to me.  The artificial insemination of queen bees in some distant lab; bees having their honey taken and being fed high fructose corn syrup; the use of prophylactic antibiotics—all were shocks to me.  Monoculture food growth requires bees to be trucked in from distant locations.  With this new knowledge, I am more determined than ever to start a sustainable, local bee concern.  

When you combine our mistakes and harmful intervention with the increased use of systemic pesticides, the future of bee keeping can seem bleak indeed.  I am convinced we can reverse that decline and I want my family to be part of the change. 

Central to this process is the strengthening of the honeybee.  My project has two primary goals—to help the local bee population and to benefit local food production.  One third of all the food we eat is pollinated by bees.. The more bees on a farm or orchard, the more their crops will yield.  My dream is to provide organic farms and gardeners with their own hive of local, holistically raised bees.  Users could care for the hives themselves once set up, or choose my reasonably priced care option.  

What are holistically raised bees?  Holistic beekeeping simply means trusting our bees.  When a queen dies we let the hive create a new one, or provide a local virgin queen, eventually one that I have raised myself.  We will be using a biodynamic approach to treat mites and diseases.  
-OUR PROMISES
--NO High Fructose Corn Syrup!
--NO Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs)
--NO taking honey from bees except in the face of a real surplus
--NO plastic foundations
But we WILL lovingly care for the bees and explore alternative hive options.  

Step one for this project is expanding my apiary and beginning to raise local queens.  I would like to add 8 new nucs* in Spring 2014.  Further, I have two hives that are currently wintering well that could be split for a total of 12 hives.  8 of these are earmarked for an 8-acre organic farm, 2 will go to a protected organic apple orchard and 2 will be kept in my backyard for daily observation.  In winter 2014/15, as splits continue apace, I will offer my expanding bee production to other local organic farms and orchards.

  * A “Nuc” is a small colony of bees created from a larger colony.


Bees aren’t cheap!  Project costs are as follows:
$1000 for 8 Nucs of local bees
$3100 for Hive supplies—including hive boxes, frames, foundations and more
$150 for queen rearing supplies

  
My plan to sell products derived from their wax and any surplus honey will offset future capital outlays and allow me to keep my fees reasonable.  This production requires the following equipment:

$100 for Solar Wax Melter
$550 for a professional grade Extractor
$450 for Indiegogo fees

  Total $5350  


Thanks for considering funding my bee project.  It truly means the world to me.

story:
Nous aimerions mettre à disposition de nos clients particuliers et professionnels un/deux vélo(s) électrique(s) (en complément de nos véhicules de prêts qui sont destinés à nos clients professionnels), dans une dynamique écologique.

Offrir l'opportunité à nos clients de vivre une expérience originale.

C'est un moyen de transport doux qui ne dégage aucun gaz à effet de serre et consomme très peu d'électricité.

Moyen de transport confortable et accessible à tous.

Pour quoi faire? Faire une course ou se balader,...Moyen de transport écologique.

2 modèles de vélos : 

1 vélo e-colors d'une valeur de 727€ HT

1 vélo e-cardan d'une valeur de 898€ HT

À quoi servira la collecte ?

La collecte servira à payer le(s) vélo(s) ainsi que (si dépassement de budget) leur entretien, l'assurance ainsi que casques de sécurité!!!

Si au bout du temps imparti, la somme de 1000€ n'est pas atteinte, le projet sera avorté et les contributeurs seront remboursés.

Chaque contribution donne droit à une réduction d'impôts (cf. mise à jour)

Qui sommes nous et pourquoi ce projet ?

Nous sommes une entreprise de contrôle technique auto indépendante et affiliée à un réseau (AutoSécurité).
Ce réseau propose actuellement des vélos électriques à la vente à prix réduit pour une durée limitée (fin mars délai de commande).
Sinon nous commanderons le vélo à une entreprise locale.
C'est pourquoi nous souhaiterions en acquérir un afin de proposer à nos clients une alternative au "traditionnel" véhicule de prêt.
Nous n'avons malheureusement pas les moyens financiers d'en acheter un d'où la naissance de cette initiative de crowfunding.
Merci de votre attention.

story:
Hi from Rose Avenue Public School, a big school, with a big heart in the heart of Toronto!  Unfortunately, being in the heart of downtown, we don't have a lot of green space.  We do a lot though, with the space we have, being rated a Platinum level Eco-School 4 years and counting! 

On November 15, we are overjoyed to be getting a big supply of muscle and elbow grease from the student volunteers of Royal St. George's College to build new planter boxes for our school gardens.  But we need the materials first!   We will be using the money we receive from this campaign to buy cedar lumber, hardware, and other materials, so that we can transform our garden into a sensory paradise for our 700 students.  Help us put our volunteers to good use, and keep our gardens growing! If you require a tax receipt, please visit https://www.canadahelps.org/dn/7819 and under "Your Donation Will Support" choose "Rose Ave. Greater Garden Fund."

Please remember to like us on facebook and other social media, and pass this information to anyone you think could help us!  It's easy, just use the indiegogo share tools!

story:
Why We Need Your Help

"Twenty years ago there were Dolphins as far as the eye could see, and Tuna everywhere. Today these monster factory ships have made Costa Rica's ocean into an almost barren sea. There are very few Tuna with the Dolphins. Scared as hell."  ~ Fred Maschmeier ~ Drake Bay, Costa Rica Sport Fisherman

Costa Rica's dolphins, whales, sea turtles and other marine flora and fauna are being decimated at alarming rates due to rampant commericIal fishing including long lines, gill nets, shrimp trawling and tuna boats.

The Osa Peninsula, on the South Pacific side of Costa Rica is known by National Geographic as the most biologically intense place on Earth. The waters off the Osa Peninsula are a virtual marine wonderland, housing over twenty-five species of dolphins and whales that live here year round or migrate through and also hosts four of the world’s eight species of sea turtles. 

In fact, Costa Rica enjoys one of the most biologically diverse ocean ecosystems in the world. This is mainly because the heart of a vast habitat known as the Costa Rican Thermal Convection Dome, named for its proximity to this country, lies here. Shallow warm waters lie on top of low-oxygen cold water, creating the perfect ecosystem for a vast variety of marine life. The dome off the coast of Costa Rica is the only one in the world that is constant. Such conditions provide the Costa Rican Pacific waters with a very unique scheme of biological richness. Whales, dolphins, tuna, marlin, manta rays, sea turtles, sailfish and more, congregate in this area taking advantage of this year-round thermal dome of ecologically rich waters.


All this rich biodiversity is found here on the Osa Peninsula, but yet, the area is almost entirely unprotected, except for small areas around the national parks. Commercial fishing techniques such as long lining, shrimping, gill netting and tuna fishing are wreaking havoc on this delicate and biologically diverse area and its marine inhabitants, and if urgent and drastic actions are not taken immediately, the world will lose this treasure forever.

The quickest and easiest way to protect this precious and pristine area before it is to late is to create a Marine Protected Area (MPA)… and we need your help to do it.

"One of the few commitments made by world leaders at the World Summit on Sustainable Development (WSSD) in 2002 was to address the current inadequate protection of our oceans and coasts by creating representative networks of MPAs by 2012. More recently, in 2010 governments gathered in Japan at the UN Convention on Biodiversity meeting agreed to a biodiversity rescue plan that includes marine protected areas covering 10% of our oceans by 2020." ~ World Wildlife Federation
Humpback Whales

The Pacific side of Costa Rica is the vital breeding and birthing grounds of Humpback Whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) that migrate from both North and South America. It is the only place in the world where Humpback Whales come from two different hemispheres to have their babies and breed. Humpbacks have been sighted in every month of the year, giving us the longest season of Humpbacks in the world. For these reasons alone, the area should be protected but yet they are met by long lines, gill nets and shrimp boats, putting them in danger of entanglement and noise pollution. This is no way to treat an endangered species.

Dolphins and Other Whales

These biologically intense Costa Rican Pacific waters host more than twenty-six species of marine mammals from the Cetacean Order (dolphins and whales). Some of the species with a bigger presence in the area are the Pantropical Spotted Dolphins (Stenella attenuata), the Bottlenose Dolphins (Tursiops Truncatus) and the Spinner Dolphins (Stenella Longirostris). The Spinner Dolphins found here are a sub-species of Spinner Dolphins found only off the Pacific Coast of Costa Rica in a 90 mile wide band of ocean. They are hence called Costa Rica Spinner Dolphins, our very own species. But yet they are netted, killed, maimed and stressed out relentlessly by the tuna boats, mostly foreign fleets.

The dolphins are distributed in a heterogeneous manner, from smaller groups with two or three individuals in coastal waters, to pods of thousands of individuals in deeper oceanic waters. Also Roughtooth Dolphins, Risso’s Dolphins, Pseudo Orcas, Pilot Whales, Orcas, Bryde’s Whales, Fin Whales and Sei Whales are commonly seen in these waters. For a full list of the dolphins and whales in the area, please visit our website, MPA for OSA.

Sea Turtles

Four out of the eight sea turtles species in the world are found in the Pacific side of Costa Rica. UICN finds these four sea turtle species to be in a critical state or in danger of extinction. The sea turtles’ threats are mainly over-exploitation of eggs and shells, the changing and destruction of sea turtles’ natural habitats, pollution, and the incidental capture of turtles by commercial and traditional fishing boats. Through the data collected on our research tours, we have discovered that in the last four years, the population of the Olive Ridley Sea turtle has decreased an alarming 79%.

The Threats

Commercial Shrimp Boats

Commercial shrimp boats drag their nets along the ocean floor virtually killing and “clear cutting” everything in their path, including sea turtles, rays, eels, coral, plant life and thousands of small fish. These small fish are an intricate part of the food chain but are killed before they can grow to reproduce and become food for animals and humans alike, breaking the natural food chain. We already know our turtle population is in grave danger and our coral systems are dead or dying. Once the ocean floor is stripped in this way, it does not grow back. The area that the Humpback Whales (and divers) love so much called Paraiso, is being destroyed by the shrimp boats as are the main feeding areas for our local dolphins. In fact, for every gallon of shrimp that is harvested, over five gallons of other sea life is killed.


Long Lines and Nets

Another major problem in the area is the long line fishing boats. Long lines are spread out, sometimes for miles and miles, and are baited every several feet with a hook and a piece of fish. The sea turtles, sharks, manta rays, billfish and many other forms of marine life often will bite the bait and get hooked on the line. If the line is too far below for the turtles to reach the surface, they drown. The ones who don’t drown and are hooked on the long line at the surface are often cut open by the fishermen in order to look for sea turtle eggs or otherwise killed in the process. The long lines are also harmful to dolphins and whales that cannot see them and get severely cut by the lines and hooks, or worse, get entangled in them and drown.

A baby humpback whale with a line embedded in its skin

Twice we have seen small humpbacks with long lines and rope wrapped around their bodies. We have frequently recorded long lines spread out in the areas frequented by the dolphins, whales and turtles. Often long line gear and nets that are tangled or unusable is left floating in the water so it continues to kill and maim even after the fishermen are done with it. Any captain traveling these waters has seen dead or even live turtles, rays and dolphins stuck in freely floating long line gear and most recently, a dead baby Humpback Whale washed up onto the shores of Corcovado National Park, the victim of a net left in the water as seen in the photo below. 

A recent study published in the Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology and conducted by the Department of Biodiversity, Earth and Environmental Science, Drexel University and the Programa Restauración de Tortugas Marinas (Pretoma) called Impact of Costa Rican longline fishery on its bycatch of sharks, stingrays, bony fish and olive ridley turtles (Lepidochelys olivacea) states:

"Marine protected areas and/or time area closures are needed to reduce the impact of the Costa Rican longline fishery on sea turtles and sharks."

Randall Arauz, president of the Marine Turtle Restoration Project (PRETOMA) and one of the authors of the above study states:

“You don’t have to be a fishery biologist to know that if you’re killing 80 percent of the animals that haven’t reproduced yet, you’re … on a collision course towards extinction."

A long line fisherman cuts up a manta ray that was captured on their line.

We can see rays, sharks and possibly dolphins in the carnage from the long line boats.


Tuna Boats

Large commercial tuna boats also kill and maim thousands of dolphins each year. They use helicopters to find the dolphins and when they do, they radio the tuna boat which then puts several speed boats in the water to round up to dolphins and set a net around them to catch the tuna swimming underneath. It is now believed that more than 2000 Spinner dolphins per year or more are being killed by the tuna industry off the Osa Peninsula alone. The dolphins are not able to sustain their populations when they are killed off at this rate. Our subspecies of Spinner Dolphin, the “Costa Rican Spinner Dolphin” has been severely depleted. Where there used to be thousands and thousands of them, there are now hundreds. If we continue to let them be killed, there will be no more Costa Rican Spinner Dolphins.

Our Costa Rica Spinner Dolphins captured in a tuna net by a tuna boat from Venezuela
on July 10, 2012. For the full story and more photos,visit http://on.fb.me/17NUAPS


Our Goal

To promote and support, with a solid scientific base, the creation of a “Multiple Use Marine Protected Area” off the coast of the Osa Peninsula, Costa Rica and cooperate with all involved parties to achieve its effective protection and enforcement.

The main objective of the AMUM “Multiple Use Marine Protected Area” management category is the protection and conservation of the comprised marine areas and to assure sustainable use of their resources and habitats. Private, commercial, scientific and sport fishing, as well as tourism development and marine transportation activities, will be executed within a management plan and supervision.

The area that we have determined as needing protecting is located in the south of the Pacific Ocean of Costa Rica. A “Multiple Use Marine Protected Area” AMUM, is proposed from and including Marino Ballena National Park and Caño Island to Punta Sirena.

This area comprises already protected areas (Corcovado National Park, Isla del Caño, Marino Ballena National Park and Terraba-Sierpe Mangroves); ecosystems of great relevance and unique biological characteristics. The importance of these ecosystems and their immediate and future threats, calls for real protection, coordination and control, both of their natural resources and the activities carried out within their boundaries.

In 2004, the Costa Rican government issued a decree to protect 25% of the nation’s Exclusive Economic Zone. In support of this objective, and to assist in determining the management and protection needs of the extensive marine life found here, MPA for OSA's ambitious project will provide direct technical input, using their extensive scientific database, to create a Protected Marine Area (MPA) and to improve networking for marine biodiversity research at local, national and international levels. This will be accomplished with a master plan that will determine the management and protection needs of the Mesoamerican Marine Corridor’s biodiversity and natural resources.

The conservation of the Osa Peninsula marine life is a complex process that requires commitment, participation and coordination from all possible institutions, individuals and organizations. MPA for OSA seeks cooperative efforts to support our initiative from partners and involved organizations, the private sector and government.

Helping a stranded dolphin we named Grace.

Specific goals:

To initiate the creation of a Marine Education and Research Center that will:

• Support the creation of environmental and protective laws towards marine eco-systems and its resources and creating protected marine areas
• Help preserve the representative natural environments of the area and its’ more fragile ecosystems in order to guarantee the equilibrium and continuity of such marine mega-ecosystem
• Guarantee the sustainable use of natural resources encouraging the active participation of local communities
• Support, promote and carry out scientific studies related to marine resources, especially those related to marine mammals and sea turtles.
• Carry out educational projects on these animals and contribute to the creation of an environmental awareness about marine resources
• Create a web of information, documentation and reference on local marine life with educational purposes.
• Stimulate and support other organizations and institutions that may share our goals.
• Implement varied educative activities with and for the local community (workshops, courses, presentations of the use of new technologies, GPS, data collecting, first aid for a beached or hurt cetacean and others).
• Develop educational programs and informative materials for kids, tourists and research (Osa marine mammals ID catalogs, Interaction Guidelines for Tourists, Photo Id catalogs for Research use)
• Carry out environmental campaigns: waste and harmful chemical reduction in homes and hotels, beach cleaning, recycling etc.
• Promote regulated eco-tourism specially oriented towards cetaceans watching in their natural habitats.
• Support the certification of tour operators and tour guides involved in Whale and Dolphin watching, and contribute to the establishment of adequate whale and dolphin watching activities and to guidelines for appropriate interaction
• Continue the monitoring and collection of sighting data in order to maintain the health and sustainability of the MPA as well as write and submit scientific articles and conduct studies that contribute to a better understanding of marine mammals.
• Monitor, report and help prosecute illegal activities

Research Info

From 1999 to 2008, Delfin Amor Eco Lodge, a small hotel nestled in the heart of Drake Bay, closed in 2008 to focus on marine activities exclusively, in conjunction with the Vida Marina Foundation, collected sighting data on their dolphin and whale educational research tours. Delfin Amor’s tours, now run by The Divine Dolphin, are conducted year round, with a higher percentage of tours in the “dry season,” December through April.

During our research tours, we counted and document the location of turtles, dead and alive, as well as commercial fishing boats and long lines. Also documented were the dolphins’ and whales’ group size, ages, and also their travel and feeding patterns and behaviors. Digital photos and video were also taken to further document and identify the dolphins, whales, turtles and commercial fishing activities. With the data analysis we have carried out, we have documented an alarming 79% decrease in the Olive Ridley Sea Turtle (Lepidochelys olivacea) population during the last several years.


Our solid scientific database allows us to generate reports and graphs that demonstrate the variety of species found here and the need to protect them. The sighting data collected by our marine biologists and volunteers on our tours is entered into the computer database. The information generated from this database, along with comprehensive knowledge of the marine resources in the area, will serve as the basis for the development of the protected area, control and protection measures, designation of local capacity building projects, and regional planning in general.

A marine biologist on the Vida Marina team prepared a technical interpretation of the data collected during the past years, and developed an unprecedented study of marine mammals in Costa Rican waters off the Osa Peninsula. The costs and resources invested in such work were a contribution from Delfín Amor Eco Lodge and several grants, but now that Delfin Amor no longer exists, we seek funds to continue our important research and data collection and need your help to do that.

Our published scientific documents are:

CO-OCURRENCE OF CETACEAN INDICATOR SPECIES OF UPWELLING MODIFIED WATERS AND TROPICAL WARM WATERS OFF OSA PENINSULA, COSTA RICA

Conservación de Cetáceos en la Península de Osa, Costa Rica: La Ballena Jorobada como Especie Sombrilla

Determinación Preliminar de Hábitat Crítico de Alimentación del Delfín Nariz de Botella (Tursiops truncatus) en Golfo Dulce, Costa Rica

Budgets and Funding

Our previous research and data collection was funded by profits from Delfin Amor Eco Lodge, which now does not exist, and donations to our foundation, Vida Marina. The foundation’s biggest funder lost their fortune in the Bernie Madoff scandal, just when we were about to receive a grant of $250,000 and as a result, our foundation could no longer stay afloat. We are now in need of researchers, marine biologists, research equipment and materials in order to continue the collection of data for written scientific reports both supporting the MPA initiative and once established, maintaining it and enforcing laws and regulations within.

Recording data on our research tours

Phase I of our project includes continuing data collection, including Photo ID and video evidence, and comparing it with our previous data to generate reports and graphs on the current state of the ocean off the Osa Peninsula. We will gather signatures for an online Petition in support of the MPA and coordinate meetings with all concerned parties in the communities affected by the borders of the proposed MPA and the local government for input and strategy and completing an Implementation and Management Plan for the Marine Protected Area.

Earth Island Institute has graciously donated a high tech hydrophone and digital recording system to us, but we need much more to carry out our research and to take the steps necessary towards creating the MPA.

All equipment purchased in Phase I will be used for all other phases and beyond. If all funds are not received, we will purchase the most important equipment and move forward the best we can with what we have.

Our budget and requested funds are as follows:

HOW YOU CAN HELP US 

You can help us to conserve these incredible animals by donating whatever you can – no donation is too small, every dollar is a step closer to reaching our goal.

We passionately believe that your contribution will help to make a huge difference to the conservation and protection of the dolphins, whales, sea turtles and all marine life of the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica. Together we have the opporunity to preserve an entire marine eco system that desperately needs our help to survive. 

As well as donations, please help us to spread the word and share this page with all of your friends and be sure to SIGN AND SHARE OUR PETITION:

FOLLOW OUR PROGRESS

If you would like to keep up to date with our projects and the creation of the Marine Protected Area, please FOLLOW US:

scandal, just when we were about to receive a grant of $250,000 and as a
result, our foundation could no longer stay afloat. We are now in need of researchers,
marine biologists, research equipment and materials in order to continue the
collection of data for written scientific reports both supporting the MPA
initiative and once established, maintaining it and enforcing laws and
regulations within.


Recording data on our research tours

Phase I of
our project includes continuing data collection, including Photo ID and video
evidence, and comparing it with our previous data to generate reports and
graphs on the current state of the ocean off the Osa Peninsula. We will gather
signatures for an online Petition in support of the MPA and coordinate meetings
with all concerned parties in the communities affected by the borders of the
proposed MPA and the local government for input and strategy and completing an
Implementation and Management Plan for the Marine Protected Area.
Earth Island Institute has graciously donated a high tech hydrophone and digital
recording system to us, but we need much more to carry out our research and to
take the steps necessary towards creating the MPA. 
All equipment purchased in Phase I will be
used for all other phases and beyond. If all funds are not received, we will
purchase the most important equipment and move forward the best we can with what we have.
Our budget and requested
funds are as follows:



HOW YOU CAN HELP US 
You can help us to conserve these incredible animals by donating whatever you can – no donation is too small, every dollar is a step closer to reaching our goal.
We passionately believe that your contribution will help to make a huge difference to the conservation and protection of the dolphins, whales, sea turtles and all marine life of the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica. Together we have the opporunity to preserve an entire marine eco system that desperately needs our help to survive. 
As well as donations, please help us to spread the word and share this page with all of your friends and be sure to SIGN AND SHARE OUR PETITION:



FOLLOW OUR PROGRESS
If you would like to keep up to date with our projects and the creation of the Marine Protected Area, please FOLLOW US:

story:
Twenty years of tree planting!

Activate the Wheatbelt and our loyal supporters (that's you!) have been revegetating degraded farmland for quite a while now. In fact, this year marks our two decades milestone and so we wanted to make it even more memorable.

In December last year we committed to planting more than DOUBLE our usual number of trees. For the last 6 months, 65,000 native seedlings have been nutured up to planting size, ready to provide vital Wheatbelt habitat and fight back against climate change. 

Our challenge

We have all been in lockdown for most of 2020. This means that Activate have not been able to host our usual swag of awesome fundraising events for you.  Now we need to raise $5,000 more to make sure this year's events can still proceed in the usual fun, delicious, safe and memorable way you have come to know and love from Activate.

Where your money goes

Typically it costs around $5 to plant one seedling and so 65,000 seedlings needs a lot. This year, you will also be helping Activate to:

  1. complete the fitout of our new festival site trailers 
  2. have Activate crew complete new COVID event training, purchase additional cleaning supplies, sanitizer and equipment and take all other necessary steps to ensure a safe planting site
  3. begin planning for 2021 where we aim to plant over 100,000 trees!

Other ways you can help

Not everyone can contribute and that's okay but that doesn't mean you can't help. You may consider sharing this link to your Facebook page or sending to your friends in a message.

story:
Preservation Campaign

Join Western Foothills Land Trust in our campaign to protect the summit of historic Noyes Mountain. We need your help to purchase the 295-acre parcel that will protect water resources, wildlife habitat, and agricultural fields. Like our other Preserves, it will accommodate a variety of non-motorized recreational trails for public use by the community and its visitors. The land will provide access to outstanding views and to the historic Harvard Quarry owned by Frank Perham, renowned geologist and pegmatite miner of West Paris, Maine. The purchase will assure that the iconic and inspiring view of Norway Lake, framed by Noyes Mountain, will be preserved for the benefit and enjoyment of future generations.

What We Need

We have 6 months to secure the 295-acre Noyes Mountain parcel. The appraised value of the land is $455,000. After negotiations and initial fundraising we now need a remainder of $270,000 to secure the land. Funds raised beyond our goal will cover closing costs and establish a stewardship fund. Western Foothills Land Trust is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) corporation and all contributions are tax deductible.

What You Get

Noyes Mountain Preserve will forever protect...

Views Iconic view of Norway Lake from the 1,500' summit and the view of the undeveloped mountain from Norway Lake and Routes 117/118.

Water 1,000' of streams and 295 acres within the Norway Lake watershed.

Land Dramatic ledges, working forests and fields in a significant undeveloped block of woodlands. The land provides habitat for rare plants and two rare natural communities. 

Recreation Trails for mountain bikers, horseback riders, runners, snowshoers, skiers, rock hounds, hikers and hunters.

Community The Trust will provide public programs, pay current use property taxes, and manage resources conscientiously.


History of Noyes Mountain

Historically the land was owned by the Stevens family and included a through road north from Norway to Greenwood (from the Upton Brothers Road to the Hayes Road). In 1869 Ethel Stevens sold the land to Isaac Noyes.

Isaac Noyes became interested in the site’s pegmatitic outcroppings in the late 1880′s. In 1892 the ledge was opened for the first time and became a mecca for scientists and collectors, offering one of the most complex mineralized pegmatites in Maine. Mineral operations on the mountain were opened by Isaac’s 6th cousin George Lorenzo (“Shavey”) Noyes and Tim Heath about 1894. Tourmaline was first recorded from the locale about 1904. In 1917, Harvard College bought a 1 acre mine site and a 100-year mineral rights lease on 60 acres. Over the years the dark green tourmaline found at this location has become known as “Harvard Green."

The granite pegmatites Noyes collected were largely preserved and passed into the possession of the Harvard Museum. In the summer of 1923 active quarrying was undertaken by the Harvard Mineralogical Department under the supervision of Harvard University student Kenneth K. Landes for Landes' dissertation, Paragenesis of the Granitic Pegmatites of Central Maine (American Mineralogist, 1925, v. 10, p. 355-411). Loren B. Merrill of Paris and Arthur Valley undertook most of the actual excavation for Landes at the site.

The land, which has been the subject of images by artists and photographers since settlement as the backdrop for Lake Pennesseewassee, is also coveted for its wildlife habitat, rare plants, mineral and cultural significance.

Currently Frank Perham owns the 1-acre Harvard quarry, which remains open to the public. Mineral rights on the western portion will retire in 2016. 

Why This Land is Worth Protecting

The View of the Mountain Looking north up the reach of Norway Lake, two mountains shape the horizon and frame the distant view of Old Speck Mountain. The western mountain is Patch Mountain (elev. 1,565'), and the eastern steeper mountain is Noyes Mountain (elev. 1,500'). By day our community and its visitors have enjoyed a verdant mountain backdrop to the lake, and by night humans and wildlife have benefitted from dark hills uninterrupted by development.

That could all change quickly. The Land Trust has seized this as our first and best opportunity to protect that signature view that has inspired artists and photographers since settlement in the late 1700s.

The View from the Mountain The other view to protect, that is less widely known, is the stunning panorama south and west from Noyes. Most of us have not seen Norway Lake, or North Pond, or the nearby McIntire Ridge, or Patch Mountain from this beautiful vantage point. Easily travelled twitch trails will lead hikers, skiers and snowshoers from a maintained landing to the viewpoint and summit beyond.

The Land To the east of the summit, the land descends gradually to a saddle plateau towards Rock O Dundee. A path is a vestige of the old road that crossed to Greenwood City. Now a working forest, the land was historically managed as a mix of agricultural fields, pastures and woodlands, as is evidenced by stone walls in the deep woods, and in historic photographs and paintings. Twitch trails are well-maintained and will make for wonderful hiking and backcountry skiing.

Wildlife Habitat and Rare Plants This site's diverse ecology supports several rare plants and provides excellent wildlife habitat as it lies in an undeveloped block of 2,691 acres. It also includes nearly 1,000 feet of stream that supports a riparian habitat and, given its size and altitude, is an important forested filter for the Norway Lake watershed.

Mineral and Cultural Significance The parcel is the location of the respected Harvard Quarry (a separately held acre owned by Frank Perham open to the public) that was opened by Shavey Noyes and Tim Heath in the 1890s. The mineralogy of this mountain, like other deposits in this region, played an important cultural and industrial role in the history of western Maine.

Management The Trust will manage Noyes Mountain In much the same way that we have managed our other Preserves. We will maintain existing trails and potentially create additional multi-use trails if consistent with our overall resource conservation goals.

We would allow hunting on site. We would keep the parcel in tree growth tax basis and would continue to manage the forest responsibly. Forest management revenue is important for the Trust’s own sustainability.

About Us

Western Foothills Land Trust was founded in 1987 by citizens committed to land and natural resource protection in Western Maine. 

Western Foothills Land Trust is a member of Maine Land Trust Network and the national Land Trust Alliance. As a member of this extensive network of land trusts in Maine, Western Foothills Land Trust protects land by advocating locally for open space and resource protection, stewarding lands held in fee-ownership, and assisting landowners as a legal holder of donated or purchased conservation easements.

"Once you have preserved your property, you look at it in a different way... 
you take the long view of management and treat your land in a sustainable way that will preserve it. You become more of a husband to your land." 
—Robert Van Nest, President

Mission Western Foothills Land Trust is dedicated to the conservation and protection of native ecosystems, farm and forestlands, watersheds, and scenic landscapes for the benefit of wild and human communities in western Maine.

Service Area Western Foothills Land Trust protects farmlands, wetlands, forestlands, unique natural resources and open space in the greater Oxford Hills area of Western Maine. The Trust holds conservation easements on privately owned lands (3,768 acres) and owns 2,422 acres in the region. The Trust also manages 20 miles of recreational trails on 5 preserves and collaborates within its community to create healthy opportunities.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and make some "noise" about Noyes Mountain.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools or just pick up the phone and ask your friends and family to help.

Purchasing Noyes Mountain serves all of us now and for generations to come.

Thank you for being part of this campaign!

story:
Campaign Summary

Hi! I’m Doug Zietlow, an inventor living in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area.  With degrees in chemistry and chemical engineering, I have 29 years of experience as a process engineer in the food and renewable energy industries.  You can see my LinkedIn profile at www.linkedin.com/in/dazietlow/.

For three decades, I have been working to solve the Achilles' heel of renewable energy.  We get it when and where it is available, which is often not when and where it is needed.  We can't control when and where we get it and there isn't a feasible way of storing and transporting it, so we can have it when and where we need it. I have an invention that solves this problem for electricity from wind and solar power.

My campaign is to fund the final patent application for my invention.  Filing this application is a significant milestone. Although the application does not guarantee a patent and the patent process will take additional time and money, filing will give me more freedom to disclose my invention to investors and potential partners to get their help developing and implementing it.  Based on the input of the patent professionals I am working with, I am confident that my patent application will result in a patent that will allow me to commercialize this invention, solving a major problem limiting the use of renewable energy, making it more usable for all of us, the US and the world.

The Problem

Each year, the United States consumes one billion tons of fossil fuels and produces more than two billion tons of greenhouse gases and pollution to generate electricity.  But we generate less than 4% of our electricity from wind and solar power.  No wonder three-quarters of Americans think increasing renewable energy is a priority!

However, the amount of electricity from wind and solar power is limited because wind and solar power are often not available when and where needed.  By storing wind and solar power in a form that is transportable and readily usable, my invention would make electricity from wind and solar power available when and where needed.

The Solution

Like the carbon cycle (see the video for an explanation), my invention takes naturally occurring materials and uses wind or solar power to produce clean, safe fuel that can be stored, transported and used to generate electricity when and where needed.  Burning the fuel to generate electricity, produces the original naturally occurring materials which are recycled again and again. My invention converts wind and solar power into electricity when and where needed.

The general idea of using renewable energy to produce a renewable fuel where the materials in the process get recycled is not new.  Hydrogen has been proposed for decades.  There are good reasons why its not being used yet.  Researchers are working on a number of other chemical systems for accomplishing the goal of renewable carbon neutral fuels.

My invention is different from these in several ways.  First, the chemical system used is novel. Neither I nor the patent researcher I have hired have found a patent or other technical literature that discloses the chemical system of my invention.  Second, the chemical system of my invention, unlike batteries and most energy storage systems, has more than enough energy to make transporting it long distances feasible.  Third, most of the infrastructure needed to implement my invention already exists, which greatly increases the chances it will ultimately be practically and economically feasible. Fourth, my invention doesn't require water, which is increasingly scarce and valuable.  I believe my invention actually has the best chance of any technology existing or currently proposed of making wind and solar power more available sources of electricity with zero carbon emissions at a reasonable price.

One note, I don't disclose the materials used in my invention because that is the key to my invention and it's not patented yet.  Six months after filing, my invention will become public, regardless of whether the patent office grants a patent or not.  If you are interested in the details, I offer a perk disclosing the details or you can wait until mid-September and get a copy free or cheap from the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

The Benefit

In the nearer term, my invention could capture wind power that is currently lost because it has no place to go.  Currently, lost generated wind power in the United States is equal to the electricity consumed by the state of Rhode Island.

In the long term, my invention could significantly increase the installed capacity of electricity from wind and solar power and get the maximum benefit from them.  We would have a way of getting renewable energy from locations with large wind or solar potential and limited transmission capacity, such as North Dakota, to places with high demand, like Chicago.  Renewable energy from wind and solar power would be available most anywhere even when the wind isn't blowing and the sun isn't shining.

A Note to Those Living Outside the United States

Although my video is primarily talks about the United States, I am also filing an international PCT patent application as part of my campaign.  Since launching my crowd funding campaign, I have determined that the potential impact of my invention outside the United States may be even greater than that inside, particularly in countries with limited or expensive fossil fuels and biomass.  Your contributions are also needed and appreciated.

Have I Ever Done Anything Like This Before?

I have conceived and developed a number of inventions, some patentable, some not.  Probably, my most significant invention to date, other than the one of this campaign, was a practical breakthrough in industrial microwave heating technology.  Since it is patented, you can read about it here.

This invention was a breakthrough because it took a type of microwave heater, that was very powerful and efficient, but so inflexible it had limited practical applications, and modified it to retain all the power and efficiency, but also to have tremendous flexibility.  This innovation created many new potential applications, including heating materials in ways that are not possible any other way.  Others more qualified than I had tried to do the same thing without success.  I find it interesting that I was able to see the potential for, conceive and successfully develop this invention, even though I wasn’t an expert in microwave heating, either by training or previous experience.

I believe my current invention is similar.  Although it is more in line with my training as a chemical engineer, most of my professional experience is not in the renewable energy industry.  In this case, I think being at arm’s length actually gives me an advantage because I am not as influenced by the prevailing ideas and thinking of the industry.  Breakthroughs are often the result of a different perspective.

What I Need

My campaign goal is $30,000, of which $21,000 (70%) is for preparing and filing the patent application. The itemized campaign budget is presented in the table below.

Expense Amount Notes
Prior art search $1,000 Professional patent & literature search
Patent attorney fee $16,000 Patent preparation
Patent filing fees $4,000 US & international PCT applications
Video production $3,500 11.7% of budget
Payment processing $900 3% of budget
Indiegogo fee $1,200 4% of budget
Perks $3,000 10% of budget
Contingency $400 1.3% of budget for the unexpected
Total $30,000

If the campaign doesn’t reach the goal, the funding raised will be used as shown in the table below in order of priority.  I still intend to file the patent application, but will have to find another source of funding as well.

Expense Amount Notes
Payment processing About 3% of total raised Automatic
Indiegogo fee 9% of total raised Automatic
Video production 10% of total raised Promised
Perks About 10% of total raised Promised
Patent attorney fee Paid next until fully covered. The biggest hurdle
Patent filing fee Paid last until fully covered. US application first,
PCT application second

If the campaign exceeds the goal, the extra funding will go toward the following items in order of priority.

Expense

Amount

Notes
Payment processing About 3% of extra raised Automatic
Indiegogo fee 4% of extra raised Automatic
Video production 10% of extra raised Promised
Perks About 10% of extra raised Promised
Patent granting process As needed Actually getting a patent
requires more work and
money after filing.
International patents,
Business development,
Technology development		 Whatever is left This is where the rubber hits
the road.  Let's go!

What You Get

The satisfaction of helping:

  • Decrease the consumption of fossil fuels.
  • Decrease the production of greenhouse gases and pollution.
  • Improve the energy security of the United States and the world.
  • Generate clean energy jobs in the United States and, perhaps, beyond.

A perk of your choice depending on the amount of your contribution:

  • $1: Thank you for your contribution.
  • $10: Ongoing email updates on the progress of my invention.
  • $30: An email thank you from me with an electronic copy of the patent application receipt from the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
  • $90: A hard copy of the patent application receipt from the United States Patent and Trademark Office personally signed by me.
  • $160: A graphic tee shirt with a windmill and text from the video.
  • $1,000: A copy of the patent application as submitted to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. Get the full scoop. Not available any other way until six months after filing, about Sept. 15, 2014.

Note: All perks for $10 or greater include ongoing email updates.  The patent application receipt includes the title of the invention.  Remember you can order more than one perk.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you contribute or not, please spreading the word and sending  people to my crowd funding campaign site.  Hey, at least the video is entertaining.  You can do so by:

  1. Indiegogo share tools
  2. Facebook, LinkedIn or other social media
  3. Your blog or podcast
  4. Good, old-fashioned word of mouth
  5. Get creative!

could capture wind power that is currently lost because it has no place to go.  Currently, lost generated wind power in the United States is equal to the electricity consumed by the state of Rhode Island.In the long term, my invention could significantly increase the installed capacity of electricity from wind and solar power and get the maximum benefit from them.  We would have a way of getting renewable energy from locations with large wind or solar potential and limited transmission capacity, such as North Dakota, to places with high demand, like Chicago.  Renewable energy from wind and solar power would be available most anywhere even when the wind isn't blowing and the sun isn't shining.A Note to Those Living Outside the United StatesAlthough my video is primarily talks about the United States, I am also filing an international PCT patent application as part of my campaign.  Since launching my crowd funding campaign, I have determined that the potential impact of my invention outside the United States may be even greater than that inside, particularly in countries with limited or expensive fossil fuels and biomass.  Your contributions are also needed and appreciated.Have I Ever Done Anything Like This Before?I have conceived and developed a number of inventions, some patentable, some not.  Probably, my most significant invention to date, other than the one of this campaign, was a practical breakthrough in industrial microwave heating technology.  Since it is patented, you can read about it here.This invention was a breakthrough because it took a type of microwave heater, that was very powerful and efficient, but so inflexible it had limited practical applications, and modified it to retain all the power and efficiency, but also to have tremendous flexibility.  This innovation created many new potential applications, including heating materials in ways that are not possible any other way.  Others more qualified than I had tried to do the same thing without success.  I find it interesting that I was able to see the potential for, conceive and successfully develop this invention, even though I wasn’t an expert in microwave heating, either by training or previous experience.I believe my current invention is similar.  Although it is more in line with my training as a chemical engineer, most of my professional experience is not in the renewable energy industry.  In this case, I think being at arm’s length actually gives me an advantage because I am not as influenced by the prevailing ideas and thinking of the industry.  Breakthroughs are often the result of a different perspective.What I NeedMy campaign goal is $30,000, of which $21,000 (70%) is for preparing and filing the patent application.
The itemized campaign budget is presented in the table below.


Expense

goal, the funding raised will be used as shown in the table below in order of
priority.  I still intend to file the patent application, but will have to
find another source of funding as well.

This is where the rubber hits the road.  Let's go!


What You Get
The satisfaction of helping:


Decrease the consumption of fossil fuels.
Decrease the production of greenhouse gases and pollution.
Improve the energy security of the United States and the world.
Generate clean energy jobs in the United States and, perhaps, beyond.

A perk of your choice depending on the amount of your contribution:


$1: Thank you for your contribution.

$10: Ongoing email updates on the progress of my invention.

$30: An email thank you from me with an electronic copy of the patent application receipt from the United States Patent and Trademark Office.


$90: A hard copy of the patent application receipt from the United States Patent and Trademark Office personally signed by me.

$160: A graphic tee shirt with a windmill and text from the video.

$1,000: A copy of the patent application as submitted to the United States Patent and Trademark Office.  Get the full scoop.  Not available any other way until six months after filing, about Sept. 15, 2014.
Note: All perks for $10 or greater include ongoing email updates.  The patent application
receipt includes the title of the invention.  Remember you can order more than one perk.
Other
Ways You Can Help
Whether you contribute or not,
please spreading the word and sending  people to my crowd funding
campaign site.  Hey, at least the video is entertaining.  You can do
so by:

Indiegogo share tools
Facebook, LinkedIn or other social media
Your blog or podcast
Good, old-fashioned word of mouth
Get creative!

story:
Rivenstone Ranch Dog Rescue

We need YOUR help to save strays in our area!

Rivenstone Ranch is a private ranch in the White Mountains of Northeast Arizona. We have been taking in strays in this remote area for 5 years. To the ranchers here, stray dogs are the same as coyotes and they are shot on sight. Most of the dogs we've taken in were in bad shape when they got here. Some had wounds from fights with coyotes, other strays, or from being shot.

The dogs in our care come from a wide area, and many were dumped, and arrived here pregnant. We take them in, rehabilitate them until they are healthy and friendly, then try to find new homes for them. Most of the dogs are medium to large dogs and are not as easily re-homed as small ones.

Building for the future of these dogs 

This campaign will help us to raise enough money to build a new housing area for all of our dogs, pay for vet costs (spay, neuter, and shots), food, and re-homing costs. By completing this campaign to house all of the dogs on site at Rivenstone Ranch we can:

  • Pay for the materials and construction of good quality housing that will last for years to come, where it is comfortable and warm for all of the dogs. (Costs will be kept to a minimum by using volunteers for labor and as much indigenous material as possible. (eg. Local stone, local clay for stucco, etc.)
  • Help with cost for the spaying and neutering of all the dogs as well as shots and any other veterinary needs
  • Purchase food in bulk at a lower cost per pound
  • Pay for additional marketing for re-homing and education for new dog owners

In short, by completing this project, you will not only be helping towards a new building, but ensuring we can carry on the work of saving strays by allowing us to keep caring for these dogs. 

For a long time now we've cared for these dogs with our own money, but changes in the economy and our real world jobs, have made this no longer feasible.  Food and vet bills are a constant, and new dogs continue to show up. Any help you can give us is gratefully received and will go a long way towards helping us improve our facilities so that we can keep these lost animals safe until they find new forever-homes.

Why we're running this campaign

At this moment we are sheltering 25 dogs.  Unfortunately, we've been told that someone else in the area that has also taken in strays over the last few years is relocating soon, and we will be taking in his 16 dogs as well. Although initially we had no intention of becoming a dog shelter, we love dogs and can not allow them to starve or be shot like vermin by the ranchers.

The crisis we are facing now is made worse because the existing animal shelters in this area are also completely overwhelmed by stray and abandoned dogs. These shelters try to be no-kill, but simply do not have the space or funds to keep all the dogs until they are adopted.  There are no other animal shelters within 25 miles of our ranch and most of the public facilities in this county euthanize after only a day or two. 

There is not enough funding available from government agencies for the need in this area, so we are seeking help from dog/animal lovers to keep the dogs we have safe and healthy and to build a shelter that can continue to be of service for years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for volunteers to help us spread the word about adoption and fundraising. A like on our Facebook page ( https://www.facebook.com/rivenstonerescue ) goes a long way when helping us approach sponsors. If you have any connections with people who want to help in ANY WAY whether it is with this campaign, or supplies after the campaign is over, all help is gratefully accepted.

story:
We are a non-profit (called CommunEcos) that hosts weekly green education programs in Durham, NC, and our work is funded by Recyclique, our creative-reuse shop and public donations!  We need your help to buy our building by early 2015 so that we can continue our mission!  The price is right so this could be a great opportunity, since as owners we could develop on-site eco-demonstrations to boost  community-based enviro-ed.  But we need your help to pull it off!

Our pioneer, anthropologist Sandy Smith-Nonini, founded Recyclique with a group of crafters and environmental educators in 2009.  We used upcycling (making new things or upgrading old ones with reused materials) to introduce interactive aspects to green educational programming. We specialize in rain barrels painted with eco-designs, and our programming has been aimed at both teens and adults.  

In 2011 we secured non-profit status for CommunEcos, our educational  arm, and opened the Recyclique creative-reuse shop in a bungalow in West Durham.  The shop carries upcycled goods made by local crafters,  vintage, eclectic thrift, sustainability products and a wide selection of books and educational materials. Our space includes an upcycling workshop room and a large EcoLounge room for educational events and community meetings. 

Sales from the shop and suggested donations fund our weekly events on sustainability themes, community economics, or how-to (skillshare) workshops. We have hosted over 175 educational events at our current location, and more than 220, counting events at other sites prior to 2011.  Topics have included raising chickens, organic gardening, vermiculture, solar energy, cooperative workplaces, aquaponics, composting, lamp repair, sewing, solar space heaters, mosaic stepping stones, crochet w/ plastic bags, local currencies, and many more. For calendars of past events visit our website: www.communecos.org, and click on events page.  Since spring 2013 we have partnered with Transition Durham, a community organization working on the transition to a low-carbon future, and we've jointly sponsored many educational events and films with TD both at our site, as well as larger local venues such as FullSteam Brewery and Motorco Music Hall.

If we are able to buy the building we will pursue projects such as addition of a greenhouse in the rear (South side), improving our EcoLounge cafe and  our outdoor classroom area in back, installation of a  solar space heater (already built), and other energy conservation projects.  Long term, we'd like to install a DIY solar hot water system, a small green roof and green wall demonstration,  and photovoltaics -- all of which will be done in conjunction with educational programs.

We are mostly self-supporting. We've grown slowly each year --(we had a $15,000 budget last year, and will end this year at $18,000-$20,000).  We are loan-free at present, and non-grant dependent (which we see as a good thing) & we rely on a combo of part-time staff and  volunteers to make it all work.  But we have no surplus - all proceeds in the past have gone back into the mission.  We love our location on Hillsborough Rd, a major artery in West Durham, close to a diversity of neighborhoods, so our first choice is to stay.  But to make the leap for a purchase we need a helping hand from you folks.

We will need a total of $30,000 for our down-payment.  We are lining up key board members and partners -- and as of late November we have pledges so far for just over half of that amount from our enviro-ed partners!   The online campaign will help us fill the hole between what our major donors can put in the pot and what we'll need to pull off the deal!   Also, we've been recruiting key social entrepreneurial tenants to share our site, and to boost our revenue flow in 2015, and this past week we worked out a deal with a new key tenant for one of our front rooms that opens onto the front porch -- a consignment clothing business.   We offer our deepest thanks for any contributions you can afford to offer. We'll be sending out tokens of our gratitude in the form of  free products, some of which we can mail, and/or credit on purchases and educational workshops if you live near Durham. 

Other Ways You Can Help -- If you support the work, but can't contribute, we understand -- You can also assist our campaign by helping us get the word out!  Please make some noise and post about the campaign on Facebook and other social media.  Take advantage of the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Blue Change a new rain water collection invention that provides free, clean water at less than $100 per installation whether at a shack or a mansion.

The Problem

Rain falls on your roof as free clean fresh water.

It starts on a costly and totally unnecessary journey before it gets back to where it started a couple of meters from your tap!

How far did the water in your glass travel?

How much did you pay for it?

How much energy was used? 

In California 5 billion Kw/hours per year to pump water to 38 million people.

In South Africa 18 billion Kw/hours per year to pump water to 30 million people.

What's the figure for your state or country ?

20 % of all energy generated in the USA & Europe is used to pump water.

Can we halt climate change by saving this energy? Yes by installing Blue-Change.

Can ordinary folk do it? Yes by installing Blue-Change for themselves in a couple of hours.

The Solution

Simple and easy to install. (DIY)

Low cost.

Collects water efficiently.

Does not collect dust and detritus like conventional gutters.

Easily cleaned by pulling the bottom lip down and clearing the obstruction.

It can collect rainwater from formal and informal structures.

It can be installed very quickly.

Blue-Change may be installed for own private home use without restriction.

Send this picture that shows how Blue-Change works to friends and family.
Blue Change brings fresh clean water a couple of meters to your tap.
Blue Change does this for less than a hundred dollars in readily available materials and everyone can install the system from a picture and simple instructions.

With Blue-Change

10 mm's of rain on a 20 sq meter shanty roof means that for 10 whole days there is no fetching and carrying of water.

10 mm's of rain on a 200 sq meter roof means 10 days of free water or 100 days of emergency backup. 

Water in the tank is better than money in the bank.

The Plan

With your help we can get this patented invention to every community in the world and create jobs overnight.

We need people in every country to help themselves and show others how to have free clean water.

Blue-Change will offer further selling, distribution and manufacturing rights. 

These rights/opportunities shall be offered to donors of this campaign first.

Only a living human being shall own any right in Blue-Change.



What do you get when you donate and install?

   a free source of water. 

  independence from utilities.

 control over the quality of your water.

  electricity used to pump water uphill by the utility is saved

 You do not have to waste your life carrying water.

  You earn money doing the installations full, or part-time.

  your donation back in the first months from water saved. 

  first option on any future offering of blue-change.

Your support will mark the day when ordinary folk like us have a way to fight global warming; Instead of looking on helplessly while the world boils away.
Draw a wet-line in the sand - it's not too late!



My name is Peter Caroto a 70 year old man with 40 years experience in the construction industry.  

Blue-Change came about quite by accident. A young woman who knew of my construction background asked me for an old wheelbarrow to help her carry water for her family.

As she lived in a township I had assumed that they had water on tap, if not inside then at least, in the yard.  In reality the tap was 70 yards (60 meters) from her shack and shared by at least 20 families. Because she could only carry 4 gallons (20 litres) at a time, she spent many hours just waiting her turn. 

I learnt later while researching this problem, that 200,000,000 hours are wasted carrying water every day. This is the equivalent of assembling 

7 000,000 motor cars, or building 28 complete Empire State Buildings.

I dropped off the wheelbarrow and while looking around the shacks it occurred to me that a part of a filtration plant that I had designed was the solution to the problem. 

I went home and in thirty minutes the product was adapted for this application, tested and, most importantly, working perfectly.

I realized that the making and installation of Blue-Change was so simple that anyone could do it and have FREE CLEAN WATER FOREVER!

Where will your money go?

To spread the word until everyone knows how to collect their own free clean water.
To secure provisional intellectual protection in all countries.
Challenges
The major challenge facing blue change is to convince people that the solution  to the worlds water crisis and  global warming is so simple and easy to implement.
I ask only that you trust your own common sense and judgement in this regard.  

Ask your friends and family to share and support the Blue-Change opportunity.

Remember your roots and friends in other countries that can have free clean water forever!
