story:
My name is Ed Carter. I am a US Coast Guard Licensed Captain and a Certified Salvagemaster.I have been involved with Salvaging sunken and damaged boats for over twenty years.

Billions of tons of Boats, and other unwanted fiberglass are clogging the Nations Landfills,some of which has been there over 60 years. No one knows how long it takes for this material to start decomposing. If & when it does, it is full of Hazardous Chemicals that could seep into our water supply. It has never been labeled Hazardous Waste, and banned from Landfills, because, until recently, there was nothing else that could be done with it. Several States have labled it Hazardous Waste beginning in 2014.

The Technology is proven, it can now be processed back into a product that can be used in the construction of New Boats, and other products such as bathtubs, spas,car bodies, etc. This is true Cradle-To-Cradle Management. It is a step above Cradle-To Grave Management ......because there is no grave. This is UPCYCLING.

.From Wikipedia: DOWNCYCLING  is the process of converting waste material into New Material or Products of lesser quality and reduced functionality. Downcycling aims to prevent wasting potentially useful materials,and reduce consumption of Raw Materials.      UPCYCLING: is the process of converting waste material or useless products into New Materials or products of better quality or for better Environmental Value.

Every Ton that we Recycle is a Ton that will not be taken from the earth in raw material, and a Ton that will not end up in a Landfill. The dumping of this material in Landfills has been banned in other Countries, and soon will be banned in the US. Several States have already declared it to be Hazardous Waste beginning next year. 

   With this Campain, we are seeking Seed Capital  to lease  a parcel of land, where we will gather & store derilect Boats ,and to help with Start-Up Costs,and developing the market for our Product. These  hulks will be reduced into a manageable size to await Recycling. We will start locally,and work out from there.

We will work with local County Waste Departments to divert from Landfills, while we seek Funding from Grants, and other sources to purchase the Equipment to Recycle the fiberglass. Our Recycled Product will earn "Carbon Credits". These Credits are a part of the Cap & Trade Plan, both nationally & Internationally. This goes to Global Warming and reducing our  Carbon Footprint.

Our local Operation will be a Pilot Project for a bigger, Nationwide Plan with Franchisees in other Coastal States.

Any and all monies raised with this Campaign will be used toward this Goal.

Our current location lies in the middle of one of the East Coast Boatbuilding Hubs. We are surrounded by businesses that produce scrap for our feedstock, and can also be our customers by using our end-product in their New Boats. When our stock of Raw-Recycled- Material is of sufficient size,we will build a line of small (9-18ft) boats. The Countrys first Recycled Boats. We have a beautiful Harkers Island Style Dingy, from which to make a mold, and an agreement on a mold for a Carolina Flare Center Console.

The Founder (EC) is an affiliate of a Network of Marine Salvage Operators from the Great Lakes to Florida. One of our Affiliates was recently featured on the Discovery Channels "Shipwreck Men" Those 4 episodes showed derilect boats going to Landfills in South Florida and the Florida Keys.

There is no doubt this can be the start of a New Business that is urgently needed Nationwide.  Help us be the First & we will remain the Best !

story:
Short Summary

We are Lafayette's Energy Future ( LafEnergy.org ), a grassroots Issue Committee in Lafayette, CO.  We want a more sustainable energy future, and it seems to us that our monopoly utility, Xcel Energy, does not take this seriously.  We want to give Lafayette citizens a choice on energy direction - the status quo with Xcel Energy, heavy on the coal, or a more sustainable energy path based on more renewable energy and energy efficiency.  

So we are encouraging Lafayette voters to say "NO" to another 20-year franchise agreement with Xcel (NO on 2A!) in order to send a message that we want more clean energy and energy efficiency programs in Lafayette!  

We gathered signatures to get a replacement for the franchise fee on the ballot.  The Utility Occupation Tax (UOT) (YES on 301!) will be collected the same way the franchise fee is currently collected, and will be the same amount in year 1.  The franchise fee currently goes to Lafayette's General Fund, but UOT funds will be dedicated to renewable energy and energy efficiency; these INVESTMENTS will pay the city back over time!  The UOT will ONLY be collected if the franchise fee is not.  

We are standing up and telling this powerful utility that the future of this planet is for all of us, and if they won't get serious about cutting carbon emissions, we'll start doing it for them!     

What We Need & What You Get

PayPal donations help us right now, when we need it!  Please consider making your donation via PayPal! Thanks! 

We need to be able to get the word out about the impacts of our proposed votes:

NO on 2A (20-year Xcel franchise agreement) and 

YES on 301 (Utility Occupation Tax) to replace the franchise fee for the city.  

Printing costs money!  Xcel will undoubtedly throw mass quantities of literature at voters, and we must be able to reach those same voters with the information they need to make an informed, responsible decision.  

If you support this campaign, you can feel good knowing that you helped a small grassroots campaign stand up to a utility GIANT for what is right, for what we KNOW we need to do!   

The Impact

We want to set an example for other communities, to show them that they CAN make a difference!  

We want to be the pebble in the pond that begins the sea change toward a healthier future for our children, and theirs. 

Share this with your friends!  

With your help, 

we can make a difference!   

*Note*  If you have trouble contributing, please try updating your browser.  If you still have trouble, please contact info@Lafenergy.org .  Thank you!

story:
March 5th: OFFICIAL THEATRICAL TRAILER RELEASED!

Just announced on Huffington Post:

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/05/bidder...

Everyone, now is the time to share our IndieGoGo Campaign!

WE'VE ADDED DVDs!

Preorder your BIDDER 70 DVD for $25. Anyone who funds more than $25 will have a DVD added to his/her perk!

Also, the digital download is now only $10!

 

We are releasing BIDDER 70 in theatres on Earth Day!

This Earth Day, Monday, April 22nd, 2013, the day after Tim DeChristopher will be released from the prison system, we are going to celebrate with a countrywide, simultaneous theatrical screening of the award-winning documentary, BIDDER 70, followed by an hour-long discussion with Tim (who will be attending the Salt Lake City screening) that will be broadcast to theatres via Skype, and a Q&A that everyone can participate in via Twitter (you can Tweet a question using a Twitter hashtag, from wherever you're attending)!

 

This is not only a celebration...

The Earth Day screening event, combined with Tim's timely release, creates a 'perfect storm' of newsworthiness around the cause of climate change and peaceful activism. Here is a rare opportunity to create awareness on both a local and national scale.

Tell me about the movie:

BIDDER 70 has screened in over a dozen film festivals and won over 16 awards! An official BIDDER 70 EARTH DAY MOVIE TRAILER is on its way, but take a look at this in the meantime:

 

BIDDER 70 PREVIEW

 

Directors Statement:

Once in a while someone comes along that totally wows you. That’s how we felt when we read about Tim DeChristopher.  As bidder #70, DeChristopher bid 1.8 million dollars and saved 22,000 acres of pristine wilderness.  No property was destroyed, no one was hurt, and valid concerns were raised over the entire BLM oil and gas leasing process.  Bidder 70 was a story we wanted to tell.

Since 1993, Gage & Gage Productions has produced feature documentaries that inspire, educate and entertain; with Bidder 70, we will also motivate.  Tim DeChristopher is a young man with a message that needs to be heard. Climate change is upon us and there is nothing more important to work for than a livable future.  Tim's commitment to future generations, his evolution as a leader and his willingness to courageously accept the consequences of his action make his a story we hope will inspire and motivate a new generation of activists.

- Beth & George Gage                     

           Gage & Gage Productions     

We cannot do it without your help!

We need passionate volunteers to campaign for local screenings around the country. Championing a screening doesn't cost money, but requires a committment to the cause.

We also need passionate donors to help fund not only the logistics of putting on the nationwide event, but also the marketing and promotion. By creating awareness we can create change.

What we need:

We've got perks that directly defray the costs of, or entirely fund, theatrical screenings of BIDDER 70 all over the United States. These perks include: GREENLIGHT A SCREENING, ULTIMATE GREENLIGHT PACKAGE, and PRIVATE EARTH DAY SCREENING. As for the rest...

Here's how the $15,000 breaks down:

$2,000 Covers the Salt Lake City main event (includes theatre rental/buyout, press line 'Step & Repeat', photographer, staff, equipment for discussion/Q&A, etc)

$1,000 Covers airfare and transporation for New York musician, Bryan Cahall, to come to Salt Lake City in order to perform at the Earth Day screening.

$1,500 Covers the cost of creating a DCP (Digital Cinema Package) which is the preferred delivery format of the film, so that the majority of theatres, nationwide, will be able to exhibit it.

$4,500 Covers a publicity firm (2 months, March/April) that will issue press releases, encourage local/national news to cover the event, get us online and offline features/editorials/event listings, place Tim and/or the filmmakers (Beth and George Gage) on local/national radio and television, etc

$2,000 Covers the cost of creating, printing and shipping the movie posters to the theatres

$500 Covers the cost of creating, printing and shipping 'lobby cards' to Movie Captains (local volunteers who are promoting screenings) to pass out.

$3,500 Covers the costs of geo-targetted Google and/or Facebook ads to help build awareness for our Movie Captains' local screenings in order to help them 'tip' their screenings.

$1,500 Covers the fees and taxes that IndieGoGo charges so that we can net $15,000

If we can raise more funds:

$3,000 Covers the costs of inserting paid ads (e.g. LA Weekly, Salt Lake City Tribune, Village Voice, etc...) wherever Movie Captains are championing screenings in order to help them 'tip' their screenings.

$150 Covers the DCP (Digital Cinema Package) copy and also the shipping/receiving. So, everytime we raise an additional $150, we will be able to defray that much of the cost for individual screenings, thereby lowering the barrier to entry for having the screenings!

So, who are we?

We are Gathr, a group of filmmakers who have set out to democratize theatrical distribution because we've been disheartened by the inability of so many worthy films to get into theatres and to be seen by communities around the country.

We created a new, bottom-up model for theatrical distribution that allows anyone, anywhere to request a screening of a movie -- and by getting enough ticket reservations -- to 'tip' that screening opportunity so that it is able to been seen in the local community.

We have had the great pleasure of helping many important films reach wider audiences in the short time we've been around, including THE CENTRAL PARK FIVE, MEA MAXIMA CULPA, and the upcoming GIRL RISING, for which we've already had close to 500 screening requests!

Okay, so how does it work? How do I request a screening?

It couldn't be more simple. In order to request a screening simply fill out the screening request form right here:

 

http://gathr.us/films/bidder-70/request-new-screening

 

How do Gathr screenings of BIDDER 70 happen?

Gathr screenings happen when a minimum number of people reserve tickets before a predetermined expiration date. We call this “tipping” the screening. On every screening page, you’ll find an update that shows you the number of current reservations, the number of additional reservations needed to tip the screening, as well as how much time remains before that screening request expires. When enough people reserve tickets to a screening before time expires, the screening takes place. If the minimum number of reservations is not met, the screening does not take place and nobody is charged.

Who can request a Gathr screening?

You can! Anyone can request to host a screening, making them a BIDDER 70 Captain. Simply fill out a Screening Request to indicate when and where you want to screen BIDDER 70. Gathr will then work to confirm the request and then a page for your screening request becomes live on the gathr.us site. Whether you’re an individual, an organization, or a theater, you can request a screening. It’s fun, simple, and only takes a few minutes.

What can you do to make my screening happen?

We’ve prepared all kinds of tools and resources to help you promote and tip your screening, which we will inform you of, directly, and which will be forthcoming in our BIDDER 70 newsletters.  You’ll be hearing from the BIDDER 70 team regularly with new promotion ideas, sample Tweets and Facebook posts, updates on events like festival screenings, and more, so that you can use all of this to promote and tip your screening.

What is the difference between reserving a ticket and purchasing a ticket?

When a screening of BIDDER 70 has not been “tipped,” your option is to reserve a ticket by pre-authorizing your credit card. When a movie has been “tipped”, your ticket purchase will be processed immediately.

When will your credit card be charged?

Your credit card will only be charged once your screening has met the minimum number of reservations and has been tipped. It works just like IndieGoGo!

Why host a BIDDER 70 screening?

Hosting a screening of BIDDER 70 is the perfect opportunity for you to raise awareness of climate change, of Tim DeChristopher's story, of Earth Day, of peaceful civil disobedience, and even of your own organization.  By encouraging your friends and family to see BIDDER 70, you’re helping to spread awareness and, thus, you are contributing to effect change -- change in minds and change in policy.

 

BIDDER 70 comes out in theatres in selected cities on April 26th, 2013. Check www.firstrunfeatures.com/ for more information.


Thank you to our participating organizations:

story:
The Down to Earth Storytelling Project is capturing stories on film that can connect people everywhere to the growing climate justice movement.

---> Help us commission an original score! 2016 stretch goals down below! <---

Hi, I'm Andy Burt. In the 1980's I had the experience of bringing Central American people and their powerful stories of human rights abuses into mainstream Indiana communities, where, to my surprise and delight, the stories helped to seed a refugee sanctuary movement. 

Today I believe there is no bigger problem we face than global climate change. Here in Maine I've met a number of activists of all ages who are putting their values and passion to work for climate justice. My experience in the Midwest has led me to believe in the power of stories to change hearts and minds. Now I'm working with videographer Charlie Hudson to bring these Maine stories, told by a new generation of activists, to audiences that might need a gentle nudge. 

With our film of inspiring stories as a centerpiece, we plan to facilitate workshops that will help participants explore their own values and how they might address the urgent climate crisis. We are creating a journaling workbook that draws from the filmed stories and may guide people into deeper personal and community commitment to climate and social justice activism.

We are developing several different modes to present the Down to Earth materials. We hope to engage people of all ages, both the choir and those sitting on the fence, who may be moved to join the climate justice movement. Here are some of our plans:

  • A four-week experience that includes four workshops featuring our film, invited guest activists, visioning exercises, and time for sharing workshop participants' own stories arising out of daily journaling in the workbook guide.
  • A virtual workshop experience similar to the one described above.
  • A two-hour workshop including our film and time for reflection on filmed stories that spoke to audience members. A handout with opportunities for further reflection and action steps and resources.
With your help we can complete the film and materials and take the workshop on the road and into virtual reality. We offer perks that enable you to support the Down to Earth Project with a contribution, but also allow you to participate in the film and workshop experiences.
We would welcome your support...every little bit gets us closer to our goal. We appreciate your help in spreading the word to your family and friends about our Indiegogo campaign and our project. Future generations are counting on us! Thank you so much for your support!

---> New Stretch Goals! <---

We're excited to announce some new stretch goals for the campaign, which, if reached, will allow us to collaborate with musician and Portland local Kyle Morgan for an original score!

I first met Kyle when he joined the Tumbling Bones in 2013. Kyle is an inspired songwriter. If you haven’t heard his music before, you can get a taste here:


In order to make this collaboration possible we are introducing three levels of stretch goals, from the basics to the works.

Stretch Goal #1 (The Basics)- $7,000

If we can get our total up to $7,000 ($1,000 above our initial goal) we can get Kyle what he needs to record and mix a basic score with his own equipment, and have it professionally mastered.


Stretch Goal #2 (The Middle) - $8,000

If we can get our total up to $8,000 we can get Kyle two days of studio time with a professional audio engineer, more access to professional musicians, and more time overall.


Stretch Goal #3 (The Works) - $9,000

If we can get our total up to $9,000 we can get higher quality mastering, more studio time, and more time for Kyle and other musicians.

An original score by a musician of Kyle’s caliber could add so much to our film.

Can you help us make it a reality?

story:
The "No Ordinary Wind Power Design" project is a new and innovative concept, highly effectively using wind power in a decent way, not defacing your home or area and dedicated to help finding new ways in generating clean and responsible energy for the future.

All of today's wind power concepts have, two things in common: they all include the idea "as high as possible" and "as big as possible". This makes wind power dominant in a area used and causes light flickering and noises. These are the reasons why an area used for wind power plants is so ugly dominated by noise and flickering lights.

But how about that: Do you know those corners where always a strong wind blows? Have you ever worked on a roof and felt the wind right on the top? Ask window cleaners about the corners of skyscrapers!

What if we could acutually make use of those forces at existing places, even integrate the device harmonically in the surrounding, leaving the disadvantages of regular wind power plants behind such as ugly dominating the landscape, noise, and flickering lights?

We could ! Using this new wind turbine technology and design:

Covered on the roof or at a corner its nearly invisible and your house becomes a wind collector

Skyscrapers and industrial buildings equipped with those devices would produce an immense amount of energy 24 hours a day.

Even bridges with their exposed locations could become power plants

On the first look it does not seem to be a good idea attaching the new rotor on the house in this way as you can efficiently use the wind coming from only 2 directions.
But think again.

On the first hand in many areas  most of the time the wind blows form  only 2 opposite directions anyway and on the second hand you make usage out of the full surface of your roof and your house.


The angle of your roof will collect, compress and head the wind to the top of your roof so that in the end you receive even higher energy from the wind  as if new the rotor would be just erected vertically up in the sky.


It works the same way on the corners of a house. The wind is also collected, compressed and headed to the corners. That’s why it’s always more windy around a corner of a house as anywhere else. I am sure you already have experienced this effect.

Attaching the wind rotor vertically on the corners of a house, the full surface of your walls works as a wind collector multiplying the effectiveness of the device.



Help bringing this new design into production and launch it on the markets.

As this project is about clean responsible power and sustainability I want not only to produce the new wind turbine I also want to achieve that the new wind turbine is produced locally in your own country or area wherever possible.

I thought a lot about the rewards for your support. And I came to the conclusion that I do not offer a cup, a t-shirt or any other advertising material for your support. Because I think that you do not really need another cup or t-shirt with a logo on it and therefore I do not want to waste resources for production and transport/delivery of the items. Instead I offer you a set of wind data of your area  containing the directions and strength of the wind in your area - wherever this data is available - so that you can see if in your area it would make sense to install the new wind turbine.

This makes wind power dominant in a area used and causes light flickering and noises. These are the reasons why an area used for wind power plants is so ugly dominated by noise and flickering lights.But how about that: Do you know those corners where always a strong wind blows? Have you ever worked on a roof and felt the wind right on the top? Ask window cleaners about the corners of skyscrapers!What if we could acutually make use of those forces at existing places, even integrate the device harmonically in the surrounding, leaving the disadvantages of regular wind power plants behind such as ugly dominating the landscape, noise, and flickering lights?
We could ! Using this new wind turbine technology and design:

Covered on the roof or at a corner its nearly invisible and your house becomes a wind collector


Skyscrapers and industrial buildings equipped with those devices would produce an immense amount of energy 24 hours a day.



Even bridges with their exposed locations could become power plants
On the first look it does not seem to be a good idea attaching the new rotor on the house in this way as you can efficiently use the wind coming from only 2 directions.
But think again.

On the
first hand in many areas  most of the
time the wind blows form  only 2 opposite
directions anyway and on the second hand you make usage out of the full surface
of your roof and your house.
The angle
of your roof will collect, compress and head the wind to the top of your roof
so that in the end you receive even higher energy from the wind  as if new the rotor would be just erected
vertically up in the sky.






It
works the same way on the corners of a house. The wind is also collected,
compressed and headed to the corners. That’s why it’s always more windy around
a corner of a house as anywhere else. I am sure you already have experienced
this effect.

Attaching the
wind rotor vertically on the corners of a house, the full surface of your walls
works as a wind collector multiplying the effectiveness of the device.





Help bringing this
new design into production and launch it on the markets.
As this project is about clean responsible power and sustainability I want not only to produce the new wind turbine I also want to achieve that the new wind turbine is produced locally in your own country or area wherever possible.


I thought a lot about the rewards for
your support. And I came to the conclusion that I do not offer a cup, a t-shirt
or any other advertising material for your support. Because I think that you do
not really need another cup or t-shirt with a logo on it and therefore I do not
want to waste resources for production and transport/delivery of the items.
Instead I offer you a set of wind data of your area  containing the directions and strength of the
wind in your area - wherever this data is available - so that you can see if in
your area it would make sense to install the new wind turbine.

story:
Our Story 

  • Whale Scout is a Washington State nonprofit applying for federal 501(c)3 status.  Our mission is to protect Pacific Northwest whales through land-based conservation experiences. 
  • We provide the public with expert whale naturalists who help others spot whales from shore.  Not only do our volunteers provide information about the whales, but they encourage those who have fallen in love with watching whales to participate in salmon-habitat restoration events around Puget Sound. 
  •  Watching whales responsibly from shore and taking action to protect and restore food sources for endangered whales is what Whale Scout is all about.
  • By contributing, you help outfit our volunteers so they can do great work for our whales and our communities.  We already have the volunteers and now all they need is the gear.  Wouldn't YOU want to watch whales with an expert for FREE at a local park? 

What Whale Scout Needs & What You Get

  • Each volunteer needs an identifying vest and a booklet of weatherproof educational materials to make the biggest impact with the people they talk to.  The costs of these materials plus the training on logistics and volunteer orientation is $100 per volunteer.
  • Our goal is to raise enough money to outfit 20 volunteers stationed all over Puget Sound. 

                                                             

Vests to identify volunteers as whale experts and make them approachable with weatherproof educational materials

  • Check out the unique perks for donating on the right.  Not only will you feel great about donating and about the possibility that YOU could watch whales with a Whale Scout volunteer at a beach near you, but you can also redeem cool gifts for your contribution.  
  • As a stretch goal, we are setting our sights on $3,500 with the extra funds going toward the remaining legal and application fees for our 501(c)3 status.  Once we have this, we will finally be eligible for grant opportunities!

The Impact

The Southern Resident killer whales that swim the waters of Puget Sound are endangered and in serious trouble. With a two year gap in successful births, the population has declined to only 79 individuals - its lowest number since the mid-1980's. Whale Scout is taking a proactive approach and setting a positive example toward recovering this population by engaging in responsible whale watching from the shore, and also striving to turn whale watchers into salmon restoration activists. While the decline of a population of animals can be complex, the root causes are often simple, offering us some straightforward solutions for population recovery.

"What we have to do is ensure there is sufficient food supply for the whales...you can't have a pet if you don't feed it.  That's the first thing I learned when I had a little puppy, you have to take care of it."  Ken Balcomb - Whale Scout Podcast


Only 79 Southern Resident killer whales remain in Puget Sound
Habitat restoration for salmon is considered by many scientists to be the key to the recovery of Puget Sound killer whales and is our top priority.  We show people and teach people about the whales, they fall in love, and everyone works together to restore the vital food sources of the amazing creatures so that there will be whales to watch for future generations. One of the primary roles volunteers have is to turn whale lovers into salmon lovers, by encouraging people to attend our "Whale Scout Helpin' Out" events.  At these events we partner with amazing local groups already doing great work to restore salmon-bearing streams and rivers.  

"Forests, especially ones near salmon spawning streams, mean something that helps grow whale food." David Bain - Whale Scout Podcast

 Research shows that when people have experiences with whales coupled with the presence of an expert naturalist, they are more likely to engage in stewardship activities that will ultimately bring positive benefits for the whales.  Our Whale Scout volunteers strive to do just that and more.  


Our first "Helpin' Out" event was attended by over 35 people!  We spread over 20 cubic yards of mulch and planted over 200 trees all in the name of healthy salmon to feed orcas!

More reasons to support Whale Scout:

  • We provide FREE whale watching experiences at local parks providing a service to those who may not be able to afford trips to the San Juan Islands or other whale watching destinations.
  • We support and contribute to local sightings networks providing scientists and managers with important data.
  • By watching whales from shore we are engaging in responsible whale watching by not contributing to ocean noise or presence of vessels on the water, which have been shown to negatively affect whales.
  • In just one "Helpin' Out" event we had over 35 people spread 20 cubic yards of mulch and plant 200 trees!
  • As the "Blackfish effect" sweeps the country, more people are choosing to not support institutions which display orcas such as SeaWorld.  Whale Scout provides another opportunity for people to view orcas in the wild for FREE.  
  • Watching whales gives us so much joy and inspiration.  Whale Scout strives to reciprocate by restoring the whales' food sources, salmon.
  • We are a volunteer-run organization - all of your contributions go towards the benefit of the whales, the environment, and our local communities. 

    We need your help today. Please donate now!

    So you have donated and want to do more?  This is what you can do to help:

    • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.  Share this on facebook, twitter, your forehead, wherever!  You never know who in your social network might be a closet whale-lover.
    Thank you!

    Whitney Neugebauer, Director of Whale Scout 
    Director@whalescout.org

We are a volunteer-run organization - all of your contributions go towards the benefit of the whales, the environment, and our local communities. 

  We need your help today. Please donate now! So you have donated and want to do more?  This is what you can do to help: 
Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.  Share this on facebook, twitter, your forehead, wherever!  You never know who in your social network might be a closet whale-lover.


Thank you!




Whitney Neugebauer, Director of Whale Scout 

Director@whalescout.org

story:
Summary

How do farmers farm if the soil is void of nutrients? Without the ability to grow proper vegetation, how do the farmers of Haiti expect to provide for their families? These are questions worth asking.

My name is Maggie Jackson. I'm a 26-year old barista currently living just outside of Denver, Colorado. I have no background in agriculture nor in business, so how in the world did I get involved in this? 

I started going down to Haiti just a few months after the devastating earthquake in January 2010 and couldn't stop going back. I've taken 7 trips since then, some of which were multiple months at a time. As a result, I have learned the Haitian Creole language and have been able to ask some bigger questions like, "How can we create real change in the lives of the Haitian people? How can we help them help themselves?" Through this journey of questions, I have learned some life-changing answers and have stumbled upon a couple organizations who once asked the same questions. Where I am now, what I have learned and the resources that are present before me, allow me to know without a doubt that I'd be totally missing it if I didn't move forward in this. So, what is this?

Well, first you need to understand that farming is the only resource in what is considered the poorest country in the world, but  there seem to be so few organizations down in Haiti who are focused on this. Due to the drastic deforestation in the 1970's and the erosion that came as a result, there is an extreme lack of nutrients in the soil to grow proper vegetation. The people of Haiti, specifically Seguin which lies at the very top of the mountain, need more than just relief work. What they need is long-term change and the ability to stand on their own two feet. What they need is to be able to create a livelihood for their family.

But why reinvent the wheel? Luckily, I am not the first to take action and those before have offered to educate those to come.

CODEP, an organization currently working at the base of the mountain, took action on this exact same issue over 20 years ago. Their main program is to teach communities of Haitians a natural process of farming which works with the soil to create organic nutrients and allow for rich, healthy vegetation and even grow some vegetables during a season when they were originally believed to not be able to be grown (check out CODEP's webpage if you would like to learn the actual process - http://www.haitifundinc.org). They have spent over 2 decades working alongside the Haitian people to learn how best to serve them. As a result, there are now 7 different areas throughout Haiti, each inhabiting miles after square miles of land which were once close to barren and now crowded with growth and possibility (or moving in that direction). The people of Haiti not involved with CODEP have noticed the change in the product that these Haitian farmers have created and will now pay an even higher price simply if the name, CODEP, is placed on the particular product. Not only that, but CODEP, through leadership training and meaningful relationships, is almost all Haitian run and operated. Once I stumbled upon CODEP, visited their properties and spoke with the Haitians involved, I knew I had found my answer. I knew that I needed to take that answer to the people at the very top of the mountain who could never have even dreamed that such an answer could exist. 


What We Need & What You Get

What is needed is $3,000 in order to get this idea off the ground. Every dollar raised will go directly to the project. There isn't a trustee board who will pocket the funds. No gimmicks, just what you see. If you have any questions, feel free to ask. The layout of where all the money will be going is found below:

$1,400 plane tickets for me and my husband, Patrick

$300 transportation while in Haiti

$70 payment for Haitian leaders from CODEP

$30 lunch and coffee provided during meeting with Haitian farmers

$200 tools for farmers to begin the process

$1,000 incentives for farmers and reimbursement for land used

John Winings, the Executive Director of CODEP, has offered to provide me with all the necessities to make this happen. I will be learning what worked and what didn't work, so that I will not have to make the same mistakes CODEP had made in the beginning while learning how to work with the norms of the Haitian culture. CODEP will also be providing the Haitian leaders (each have farmed with CODEP for 20+ years) to journey up the mountains to teach the farmers of Sequin the process.


The Impact

By partnering with CODEP and providing the opportunity for these farmers in the mountains to learn and establish this process, we are not only growing rich, healthy vegetation, but we are literally changing lives. The level of poverty in the mountains is unexplainable, but it is not without hope. Handouts only go so far and are unsustainable, but the ability to provide for one's family can impact individuals, communities, whole towns for years to come. The process itself does not only focus on the farming, but long-term looks also at community needs through building schools and, if the farmer goes five years without cutting down the trees they are growing, their family receives a 2-room house with treated lumber. It is something those in the mountains have never even dreamed of. 

I intend to not just oversee the farmers, but join with them; get to know each of them personally, along with their families, and create opportunities for them to learn leadership skills and join in the decision-making processes of Deeply Rooted. It is for the Haitians and will soon be run by the Haitians. 


Risks & Challenges

I must be completely transparent and admit that I am unaware of what's to come. Maybe that's a terrible fundraising strategy, to admit that, but my journey thus far has only allowed me to see the next step (while dreaming about the whole staircase). There is a chance that the farmers of Sequin will hear what it is that those of CODEP are saying, but refuse to buy into it. There is a chance that the process, though it works amazing at the valley level, may not be nearly as successful in the rocky soil of the mountains. There are many possibilities against us, but we must try. I have the backing of a more than experienced organization as well as the leader of a community of farmers in Seguin who has given me the go ahead, so here we go. I cannot guarantee anything, but that I will try and if that doesn't work, I will try again. I have gotten this far by being faithful in simply what is before me and I intend on seeing it through to the end. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to financially help? I've been there myself in the past, but that doesn't mean you can't still contribute. Please share this post!!! Available to do so is the Indiegogo share tools which make it easy to do so. Share it on FaceBook, Twitter, in everyday conversations. Anything and everything helps!

story:
*EXCLUSIVE* For the last few days of the campaign, we are offering a special perk! Want a snazzy Kanga stocking to adorn your mantel? Here's your chance! Made by a local seamstress, there's only a few of these beautiful holiday stockings, so order now!

The Flower Kanga Stocking

Or, The Holiday Kanga Stocking

Back by popular demand, we’ve got Santa’s only option for your loved ones who’ve misbehaved: coal made from poop, naturally! 

Sanivation has provided hundreds of people in Kenya with a safe and healthy place to use the loo and take a poo with our sanitation service. We transform the poo into power, THIS COAL, that makes the perfect gift for anyone who has been “naughty.” We both know there’s at someone in your life who needs this stocking stuffer. 

Don’t worry, our coal is completely safe and doesn’t smell (but you don’t have to tell them that!) Order Santa’s Stinkiest Stocking by December 16th and it will make it to their doorstep by Christmas.

With Santa’s Stinkiest Stocking we’ll send three of our charcoal briquettes, nestled in a small,  holiday stocking, to your mischievous mate, naughty neighbor, ornery offspring, or whomever you think would get a kick out of getting coal for a cause this Christmas. We’ll even top off the stocking with a personalized note explaining why they’re getting this special coal.

Have a friend that’s been extra naughty this year? For $100, name a toilet in their honor! The average toilet processes over 1,800 yule logs (aka poops!) each year. That’s 1,800 trips to the toilet that people can now take in the safety of their own home instead of over a dirty and dangerous shared pit latrine. We'll even send you a picture of the toilet with their name written on it!

These are our toilets – BlueBox! They are portable, container based toilets that we install in peoples’ homes for free. Then we collect the waste twice a week and bring it to our processing facility to transform it into the coal you are about to send to your loved ones.

Not only will people chuckle at this coal, they will also feel warm for the holidays. The coal actually burns longer than traditional charcoal. More importantly, people will feel warm in their hearts. You’re helping us, Sanivation, a Kenyan, award-winning social enterprise (see awards below), tackle two big challenges:

  1. Preventing diarrheal diseases. Everyday, 2,200 children die worldwide from sanitation related illnesses. In fact, diarrhea is the leading cause of death in Kenya for children under five—largely because 95% of human poo is dumped into the environment without treatment (This is silly, particularly when it could be coal instead!)
  2. Saving forests by replacing traditional charcoal with coal derived from human poo!

Hundreds of people in Kenya now have safe and clean in-home toilets to take care of business because of our sanitation service.  With your support, we’ll deploy 500 toilets in the coming year and save over 50,000 trees!

Each briquette bundle YOU buy will help us save 22 trees and lower the risk of diarrhea disease in local communities.

*When we receive your order, we will send you an e-mail to get the names and addresses you would like to send Santa's Stinkiest Stocking to!*

Testimonials

Upon receiving this gift,

Your friend might say:

“Sh*t! Coal!” …. and she would be accurate.

Your husband might say:

“Aww, I’m on Santa’s naughty list again!?"

Early user reviews:

“Lumps of coal for Christmas? Really Jon?! It’s all I ever wanted!” -Your next door neighbor

“This is the s**ttiest piece of coal I’ve ever seen.” -Coal expert

“Can’t wait to throw these logs on the fire!” -  Your local lumberjack

“Even I don’t smell anything!” – Maia, Sanivation’s Mascot

Actual briquettes customer reviews:

“The local charcoal produced a lot of smoke and gave headaches and hurt the eyes. The Sanivation Briquettes make no smoke at all!”- Dennis

“I light it in the morning and it can cook until 3 or 4pm so it saves me money.”- Esther

“Where are the briquettes?! We want your briquettes!” - Eli

We take #4 very seriously.

 

Back By Popular Demand

Last year, we shipped out over 150 Stockings Full of Sh*t. And people thought it was AMAZING. So much so, that they’ve demanded we do it again. We couldn’t say no. Because we secretly all have someone we know who needs a little coal in their stocking.

We’re launching an Indiegogo to make it even bigger this year. In 2015, naughty individuals received a burlap sack with briquettes. This year, we’ve upgraded – you’re getting a stocking!

What We Do

We are Sanivation – a social enterprise reimagining healthy and safe sanitation services for urbanizing communities, starting in Naivasha, Kenya. We install modern, container-based toilets in peoples’ homes for free and collect the waste bi-weekly from the households we service. Then, instead of dumping the waste, we transform it into a clean burning alternative to charcoal using solar technologies we developed in the field, for the field.

Who We Are

We are an eclectic group of passionate engineers, innovators, and operators on a mission to transform sanitation and fuel provision for the urban poor!

We believe that everyone deserves access to safe and dignified sanitation, every day. Our team is working to make this a reality, starting for the people of Naivasha, Kenya and Kakuma Refugee Camp and growing rapidly.

Meet our Co-Founders

Andrew Foote – CEO –

Favorite Poop Joke: If the Queen farts, is it a noble gas?

Always the mediator, Andrew received degrees in both Cultural Anthropology and Environmental Engineering to create human-centered technical solutions to WASH challenges. After working in seven countries, Andrew saw the light with community-led and market-driven solutions and started this team effort to tackle the sanitation and fuel challenges.

Emily Woods – CTO –

Favorite Poop Joke: Poop is a crap palindrome.

While blonde and small in stature, her teammates on Kenya’s National Rugby team can tell you that Emily packs a punch! Emily has a passion for applying simple technical solutions to tackle major development opportunities. This passion has guided her to lead WASH projects around the world, pursue a Master’s Degree in Energy Resources from the University of California-Berkeley, and found Sanivation.

Dickson Ochieng – Director of Government Relations –

Favorite Poop Joke: What do you call Clark Kent with diarrhea? Poop-erman.

A believer in the power and participation of the people to solve seemingly intractable problems, Dickson takes charge of ensuring the local government and community are involved in every step of Sanivation’s development. After successfully establishing and running and IT consulting company for four years, Dickson was interested in working with disadvantaged Kenyans – so he went back to University and got a second degree in Community Development and Social Work!

Spread the Word!

Find our press kit here. 

Stay in Touch!

Connect with us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram!

Check out our website to learn more: www.sanivation.com

Or send us an email at coal@sanivation.com

Your support and suggestions mean the world to us!

Partners

Press

Business Insider – Kenya Start-up Turns poo into fuel 

Fast Company - This Toilet-As-A-Business Startup Is Turning Kenyan Poop Into Fuel Briquettes 

Al Jazeera - Human waste fuels Kenyan Homes  

BBC - Toilet tech proves that where there's muck there's brass 

ASME - Waste Not: addressing the Sanitation and Fuel Need  

This is Africa - Charcoal addiction: How can Africa’s households kick the habit?  

Awards

                                            Forbes                    Social Good                       WTN

Want to support us without sending coal?

We recognize that not everyone has someone that they want to send coal to and some of you may just want to support us. We will accept your contributions to help us provide more people access to a toilet in their home. Our toilets currently cost $50 to produce.

You can donate here.
story_txt:
*EXCLUSIVE* For the last few days of the campaign, we are offering a special perk! Want a snazzy Kanga stocking to adorn your mantel? Here's your chance! Made by a local seamstress, there's only a few of these beautiful holiday stockings, so order now!The Flower Kanga StockingOr, The Holiday Kanga StockingBack by popular demand, we’ve got Santa’s only option for your loved ones who’ve misbehaved: coal made from poop, naturally! Sanivation has provided hundreds of people in Kenya with a safe and healthy place to use the loo and take a poo with our sanitation service. We transform the poo into power, THIS COAL, that makes the perfect gift for anyone who has been “naughty.” We both know there’s at someone in your life who needs this stocking stuffer. Don’t worry, our coal is completely safe and doesn’t smell (but you don’t have to tell them that!) Order Santa’s Stinkiest Stocking by December 16th and it will make it to their doorstep by Christmas.With Santa’s Stinkiest Stocking we’ll send three of our charcoal briquettes, nestled in a small,  holiday stocking, to your mischievous mate, naughty neighbor, ornery offspring, or whomever you think would get a kick out of getting coal for a cause this Christmas. We’ll even top off the stocking with a personalized note explaining why they’re getting this special coal.Have a friend that’s been extra naughty this year? For $100, name a toilet in their honor! The average toilet processes over 1,800 yule logs (aka poops!) each year. That’s 1,800 trips to the toilet that people can now take in the safety of their own home instead of over a dirty and dangerous shared pit latrine. We'll even send you a picture of the toilet with their name written on it!These are our toilets – BlueBox! They are portable, container based toilets that we install in peoples’ homes for free. Then we collect the waste twice a week and bring it to our processing facility to transform it into the coal you are about to send to your loved ones.Not only will people chuckle at this coal, they will also feel warm for the holidays. The coal actually burns longer than traditional charcoal. More importantly, people will feel warm in their hearts. You’re helping us, Sanivation, a Kenyan, award-winning social enterprise (see awards below), tackle two big challenges: 

Preventing diarrheal diseases. Everyday, 2,200 children die worldwide from sanitation related illnesses. In fact, diarrhea is the leading cause of death in Kenya for children under five—largely because 95% of human poo is dumped into the environment without treatment (This is silly, particularly when it could be coal instead!)

Saving forests by replacing traditional charcoal with coal derived from human poo!
Hundreds of people in Kenya now have safe and clean in-home toilets to take care of business because of our sanitation service.  With your support, we’ll deploy 500 toilets in the coming year and save over 50,000 trees!Each briquette bundle YOU buy will help us save 22 trees and lower the risk of diarrhea disease in local communities.*When we receive your order, we will send you an e-mail to get the names and addresses you would like to send Santa's Stinkiest Stocking to!*TestimonialsUpon receiving this gift, Your friend might say:“Sh*t! Coal!” …. and she would be accurate.Your husband might say:“Aww, I’m on Santa’s naughty list again!?"Early user reviews:“Lumps of coal for Christmas? Really Jon?! It’s all I ever wanted!” -Your next door neighbor“This is the s**ttiest piece of coal I’ve ever seen.” -Coal expert“Can’t wait to throw these logs on the fire!” -  Your local lumberjack“Even I don’t smell anything!” – Maia, Sanivation’s MascotActual briquettes customer reviews:“The local charcoal produced a lot of smoke and gave headaches and hurt the eyes. The Sanivation Briquettes make no smoke at all!”- Dennis“I light it in the morning and it can cook until 3 or 4pm so it saves me money.”- Esther“Where are the briquettes?! We want your briquettes!” - EliWe take #4 very seriously. Back By Popular DemandLast year, we shipped out over 150 Stockings Full of Sh*t. And people thought it was AMAZING. So much so, that they’ve demanded we do it again. We couldn’t say no. Because we secretly all have someone we know who needs a little coal in their stocking.We’re launching an Indiegogo to make it even bigger this year. In 2015, naughty individuals received a burlap sack with briquettes. This year, we’ve upgraded – you’re getting a stocking!What We DoWe are Sanivation – a social enterprise reimagining healthy and safe sanitation services for urbanizing communities, starting in Naivasha, Kenya. We install modern, container-based toilets in peoples’ homes for free and collect the waste bi-weekly from the households we service. Then, instead of dumping the waste, we transform it into a clean burning alternative to charcoal using solar technologies we developed in the field, for the field.Who We AreWe are an eclectic group of passionate engineers, innovators, and operators on a mission to transform sanitation and fuel provision for the urban poor!We believe that everyone deserves access to safe and dignified sanitation, every day. Our team is working to make this a reality, starting for the people of Naivasha, Kenya and Kakuma Refugee Camp and growing rapidly.Meet our Co-FoundersAndrew Foote – CEO –Favorite Poop Joke: If the Queen farts, is it a noble gas?Always the mediator, Andrew received degrees in both Cultural Anthropology and Environmental Engineering to create human-centered technical solutions to WASH challenges. After working in seven countries, Andrew saw the light with community-led and market-driven solutions and started this team effort to tackle the sanitation and fuel challenges.Emily Woods – CTO –Favorite Poop Joke: Poop is a crap palindrome.While blonde and small in stature, her teammates on Kenya’s National Rugby team can tell you that Emily packs a punch! Emily has a passion for applying simple technical solutions to tackle major development opportunities. This passion has guided her to lead WASH projects around the world, pursue a Master’s Degree in Energy Resources from the University of California-Berkeley, and found Sanivation.Dickson Ochieng – Director of Government Relations –Favorite Poop Joke: What do you call Clark Kent with diarrhea? Poop-erman.A believer in the power and participation of the people to solve seemingly intractable problems, Dickson takes charge of ensuring the local government and community are involved in every step of Sanivation’s development. After successfully establishing and running and IT consulting company for four years, Dickson was interested in working with disadvantaged Kenyans – so he went back to University and got a second degree in Community Development and Social Work!Spread the Word!Find our press kit here. Stay in Touch!Connect with us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram!Check out our website to learn more: www.sanivation.comOr send us an email at coal@sanivation.comYour support and suggestions mean the world to us!PartnersPressBusiness Insider – Kenya Start-up Turns poo into fuel Fast Company - This Toilet-As-A-Business Startup Is Turning Kenyan Poop Into Fuel Briquettes Al Jazeera - Human waste fuels Kenyan Homes  BBC - Toilet tech proves that where there's muck there's brass ASME - Waste Not: addressing the Sanitation and Fuel Need  This is Africa - Charcoal addiction: How can Africa’s households kick the habit?  Awards                                            Forbes                    Social Good                       WTNWant to support us without sending coal?We recognize that not everyone has someone that they want to send coal to and some of you may just want to support us. We will accept your contributions to help us provide more people access to a toilet in their home. Our toilets currently cost $50 to produce.You can donate here.

story:
We are :Playtime Festival, the architecture and urbanism festival that invites Ho Chi Minh City residents to re-discover the urban space in a playful atmosphere while engaging in discussions on sustainable urban futures for all.

For the second year running, our attention will be focussed on the luscious urban paradise that is the Binh Quoi Peninsula of Binh Thanh district.

Over 2 week-ends, we will host tours, workshops, discussions, screenings, exhibitions, performances and games around a set of temporary installations. These activities will invite citizens to explore the area and question its present and future: can Binh Quoi retain its natural and vernacular identity as Ho Chi Minh City continues to develop?

This year, we need to call on you, architects, designers, creatives, environmentalists, zero-wasters... citizens, to support all the individuals, organisations and amazing people who come together to make Playtime the nurturing, inspiring and enlightening event that it is. Help us bring inspiration to make humane architecture & planning, nature education and sustainable lifestyles part of everyday habits in Ho Chi Minh City!

 

 

 

How much?

To make :Playtime be the festive, nurturing event it should be, we need 15,000 USD. It is the minimum to fairly compensate all organisers, all the team members who’ve worked hard the past months, and to achieve our sustainability plan (check FAQ).

 

How will we use it?

Any money raised in our campaign will go towards financing:

  • The temporary installations which will host the festival: designed by architects of Ateliers Mở Đât (HCMC) and Aupa-urba+Patrick Bertrand (Paris), the structures are a reflection on the natural and vernacular qualities of Binh Quoi. Using sustainable and recycling materials, they explore the idea of a new vernacular that answers the contemporary challenges faced by architects;
  • The activities which will specifically address the natural and vernacular identity of Binh Quoi and involve both Binh Quoi residents and HCMC dwellers, such as workshops, tours, games, screenings, talks, performances, banquet-dinner and exhibition;
  • The participatory research-action project that enquires into the topic of a sustainable Binh Quoi and is composed of three parts: months of field-work aimed at better understanding how people relate to the spaces they inhabit; the festival, which will then be a culmination and continuation of that research, as well as a catalyst for a change in the community; and a later publication building on these accumulated finds;
  • The communication, logistics and operation costs: from transportation to administrative fees, to a fair compensation for the volunteers and the organisation staff.

 

 

 

What do you get?

In exchange of your help, we will offer you unique perks which will be designed during the festival by the people who will participate to the various activities:

  • The Seed - Set of 5 Postcards: with this little perk, you will get a beautiful collection of varied looks on the Binh Quoi peninsula grasped during the Festival. Which one will you choose, the Sketch or the Photo series?;
  • Make the Wall - Unique A2 Poster: How many beautiful images of Binh Quoi will come out from the participants' minds, eyes, hands? Seize the opportunity to get a unique record of the festival. You can choose to have on your poster a sketch or a photo made during the Festival's sketch/photo tours... or a surprise;
  • The Handy - A special Totebag: A totebag like no other: one made out of used fabrics and linoprinted with love. We're upcycling fabrics, shirts to offer you a unique and useful bag, with a special touch from Binh Quoi;
  • The Leafy - Our Festival Zine: A compilation of great works made by participants during the Festival - photos, sketches, flowerprints... - accompanied by interviews, questions and surprises;
  • The Altruist - Give back: you don’t get anything, you just give it all to the locals because all you care about is the impact of our festival on their lifestyles. We’ll re-use the materials of the pavilions to create resting and playground areas;
  • The Chatty - Dinner & VIP visit with the architects and team: come hear the insights, come see through our eyes, and exchange your views with us!

Nice, right? Since all our perks are made out of Festival’s materials, we’ll work super hard on the week after the festival to produce all of these and send them as soon as by mid-August.

 

What if we don’t reach the goals?

We selected a flexible funding to make sure that even if we get a little, it can help us make Playtime happen.

 

 

 

Why why why?

Yes, why hold an architecture festival?

Architecture & design festivals happen all over the world and are rightfully celebrated as being useful, interactive and entertaining tools with which we can engage with our cities. However, in many countries (of the "global South"), the prevalent thought is that nowadays time is not for discussion but for development - and modernity cannot wait. But with environmental urgency looming and the direct threat it carries to the human race, we could not disagree more.

Our event therefore aims to question: What better time is there for discussion, than now? In Ho Chi Minh City, we cannot wait for an ‘after’. Our social networks are flooded with affirmations of urgency, calling on us to make changes. :Playtime is one of the initiatives burgeoning from ‘down there’. We want to facilitate discussions here to inspire citizens to play an active part in imagining and moulding the landscapes of their future.

 

 

:Playtime’s purpose

Through the festival format, we want to trigger a momentum where architects, artists, environmentalists, creatives who work daily on these topics can exchange with citizens with a nascent-to-strong environmental awareness. With the relatively small size of the festival, and centralized geographical location in Binh Quoi, we make sure activities are meaningful and fitting to our theme. With a wide variety of activities and a playful tone, we hope that people can find the inspiration they need to make small changes in their daily habits.

 

How can :Playtime happen?

Bottom-up events like :Playtime are still rare and lack sufficient investment -  independently organised and funded, they have to be supported by organisers, participants and the community. However, we believe this is a chance to keep :Playtime accessible and affordable for all, and truly inspiring. Last year, we were lucky enough to have amazing local partners who took upon themselves to make :Playtime happen. This year, we want to be fair with all of them and compensate them for the hard work we are demanding them.

That’s why we are now calling on the wider community to support all the individuals, organisations and citizens who come together to make :Playtime the nurturing and enlightening event that it is. Help us make :Playtime a sustainable reality!

 

The Mysterious Gardens of Binh Quoi by Anne Jauréguiberry

 

 

 

Who are we?

 

team ronde by Alice Narcy

 

This year, :Playtime is organised by:

  • An ordinary city, an independent initiative based in Ho Chi Minh City aimed at raising awareness about urban and architectural issues through cultural action;
  • Ateliers Mo Dat, an architecture and landscape studio founded in Ho Chi Minh City by Hoang Le Manh Thang and Bonnano Katia,
  • Aupa-Urba + Patrick Bertrand, architecture and urbanism studio from Paris, founded by Anne Jauréguiberry, cooperating with architect-urbanist Patrick Bertrand. Anne and Patrick are artists in residence of the Villa Saigon programme*.

Graviting around that core is an amazing team of hardworking people:

  • Graphic Design: Gia Khanh, graphic designer
  • PR & Marketing: Tipler Kate, writer-photographer
  • Research: Lê Nguyễn Huy Bảo, architect; Lee Alex, artist-architect; Mai Linh, landscape-architect; Nguyen Ngoc Xuan Quynh, urban planning student; Nguyen Tran Khoa, architect; Piau Emma, designer; Tran N. Son, urban planner.

 

*Thanks to the residency programme "Villa Saigon", the French Institute in Vietnam creates a gateway in between French young contemporary creation and the Vietnamese cultural scene, by inviting each year a dozen of French artists who wish to develop a creative project in partnership with different local cultural actors.  

:Playtime is also supported by the French Institute in Vietnam.

 

No money, no honey?

Of course, we know money doesn’t make it all. You can also help us by sharing and spreading the word to your friends and relatives on Facebook, Instagram... Tell them how much :Playtime is worth for you and why they should care about it too!

Young Women's Leadership is a peer led organization committed to the visionary leadership and solidarity of young women and female bodied people world wide.

This leadership retreat will enable me to build connections and power with my sisters in the environmental movement. Time is running out for our planet, We must perfect our strategies and grow our organizations to overcome the destruction of our Earth and the beautiful people and creatures that dwell upon it. Help me protect what you and I love.

 

Story of Self

 

As an individual, I have tried to be a conscious consumer, I have been a vegetarian since I was a teenager, an avid recycler, and have also tried to buy only environmentally friendly products.  But I realized after the BP oil disaster that as an individual going about my individual’s paltry little way of being  environmentally conscious, I was having no effect whatsoever on the preservation our planet.

I heard about a Greenpeace Action Camp through a fellow nuke activist and applied and was accepted. I learned how to climb, pilot boats, and use art to enhance action, I also met amazing people who introduced me to more amazing people and those connections led me to become a Greenpeace Community Coordinator an unpaid position. I realize that as an individual my impact on saving the planet is negligible, but as a part of an army of impassioned committed organized individuals our impact will change the world.

The cost of the retreat is $450 plus airfare which is $384. I will handle incidental travel expenses on my own. Anything you can contribute would be greatly appreciated, currently I am not employed and funds are tight. Thank you so much.

Peace be with you,

Christine

story:
Help rebuilding after earthquakes

With this campaign, we would like to request your contribution for helping victims of earthquakes occurred in Italy's regions in the last years: 2012 Emilia Romagna, 2011 Abruzzo (L'Aquila was one of the most damaged city). As Government funding is very limited without private development rebuilding after these natural disasters can take years or even decades.

Funds gathered with this campaign are going to be used as follows:

  • Half of funds will be entirely devolved to organizations directly involved in rebuilding damaged houses, churches and ancient monuments.

  • The remaining funds will be invested to organize night benefit concerts (one or more depending on total campaign contribution) to collect additional funds on behalf of the mentioned organizations.

No matter how much your contribution can be. It will certainly be a great generosity gesture towards those people who have lost a lot during the natural events mentioned above.

Who we are

“Associazione Musicale Eschilo” is a no profit organization regularly registered at the Italy's region of Lazio. It was founded in 1995 with the aim to promote the knowledge, practice and dissemination of music and artistic activities as well as language learning, diction, acting, and the like.

Since 1995, in parallel to the teaching activities, we have always worked with both the City of Rome and the municipalities of the province to organize public concerts, inaugurations, cultural seasons, conferences and parties.

In addition, we have got partnerships with public institutions. In particular, we have arranged instrumental and music courses in kindergartens, primary and secondary schools under the auspices of the Municipality of Rome.

The need of funds

Our goal is to collect funds on behalf of organizations involved in rebuilding damaged houses, churches and ancient monuments. Half of these funds will be directly devolved to the organizations. The other half will be invested to organize one or more night benefit concerts in Rome, depending on how much we will gather with this campaign. During these benefit events we will both commemorate the deaths of the natural disasters and at the same time we will collect additional funds to devolve.

We will use the money of this campaign to pay for the following things:

  • The place where the events will occur

  • The taxes for making public music events

  • The musicians (orchestra, conductor, choir and soloists) engaged for the events. Nevertheless, it will be up to them contributing to the fund for the organizations by donating all or part of what they get for the performances.

  • Advertisement to achieve 2000 people attending the events and contributing to collect funds to devolve during the events.

Hereafter the list of proposals for single performance with related cost follows.

 

Messa da Requiem by Giuseppe Verdi

The Messa da Requiem by Giuseppe Verdi is a musical setting of the Roman Catholic funeral mass (Requiem) for four soloists, double choir and orchestra. It was composed in memory of Alessandro Manzoni, an Italian poet and novelist much admired by Verdi. The first performance in San Marco in Milan on 22 May 1874 marked the first anniversary of Manzoni's death. The work was at one time called the Manzoni Requiem. It is typically performed in a concert of around 85–90 minutes.

25.000 euro are necessary for single performance of the Messa da Requiem by Giuseppe Verdi

 

Requiem Mass by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

The Requiem Mass in D minor (K. 626) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was composed in Vienna in 1791 and left unfinished at the composer's death on December 5. A completion by Franz Xaver Süssmayr was delivered to Count Franz von Walsegg, who had anonymously commissioned the piece for a requiem Mass to commemorate the February 14 anniversary of his wife's death.

It is one of the most enigmatic pieces of music ever composed, mostly because of the myths and controversies surrounding it, especially around how much of the piece was completed by Mozart before his death.

The Requiem is scored for 2 basset horns in F, 2 bassoons, 2 trumpets in D, 3 trombones (alto, tenor & bass), timpani (2 drums), violins, viola and basso continuo (cello, double bass, and organ). The vocal forces include soprano, contralto, tenor, and bass soloists and a SATB mixed choir. 

18.000 euro are necessary for single performance of the Requiem Mass by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

 

Petite Messe Solennelle by Gioachino Rossini

Gioachino Rossini's Petite Messe Solennelle was written in 1863 and described by the composer as "the last of my péchés de vieillesse" (sins of old age). The composer specified twelve singers in all, with the soloists doubling the SATB chorus, and scored it for two pianos and harmonium.

9.000 euro are necessary for single performance of the Petite Messe Solennelle by Gioachino Rossini

 

In case we will not collect enough funds we will fund cheaper concerts for the same goal.

 

You will be informed here about the events, which will occur in 2013. We will let you know about the following things:

  • The day and the place where they will be so that if you wish to personally attend you will be very welcome!

  • How much we will collect during events to be donated for rebuilding damaged places.

  • The organizations that will receive our donation and how they will use those funds.

 

Ways you can help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Give whatever you can. Lots of small contributions will add up to make a big impact!

  • If you are on any social networks such as Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, etc please consider posting a link or sending an announcement about our fund-raising effort to your contacts.

 

– THANK YOU -

9.000 euro are necessary for single performance of the Petite Messe Solennelle by Gioachino Rossini
 
In case we will not collect enough funds we will fund cheaper concerts for the same goal.
 
You will be informed here about the events, which will occur in 2013. We will let you know about the following things:


The day and the place where they will be so that if you wish to personally attend you will be very welcome!


How much we will collect during events to be donated for rebuilding damaged places.


The organizations that will receive our donation and how they will use those funds.


 
Ways you can help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:


Give whatever you can. Lots of small contributions will add up to make a big impact!


If you are on any social networks such as Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, etc please consider posting a link or sending an announcement about our fund-raising effort to your contacts.


 
– THANK YOU -

story:
Greenway Network is an all volunteer organization based in the St Louis Confluence region.  Our mission is to protect watersheds and conserve natural resources.  We do this primarily through clean water education, research, restoration and recreation projects.  We leverage our limited resources to involve as many volunteers, plant as many trees, remove as many invasive species, and to teach as many people as we can.  We believe in hands on environmental protection. 

Each year we coordinate Mission: Clean Stream where hundreds of volunteers fan out across the rivers and streams to get muddy and clean up.  The Stream Trash ART project gives metal from that clean up to sculptors who create works of art that are then on display throughout the region, providing an educational message about the need to keep our waters clean.  Our Sunlight Quilt Project, takes fabric made by kids who are learning about invasive species and gives it to quilters who create works of art which are used to raise funds to buy tools like honeysuckle poppers, making invasive removal even easier.  We will be out in force for National Public Lands Day in the Fall, planting hundreds of native trees in parks and refuges across the confluence region. On water quality monitoring days we take whole streams or large watershed snapshots of data.  Each year, we give hundreds of volunteers the chance to say they made a difference.  Right here.  Right now.

No one around here gets paid.  We work hard to minimize our costs so that we can put our resources where our shovels are, in the ground and out of the water.  We operate on a shoe string but we can’t operate on air. 

For the past five years, Greenway Network has hosted the Race for the Rivers.  It started as a pledge-based canoe and kayak race to raise awareness of our river resources and to raise money to plant more trees and dispose of more tires.  It has grown to include three paddle events, two bike rides, a music fest and a whole lot of educational activities.  We bring people to the river. 

This year, we have a unique opportunity to get hundreds of average people, families and kids, out on the river in voyageur class canoes.  They will spend a few minutes learning about paddling and about the river.  Then they will board the canoes and paddle on the river. 

We want to give people who might not imagine they could be in a canoe a chance to experience the river first hand.  Your financial support will enable us to bring in six voyageur class canoes and guides to give river rides.  Additional funds will be used to expand the festival to include more educational activities for kids, attract bigger music acts and make the festival greener.

We need to raise $7,000 from new sources to bring in the canoes.  The money is needed to pay for transportation and for the expert guides who will safely lead workshops and take folks out on the river.  The canoes are coming from Wilderness Inquiry.  They are a non-profit organization based in Minnesota with the experts and expertise to put 800 – 1000 people a day out on the water.  They will be here for 2 days.  Which means we will have the potential to get 2,000 people on the Big Muddy. 

We need a lot of money.  We have already raised $3,000 toward our goal.  We really don’t have far to go.  Our premiums are modest because we want to plant trees more than we want to use up resources making more stuff.  But we do want you to have a way to show off your support.  Anyone who contributes will receive recognition on our website. 

  • We have a killer logo and will send out a window cling for anyone donating at least $10. 
  • For $25 we will send you an EPA approved water bottle.  We believe in reusable water bottles and we do everything we can to get them into the hands of people to use instead of bottled water.   
  • At the $50 donation level, we will send you one of our t-shirts in addition to the water bottle and window cling.    
  • Anyone donating $100 gets all of the previous prizes plus a booth space at the festival and your name on the official Race for the Rivers T-shirt. 
  • There are two Greening the Festival Sponsorships.  They come with all of the previous premiums, plus a choice booth space.  More importantly one will provide for refillable water bottles and water to be given to festival attendees.  The other will enable us to enhance our recycling efforts. 
  • There are six opportunities to sponsor a support boat.  We field support boats with communication equipment on the river.   They are there for the safety of our paddlers.  This level of sponsorship will add a banner with your name or logo on “your” support boat and special recognition at the festival and on website. 
  • We also have one opportunity for you to have your very own music fest.  At least you can have your name and/or logo on the music fest.  You will be recognized at the festival including an introduction on stage.  Your contribution will enable us to beef up the sound system and enhance the music.  You will have a prime booth space next to the pavilion and a banner on the stage. 

Any funds raised beyond our $4000 goal will be put to good use.  We don’t pay any salaries so we can use that money to purchase tools, trees, native plants and safety equipment for our volunteers.  We have a lot of riparian areas waiting for the resources to make an improvement.  Your cash will be put to use directly for that purpose. 

The thing that makes this project have such an impact is that it brings new people to the river.  People who might never show up for a canoe race or music festival will turn out because they want to have a free ride in a big canoe.  Perhaps because of history, perhaps because it is free, perhaps because they don’t have anything else to do.  The canoes will bring them to the river.  We will then have the chance to connect them to it.  To build a relationship.   It is a new way to attract an audience and create an opportunity to  learn.  Who knows how many of the people who ride in the canoes will think twice about throwing trash or dumping in a drain.  How many will come out to plant trees the next time they hear about it.  How many will learn about re-usable water bottles.  How many will see the river when they drive over it.  The impact of this can be far reaching in immeasurable ways. 

We know that not everyone has the cash to spend on things like this.   There are other ways you can help.  In fact, a few minutes of time that you have could end up making all the difference in the world.  If you want to help…

  1.  Spread the word.  Share this link.  Tell everyone you know about it.  Ask them to do the same.
  2. Check out our websites http://racefortherivers.org  and http://greenwaynetwork.org.  Share those links.  Spread the word about the sponsors already listed. 
  3. Volunteer.  We can always use the help, at the festival on August 25 and in the field at any one of our planting, cleaning or monitoring events.
  4. Lend us your talent.  You can donate your handmade items, art, gift certificate to be used as prizes for pledge leaders in the canoe/kayak races and bike rides. 

Every little bit will make a difference. Thank you.

-- the entire Race for the Rivers Team

info@racefortherivers  

greenwaynetwork@gmail.com
story_txt:
