story:
Short Summary

Hey all! My name is Alexandra (Lex) and I am going to Tanzania this summer to work with a non-profit organization called HELP-International. The video above gives a good summary of the types of projects the organization works on, but my personal interest in interning/volunteering in Tanzania is because I have lived in Arusha, Tanzania before and I know firsthand the issues the people face when it comes to development and poverty eradication. It is my goal in life to be the cause of change in the international community. 

For my fundraising, I am asking for donations that will help me pay for the program fee for the three months I will spend in Tanzania, anything extra will assist me in paying for airfare. This campaign is important to me because I am hoping to gain experience in Tanzania that will help me when I start applying to graduate school next year. 

Contributors to this crowdfunding campaign will help me in my career goals. I am very passionate about making an impact on the world, and East Africa in particular. YOUR donation will make the difference in me being able to partake in this program. Your donation will be helping me take the steps I need to become influential in development issues. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

So, to break it down, I am looking to raise at least $4,000 because that is the rough estimate of my program fee. This portion of money will go directly to HELP-International. Anything additional I raise will help me pay for my airfare.

For those of you who are interested in me bringing something back for you in return for your donation, I have listed perks on this page as well. Tanzania has awesome craft markets and AMAZING coffee and tea. I will be happy to bring you guys something back if you would like! Just donate through the perk section (I think that's how it works). 

 

The Impact

This year I have seriously learned the importance of donations and generous contributions in the non-profit world. Fundraising is hard and making a difference requires a lot of outside support. That's where you guys come in. Your support in my endeavors will help me gain connections with well known non-profit organizations that work internationally. Being able to dig a well, spread awareness about HIV/AIDS. work on local business development, etc. is valuable to me because I think all people should be able to live a life like we do in America and everyone should have their basic needs met. 

Your contribution will help me with my life goals. The last time I lived in Arusha, Tanzania, the house I was in ran out of water at least once every few days. Imagine what it's like to wake up not knowing if you have water to shower, or even to wash your hands or to drink. This is a reality for people in Arusha and many other parts of the world. By making a donation, you will be helping me gain experience working on such water projects that hopefully one day no one will have to worry about their basic needs being met or available. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a donation at this time, please feel free to post a link to this webpage so that others may feel inclined to make a donation. Every little bit helps!

story:
One of the most vital things for life on our planet is water, and the problem with the pools of water on Earth is that they get more and more polluted with each day that passes. They get polluted because of us, so it is our responsibility to take action and find a solution to clean them back up for the next generations.

Srach the Robot- it will clean our waters for us!


Founders and the Operation Clean Water team.


Wouldn’t it be great if all of the Earths waters were clean? YES, as water is the most vital element for our existence! 

How would we be able to clean all our pools of water?

Of course it would be best if all of us would be responsible and clean up after ourselves, and even after others when possible, but this doesn’t always depend on us.

Sometimes we have the following scenario.


What is the solution that we propose?

We want to attack the problem in a smart way at its core. Since we are in a time when technology develops quickly and we are learning to use it in different spheres of our lives, the cleaning will be done by a robot. It will be pulling a net that will be picking all the rubbish and waste out of the water. It will be guided by a GPS system, and will be able to clean any territory independently.


Srach will be visible at night.


Technical Specifications:

From a technical point of view SRACH is a boat that uses solar power to do its job. Of course SRACH is built so it will function when there is no sunlight outside. It will be capable through the 12V and 10400 mAh battery.

To give the GPS module and command system energy, we are using a Solar Charge Controller, that sends electrical energy either from the solar panel when it is sunny outside, or from the battery when no sun light. For clarity of how Solar Charge Controller works view below:


The solar panel produces 20W and 12-18V. This power is enough to move the propelled engine, GPS module, navigation, and even charges the batteries of Srach.

Below you can see how all the equipment will be connected.

First prototype of the propeller.

First tests to verify if the solar panel would produce enough energy.

Charge time and work time:

If Srach is not working then the battery will be charged by the solar panel in an estimated time of 7 hours, and this charge will assure that the robot works 10 hours without sun light.

Srach will be able to be charged from a wall socket as well, for areas without much sunlight. If 12V and 3A will be used then it will charge Srach in 3.5 hours from a wall socket.

For us to start the process of manufacturing these robots and getting all the other equipment ready, we need $3,700. This includes costs for manufacturing, legal documents, logistics, and other small expenses that will appear during the work process.

All the robots will be tested personally and will be supervised by a qualified team, and only after positive results, it will be proposed that they be manufactured in a large mass, to be used all over the world.

Fulfillment and shipping of perks

We aim to deliver the perks in 3 months after the campaign is finished. The biggest challenge we will have is mass production of Srach. This is not our goal with this campaign, as we are aiming to improve the existing robot. 

3 months will give us enough time to get everyone's perks and sizes ready. We will send out emails asking everyone these questions after the campaign is finished.

 


PERKS:






Thank you everyone for your support and your contribution to our campaign!

story:
The Project

My name is Sharon and I'm preparing to begin a gibbon survey in partnership with the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) in the Seima Protected Forest, Cambodia. This forest is home to over 556 species of fauna including 4 critically endangered water bird species, Asian elephants, tigers (though they are feared extinct from this area since 2007) and the world's largest surviving populations of black-shanked duocs and yellow-cheeked gibbons. It is an area of incalculable natural value. In  2000, WCS took over protection of the forest and discovered a new population of a primate that had been feared close to extinction: the southern yellow-cheeked gibbon. Presumed the world's largest remaining population of this endangered species, these gibbons are now in need of protection from the illegal logging and poaching that have begun within the forest. Therefore, a survey is required in order to gain as much information as we can about this population. The results of the survey will provide crucial support for the protection of this entire ecosystem as well as for the further development of an eco-tourism operation run by the local village of Andong Kralong. Through scientific study and community-led conservation, we hope that this priceless biodiversity hotspot can remain a protected haven.  

One of the last photos captured of tiger presence in the Seima Forest

A mated pair of southern yellow-cheeked gibbons


What We Need 

The Wildlife Conservation Society has graciously offered funding for 30% of this project, which is fantastic! However, that leaves quite a bit still in need of funds. These are primarily:

  1. Transportation to and from the field site 
  2. Crucial equipment for the survey (compasses, GPS units, recording equipment etc.)
  3. Salaries for Cambodian field assistants
  4. Camping gear for field data collection
  5. Food/supplies to be provided to members of the village of Andong Kralong who participate in the survey.
 Any excess funds raised will be used to donate much needed supplies and equipment to WCS Cambodian operations. 

The village of Andong Kralong

A planning meeting


The Impact

This is such an exciting project because it will have an incredibly far-reaching impact. In order to complete this survey as efficiently as possible, WCS has decided to test a new analytical process that will be less invasive and more accurate; providing census data using only the gibbons' songs (which can be heard in the video above!). Should the technique prove successful in this project, it will be able to be applied at field sites all over the world for a wide range of species!

Also, this survey is being performed with the help of the local village of Andong Kralong in order to support an eco-tourism project run out of the village. This type of community-led conservation is essential to long term conservation success as it not only gives residents ownership of this solution but also provides much needed local income. With this added income, the need for poaching and illegal logging drops drastically.  

This project is a win-win-win for all involved and would greatly benefit from your support! 

Measuring the DBH of trees in Seima Forest


THANK YOU!

story:
Toxic e-waste doesn't have borders.

It's time for Techno-Trash Transparency!

Help BAN go to Asia and document illegally exported e-waste from North America.

International law (the United Nations Basel Convention) prohibits the transnational movement of toxic waste. Despite this, governments are often unable, and sometimes unwilling, to stop e-waste smuggling. In a global landscape of poverty, ignorance and criminal greed, secrecy poisons the environment, workers and agricultural land. 

Pollution is everyone's problem.

15 years ago, Basel Action Network (BAN) broke the worldwide e-waste abuse scandal using basic citizen journalism on the ground – going there in person, witnessing, and documenting.


In our experience, sunlight is the best disinfectant.

In a ground-breaking and unique investigative program, BAN has been working to devise an unprecedented GPS (global position systems) pilot project to track North American electronics - our old gadgets. We’ve deployed the geo-trackers; they've crossed the oceans and arrived at their final resting places. Now we need to go there ASAP to photograph their dark surroundings. This is the final component of documentation. Time is of the essence. 

Documentation will be used to support enforcement, legislation and transparency – all essential for toxic-free communities.

Help BAN get there. Bring the sunshine. Donate today.


Problem ... and Solution Details!

We're using the latest technology by mapping and capturing the ever-changing international e-waste trade routes. Beginning at so-called responsible recycling sites in the US, we’re GPS tracking donated and disposed electronics as they are loaded into containers and shipped around the world. 

Our team is uncovering what really happens to electronic waste when                     well-intentioned citizens drop off their old phones or computers at the local electronic recycling company or donation site. While most people think they’ve done their part for the environment, avenues that start with good intentions often end up in polluted wastelands.

Now that we’ve identified their final destinations, BAN’s investigative lead, Jim Puckett, will visit these locales to chronicle the devastating impact e-waste has on vulnerable populations. Often, documenting this is difficult, as authorities hide their illegal activities and threaten families into silence. Through film, photography, and narratives, we will craft unique stories that can only be told through Jim Puckett’s keen eye.

We’ll take you with us on this journey…


How YOU can be part of this movement

You’re invited to join a circle of citizens who care about the global environment!

We need $10,000 to reach our goal. Where is this funding going? We need funding to investigate and document the final resting place of the toxic e-waste we’ve tracked to China.

100% of donations will directly cover travel and associated program expenses covering this impactful investigation (including a plane ticket, interpreter expenses, lodging, etc.). Every amount is deeply appreciated and will greatly help us to track the trash!

  • By donating today, you are supporting the completion of last phase of an international investigation, which when published, will result in long-term environmental and behavioral change. 
  • You will become part of BAN’s circle and receive updating e-mails with information and tools to inspire you.
  • You will help build a global community of mobilized and engaged advocates building the online heart of the network to catalyze more direct action.

THANK YOU for your donation to this important cause.

The Impact

Our stories offer both horror and hope: the disturbing impact and our vision for a brighter future. By shining a light on e-waste’s final destination, we demonstrate that "away" is a place: e-waste doesn't disappear. In fact, e-waste pollutes the most vulnerable populations and environments, robbing families of the right to a healthy environment and toxic-free workplace. 

Fortunately, it doesn’t have to be this way.

This project will call out ‘bad actors’ who are exporting e-waste illegally. It will create a healthy future for everyone. By generating awareness of how we export e-waste to developing countries, we will also ultimately create greater awareness of and demand for the alternative – namely responsible recyclers. Citizens will elect to use responsible recyclers for their own needs, and consumers will demand greater corporate social responsibility from their favorite brands. 

Risks & Challenges

BAN’s plan is solutions-oriented – promoting everyone’s right to a flourishing environment.

At the nexus of human rights and environmental justice, BAN believes that sustainability entails transforming society’s discarded goods into valuable resources. 

Over the years, we have faced strong opposition from superpowers with vested interest in the status quo. They used every trick in the book to try to undermine and weaken the Basel Convention. And yet, with our sparse resources, we have managed to thwart them at every turn and protect this U.N. treaty. Much of our success is due to having earned the trust of developing countries and Jim Puckett’s tireless efforts to promote integrity. 

As a GLOBAL watchdog – we uncover and alert authorities                and the public of wrongdoings.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but you can still help. 

Please spread the word by sharing this campaign with friends, family, and organizations who share our values.  

Let's make some noise – and shine a light on this issue!!!

  • Share this campaign on social media
  • Sign up for our newsletter to get updates
  • Follow us on Facebook 
  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Use a responsible recycler for your electronic waste. Click here to find one near you

Start a conversation with family, friends and everyone who can lend their support!

THANK YOU for your donation to this important cause.

www.BAN.org
story_txt:
Toxic e-waste doesn't have
borders.
It's time for Techno-Trash Transparency!Help BAN go to Asia and document illegally exported e-waste from
North America.
International law (the United Nations Basel Convention) prohibits the transnational movement of toxic waste. Despite this, governments are often unable, and sometimes unwilling, to stop e-waste smuggling. In a global landscape of poverty, ignorance and criminal greed, secrecy poisons the environment, workers and agricultural land. Pollution is everyone's problem.15 years ago, Basel Action Network (BAN) broke the worldwide e-waste abuse scandal using basic citizen journalism on the ground – going there in person, witnessing, and documenting.In our experience, sunlight is the best disinfectant.In a ground-breaking and unique investigative program, BAN has been working to devise an unprecedented GPS (global position systems) pilot project to track North American electronics - our old gadgets. We’ve deployed the geo-trackers; they've crossed the oceans and arrived at their final resting places. Now we need to go there ASAP to photograph their dark surroundings. This is the final component of documentation. Time is of the essence. Documentation will be used to support enforcement, legislation and transparency – all essential for toxic-free communities.Help BAN get there. Bring the sunshine. Donate today.

story:
AME is in danger (EN)

Peasant families have invaded the jungle, cutting down many forests to sell excellent-quality wood, which is exported to other countries.

In this moment, AME has more than 265 million cubic feet of wood.

The affected areas are being used by the invaders for agriculture and cattle stock and they pour waste into the rivers depleting the river beds.

Today

AME is seeking urgently for funds to relocate the peasant families by buying them land that is suitable for agricultura and livestock breeding, out of the rainforest, where they can comfortably live. The funds will also be used to reforest the Rio Negro riverbed and deforested áreas.  In addition, we will put surveillance and control points in place in order to avoid tree cutting. For this Project, we need $1.425 million dollars.

With your help, this will be the first rainforest that we will to recover in the world.  With your help, we will recover the sources of wáter and of life around it. 

Impact

"Amigos de los arboles" will sponsor investigation and strengthen the presence of scientists and students who will take care of and preserve the species that still inhabit this area, some which are endangered.



La naturaleza te necesita (ES)

Familias campesinas han invadido la selva, talando gran cantidad de bosque para vender la excelente madera, que es exportada a otros países.

En este momento AME, cuenta con más de siete y medio millones de metros cúbicos de madera.

Las zonas deforestadas están siendo aprovechadas por los invasores para agricultura y ganadería, arrojando desechos  a los ríos y deforestando sus causes. 


Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

AME busca urgentemente, recursos para reubicar a las familias campesinas, comprándoles tierras aptas para la agricultura y la ganadería afuera de la selva, donde puedan vivir cómodamente, los recursos también serán usados para reforestar el cause del Río Negro y de las zonas deforestadas, también vamos a instalar puntos de vigilancia y control para evitar la  tala de arboles.

Para esto necesitamos $1.425.000 dólares.


Con tu ayuda, esta es la primera selva que recuperaremos en el mundo.

Con tu ayuda vamos a recuperar las fuentes de agua y la vida alrededor de estas.


El impacto

Patrocinaremos la investigación y fortaleceremos la presencia de los  científicos y estudiantes que cuidan y preservan las especies que allí viven, algunas de estas en peligro de extinción.

Generaremos certificados de donación que ayudarán a que personas y empresas puedan reducir sus impuestos al contribuir con una causa social.

No olvides compartir nuestra campaña para que todos podamos disfrutar de un futuro mejor.

story:
The 16 Frogs project combines public art with an environmental consciousness, based on the particulars of local history -- to appeal to people from all corners.

16 life-size bronze statuettes will form a trail through the Stroubles Creek watershed, forming a public arts installation that calls attention to the freshwater under and around the streets of Blacksburg. The project also references the town's original sixteen-block street grid, as mapped by founder William Black and incorporated in 1798.

Modeled after the native Green Frog (Lithobates clamitans), some of the bronzes will rest on casts of Virgnia's native water lily (Nymphaea odorata). They will range from 6" - 12" in size, and sit on pavement, knee walls, stormwater drains, or sills. The frogs will be enjoyed by toddlers on discovery; by school children investigating stream ecology; by runners, walkers, or geocachers; by history buffs, tourists, and arts patrons.

You can listen to the Green Frog on Virginia Water Radio and hear some great banjo music inspired by our amphibious neighbors!

Blacksburg was founded by 16th century European adventurers who defied the British crown by crossing the Continental Divide; then settled on the site of the first sweet springs they encountered. Today, it’s hard to locate or identify those creeks and seeps, since most have been concealed by piping and built over.

The most prominent waterway beneath our streets, Stroubles Creek was added to the state’s impaired waterways list in 1998, where it has remained ever since. Significantly compromised, it's one of the most polluted streams in the state. It will take the combined efforts of state and local governments, the university, and an educated public to restore this vital waterway.

16 Frogs and a small amount of cash can help restore Stroubles Creek through public education, inspired by art and informed by history. Our sponsors include: Seek Education, Explore, and DiScover (SEEDS, Inc); Downtown Blacksburg, Inc.; The Alexander Black House & Cultural Center; The Lyric Theater Council; Up on the Roof; the Community Foundation of the New River Valley; and the Town of Blacksburg.

Take the leap with us!

Perks

$25 USD - Egg mass
Hand-milled froggy soap by Sent with Suds, of Fincastle, Virginia.

$50 USD - Tadpole
Buy Local t-shirt - OR - Vintage Steppin' Out t-shirt.

$100 USD - Froglet
One George Wills print, specially designed for the 16 Frogs project.

$500 USD - Frog
Set of three George Wills prints, specially designed to support freshwater awareness through the 16 Frogs project.

$1000 USD - Prince
Donor recognition on a permanent brass plaque, to be placed at the Alexander Black House & Cultural Center.  

The seven highest givers, beyond $1,000, will be honored.

story:
They roam on a farm near the majestic Limpopo River, unaware of the danger they will encounter.  A man made danger, encroaching on species both endangered and protected.  One day, unsuspecting, they will wind up as a trophy, mounted on a wall or made into a skin rug.  Trophy hunting.  Very much frowned upon by UN Rio Accord 1992 countries, the practice is very much alive and thriving in areas of the world where money and corruption speak louder than animal rights. 

What is Trophy hunting?

Trophy Hunting is the selective hunting of wild game animals. Although parts of the slain animal may be kept as a hunting trophy or memorial (usually the skin, antlers and/or head), the carcass itself is sometimes used as food.

Trophy hunting has firm supporters and opponents. Public debate about trophy hunting often concentrate on the question of the morality of sport hunting and the question of the extent to which the money paid by trophy hunters benefits the population of game animals and the local economy.

What is Big Game hunting? 

A big-game hunter is a person engaged in the sport of trophy hunting for large animals or game. The pursuit of the major objective might place the hunter at risk of personal harm. Potential big game sought include, but are not limited to: bears, big cats, hippos, elephants, rhinos, buffalos, moose and so forth.

Why we think Trophy Hunting does not help economy or is good for the wildlife management and regulation?

Trophy Hunting only profits to a few number of white African people, local communities are not involved. Game reserve allowing Trophy Hunting employ at least 10 time less people than photographic game reserve. Sometime brought on the table no Trophy Hunting does not help the wildlife management and regulation. This is the biggest lie. Wildlife intended to be shot is most of the time bought from a captive breeder dealer and moved on the game reserve few days before the hunter is expected. Where is the wildlife regulation or management here? We are not the one saying there shouldn't be any wildlife regulation at all, of course, but Trophy Hunting is just killing animals for killing animals!


What can we do? What do we propose?

Trophy Hunting will not disappear only with a click! Lobbying is the right solution with the governments who are still allowing hunting concessions. But what about private lands? In Botswana for example the government understood Trophy Hunting is not a solution and hunting concession have been halted. But the government cannot remove the game farm rights (hunting) to a private land. Only the owner can give his license back.

We need your help in order to buy a hunting farm in Botswana and its land (around five thousand hectares). It is one of the last remaining hunting farms in the area. The goal is to stop all hunting in this area, remove the fences to free wildlife and re-integrate animals. The game farm will then be turned into a game lodge working very closely with the locals in order to create more sustainable jobs and make sure the return gets back to locals.

Where is this hunting farm?

Next to a magnificent river, the Limpopo, in the south east part of the country. The farm is currently on sale and the goal is to make sure no Trophy Hunter buys it and continue killing animals for fun.

FAQ:


What difference it will make (Trophy Hunting will not be stopped)?

Yes we can't stop Trophy Hunting in the entire Africa. Yes our project will only eradicate Trophy Hunting in one farm and one area. But all successes start with a new idea, others may follow and one day... who knows!

What will you do with the money if your goal is not reached?

It is not our intention to keep the money. Either we reach our goal and can buy the farm or we will organize a vote with the donors. We will ask them to choose between our preferred 3 foundations, organizations fighting Hunting Tropy where the money will be sent.

Who we are?


A small group of African freaks and safaris lovers. We have helped more than a thousand people organizing their safari in Africa. It is time to do something different and more useful. Video will follow!

story:
An insulated shipping container houses massive fish tanks filled with organic tilapia  year-round. From this container, nutrient-rich water from the fish disperses out to a large greenhouse where state-of-the-art vertical growing techniques optimize production in a compact space. 

 

**Self-regulation: when something is out of balance in the system, smart devices correct the imbalance automatically. Additionally, fish feeders release food on a schedule that increases serving size as the fish grow!



BUT before we can build this incredible facility, we needed to start somewhere...smaller. We needed a system as proof of concept and for valuable insight to guide our construction of the micro-farm.



We started by retrofitting large water tanks into containers for fish and plants. After assembling a wooden support structure, installing powerful LED lights and incorporating various plumbing/electrical components, our prototype system was ready to accommodate over 200 pounds of organic Tilapia and over 30 species of organic fruits, vegetables, and herbs.


Wouldn't it be nice if your garden could take care of itself? Our prototype's "Brain" regulates LED lights, monitors digital sensors, and moves water within the aquaponics system. The sensors are programmed to collect water quality information and stream it to any device with a browser. If there is an imbalance in the system, a notification is automatically sent to our mobile devices. 






Generating data that aims to maximize farming efficiency will not only help improve our system, but also help our non-profit organization secure local and federal grants. These grants will finance improvements to the system, additional facilities, publications for the scientific community, and much more.


The path to a healthier future requires that we empower people with a deep understanding of what goes into our food. That's why we've designed kindergarten through college lesson plans to teach students about aquaponic systems, anatomy, chemistry, physics, green engineering, computer programming and other important subjects. Shout out to Mrs. Wilson's 5th grade class at Denton's Wilson Elementary!

By growing plants with a rich diversity of colors, smells, textures and flavors, our sensory garden is a place for therapy AND fun! Sensory exposure of this kind is incredibly effective for helping children with Autism and other developmental disabilities to adjust to a world full of diverse sensory experiences. 








$26,000 = SUPER-INSULATION & VENTILATION

By installing rigid polyurethane panels around the perimeter of the greenhouse (ground level to 8 feet high), we will conserve energy and money that would otherwise be lost to temperature control. 

In addition to insulating panels, we will combine reflective paint, solar-powered turbines, automated shuttered vents and fans, compost heaters, shade cloth and other materials to minimize greenhouse climate fluctuations for more energy savings.

$35,000 = KID-FRIENDLY SCIENCE LABORATORY!!

In the spirit of education, we have designed a science laboratory that fits inside the shipping container alongside the fish tank! 

The laboratory will feature:

  • A window into the fish tank for the kids to spy thousands of live Tilapia. Submersible fiberoptic cameras mounted to remote-controlled submarines let them direct the exploration of entire aquatic ecosystems
  • Terrarium cubes that inspire kinesthetic interaction with composting earthworms, pest-eliminating praying mantis, root-enhancing fungus, and other symbiotic critters
  • A microscope station for kids to investigate the rich & diverse nature of the microscopic world. They can even record it and bring it back to the projector station for an 80" touch screen video interaction
  • Developer circuit boards for kids and adults to hard-wire their way to a solar-powered light show, or a number of other simple, stimulating rewards
  • A computer station for advanced courses in programming automation and calibrating digital sensors

And much, much more...

$55,000 = SOLAR PANELS (ZERO ENERGY POTENTIAL)

We have estimated that just by covering the roof of the shipping container with solar panels, we will produce enough electricity to offset the total energy required by the facility! 

Not just your ordinary solar panels either...we need high-grade photo-voltaic panels that track the movement of the sun and store extra energy in a reserve battery. These features will ensure that the system never shuts down in the event of a power outage and grants the freedom of going "off the grid."




JOIN US NOW in this opportunity to take our health back and to set the stage for future generations to thrive! Even if you are not in a position to donate, we ask that you simply share our campaign link on your social media, e-mail, or by word of mouth. By taking few seconds to share, you can make a world of difference!


  THANKS AGAIN FOR TAKING THE TIME TO READ ABOUT OUR PROJECT!!
                                

 


                                              WANT TO KNOW MORE?



ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS AND LEGAL DISCLAIMER

Greenfinity Farms realizes that $20,000 seems very low considering the number of features in our system. Because we’re asking for your help, we simply want to be humble with the goal amount. According to our calculations, $20,000 is just enough to build a fully functional aquaponics facility that uses a shipping container and a large greenhouse. The vertical farming structures and stretch goals are very important to us, but they are not necessary to construct a functional system.   

Legal Disclaimer

Delivery of rewards/perks listed on this page is subject to the best efforts of the team and similar to other crowdfunding campaigns not guaranteed. This disclaimer has been added to set reasonable expectations for our contributors/funders.

Please note that any crowdfunding contributions are considered final; we do not offer refunds or product returns.

© 2014 Greenfinity Farms, a Non-Profit Organization. All rights reserved. The information published herein is provided "as is" and is subject to change without prior notice. 

Contacting Greenfinity Farms

For all inquiries, please contact us at please contact customer service at media@greenfinityfarms.com If you have already made a pledge (or are considering to contribute), please include the word “Customer” in the subject line. If you have a question that is not answered in the FAQ or in the campaign, please include the word “Question” in your email subject. For Press, please include the word “press” and all other inquiries, please include the word “Other”.

LINK TO OUR FAQ 

http://greenfinityfarms.com/contact.html
story_txt:
An insulated shipping container houses massive fish tanks filled with organic tilapia  year-round. From this container, nutrient-rich water from the fish disperses out to a large greenhouse where state-of-the-art vertical growing techniques optimize production in a compact space.  **Self-regulation: when something is out of balance in the system, smart devices correct the imbalance automatically. Additionally, fish feeders release food on a schedule that increases serving size as the fish grow!


BUT before we can build this incredible facility, we needed to start somewhere...smaller. We needed a system as proof of concept and for valuable insight to guide our construction of the micro-farm.






We started by retrofitting large water tanks into containers for fish and plants. After assembling a wooden support structure, installing powerful LED lights and
incorporating various plumbing/electrical components, our prototype system was ready to accommodate over 200 pounds of organic Tilapia and
over 30 species of organic fruits, vegetables, and herbs.








Wouldn't it be nice if your garden could
take care of itself? Our prototype's "Brain" regulates LED lights,
monitors digital sensors, and moves water within the aquaponics system. The
sensors are programmed to collect water quality information and stream it to
any device with a browser. If there is an imbalance in the system, a notification is automatically sent to our mobile devices. 












Generating data that aims to maximize farming efficiency will not only help improve our system, but also help our non-profit organization secure local and federal grants. These grants will finance improvements to the system, additional facilities, publications for the scientific community, and much more.






The path to a healthier future requires that we empower people with a deep understanding of what goes into our food. That's why we've designed kindergarten through college lesson plans to teach students about aquaponic systems, anatomy, chemistry, physics, green engineering, computer programming and other important subjects. Shout out to Mrs. Wilson's 5th grade class at Denton's Wilson Elementary! 






By growing plants with a rich diversity of colors, smells, textures and flavors, our sensory garden is a place for therapy AND fun! Sensory exposure of this kind is incredibly effective for helping children with Autism and other developmental disabilities to adjust to a world full of diverse sensory experiences. 



























$26,000 = SUPER-INSULATION & VENTILATION

By installing rigid polyurethane panels around the perimeter of the greenhouse (ground level to 8 feet high), we will conserve energy and money that would otherwise be lost to temperature control. 
In addition to insulating panels, we will combine reflective paint, solar-powered turbines, automated shuttered vents and fans, compost heaters, shade cloth and other materials to minimize greenhouse climate fluctuations for more energy savings.



$35,000 = KID-FRIENDLY SCIENCE LABORATORY!!


In the spirit of education, we have designed a science laboratory that fits inside the shipping container alongside the fish tank! 
The laboratory will feature:

A window into the fish tank for the kids to spy thousands of live Tilapia. Submersible fiberoptic cameras mounted to remote-controlled submarines let them direct the exploration of entire aquatic ecosystems
Terrarium cubes that inspire kinesthetic interaction with composting earthworms, pest-eliminating praying mantis, root-enhancing fungus, and other symbiotic critters
A microscope station for kids to investigate the rich & diverse nature of the microscopic world. They can even record it and bring it back to the projector station for an 80" touch screen video interaction
Developer circuit boards for kids and adults to hard-wire their way to a solar-powered light show, or a number of other simple, stimulating rewards
A computer station for advanced courses in programming automation and calibrating digital sensors

And much, much more...






$55,000 = SOLAR PANELS (ZERO ENERGY POTENTIAL)

We have estimated that just by covering the roof of the shipping container with solar panels, we will produce enough electricity to offset the total energy required by the facility! 
Not just your ordinary solar panels either...we need high-grade photo-voltaic panels that track the movement of the sun and store extra energy in a reserve battery. These features will ensure that the system never shuts down in the event of a power outage and grants the freedom of going "off the grid."




JOIN US NOW in this opportunity to take our health back and to set the stage for future generations to thrive! Even if you are not in a position to donate, we ask that you simply share our campaign link on your social media, e-mail, or by word of mouth. By taking few seconds to share, you can make a world of difference!

  THANKS AGAIN FOR TAKING THE TIME TO READ ABOUT OUR PROJECT!!                                
 

                                              WANT TO KNOW MORE?

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS AND LEGAL DISCLAIMER


Greenfinity
Farms realizes that $20,000 seems very low considering the number of features
in our system. Because we’re asking for your help, we simply want to be humble
with the goal amount. According to our calculations, $20,000 is just enough to
build a fully functional aquaponics facility that uses a shipping container and

system.

story:
Year of Jewish Policy Engagement on the Environment

COEJL and Jewcology are teaming up to raise funds for a Year of Engagement in 2014.

You can support COEJL or Jewcology in this campaign by selecting their designated perks in the column to the right.  
If you would like to select your own donation amount, click Contribute Now and enter that amount, then select an available COEJL or Jewcology perk so that your donation is designated to COEJL or Jewcology.

Through the Year of Engagement, you’ll have the opportunity to:

  • Get to know your elected representatives

  • Engage your community to advocate for meaningful environmental change

  • Learn about key opportunities to make a difference

  • Act at the critical moment

Why are COEJL and Jewcology partnering in the Year of Engagement?

COEJL brings advocacy experience, skills and connections empowering Jewish individuals and organizations to take meaningful political action on energy and the environment. Jewcology brings experience with community organizing and a broad base of Jewish environmental activists across the Jewish and political spectrum.

Together, we will organize Jewish campaigns throughout the year to help you learn about opportunities to make a difference on key environmental issues at the national and state level, to get to know your elected representatives, and to engage your community.

More about the Year of Policy Engagement:

  • The campaigns will be tied to meaningful Jewish times of the year.

  • This program focuses on a U.S. audience, but will have tools that may have relevance to Jewcology’s international community.

  • The Year of Engagement will also connect advocacy for sustainable energy policies with the “shmittah,” a time every seven years in the Jewish calendar to focus on letting the land rest.

At the end of this Year of Engagement, participating individuals, communities and organizations will have:

  • A stronger understanding of the legislative and regulatory processes

  • Relationships with their elected officials and community leaders

  • Engaged in environmental action campaigns with a meaningful impact

  • Learned to use tools and learning materials to help their communities understand the Jewish values that teach us to protect the environment.

How can Jewish environmental advocacy make a difference?

Jews have a long history of championing support for Israel and social justice causes, including successful mobilizations on civil rights, Russian Jewry, Darfur, and other issues. For the last twenty years, the Jewish community has been learning and changing our behaviors to protect our environment. To address one of today’s most important global challenges, it is now time for the Jewish community to unite in support of sustainable policies that reflect our Jewish interests and values, to make a meaningful impact at the state and national levels and beyond.

Goal:

Our goal is to raise a total of $15,000 in this campaign.  We are honored to have a matching grant from ROI for up to $5000.  During the high holiday period (August 19-October 3), our goal is to raise:

  • $5000 from the COEJL community,

  • $5000 from the Jewcology community, and

  • $5000 match from the ROI community.

Join the campaign and contribute now at indiegogo.com/year-of-engagement

COEJL is sponsored by the Jewish Council for Public Affairs (JCPA).

story:
Forever Chasing

We are a group based in Wichita, Kansas.  We roam Tornado Alley (TX, OK, KS, MO, CO, NE, IA) in search of impressive storms with the goal of warning those in the path of deadly storm activity. 


Why You Can Help

As hobby storm chasers, everything we do comes out of pocket.  Gas gets expensive, and although we have a partnership with Wichita Roofing and Remodeling, we still need your help in order to purchase and upgrade the current technology we use.  

In order to get the word out to the National Weather Service and our media partners, we desperately need to upgrade our communication equipment so we can ensure better coverage in all areas we travel to.  Currently, we struggle with keeping the reports flowing due to overuse of cellular equipment. 


The Impact Your Donations Will Have

Your donations will enable us to obtain updated mobile communications equipment that will let us keep the National Weather Service as well as our supporters and the public informed about these dangerous events. This information contributes to more timely and accurate warnings and will keep those in the path of deadly storms aware of what they can expect.

Ground truth is crucially important in getting out vital and life-saving information. Forever Chasing gives this information directly to those groups that need it.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit us on our Facebook page:  www.facebook.com/foreverchasing  

We give out updates and warn our fans in the path of dangerous weather.

story:
Hi, my name is André Angelantoni

I’d like to tell you about this incredible project in Mongolia that’s close to my heart; a project for which I’ve been training hard to complete. The issues surrounding this project need your awareness and support, so please learn more and consider making a tax deductible donation today.

What is "A Bike for Batdorj?"


Mongolia has an ambitious goal to preserve its beautiful land, the people and the animals that live there.

We have an opportunity through this project to help protect one of the most pristine wilderness left on the planet: outer Mongolia.

With your support, I'm raising money to donate a dirt bike to a park ranger in Mongolia so that he can protect his 94,000 acres of wilderness (holy moly, that's huge). He'll stop poaching of snow leopard and Argali sheep. He'll locate and stop illegal fishing and mining. He'll make sure construction is permitted (there is illegal development and mining right now). He'll watch over ibex, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable, too.

Only native people are allowed in the Horidol Saridag Strictly Protected Area that Batdorj protects. If he finds someone who doesn't live there, they are likely up to no good!


Meet Batdorj Byambasuren, the ranger who is getting the dirt bike.

Here is a bit of how Batdorj came to be a park ranger, in his own words:

I was born into a nomadic family and I was a herder. One time, I found an Argali sheep hidden amongst my herd of sheep. It was a very cold winter. I cared for the Argali until spring and let it go into the wild. Ever since, I was inspired to become a ranger and work to protect wildlife. I’ve been working as a ranger for 12 years now and I patrol 38,000 hectares (94 thousand acres) of Horidol Saridag Strictly Protected Area.

Help Me Get a Bike to Batdorj!

Buying the dirt bike and getting it to Batdorj costs $6500.

I've already bought the plane ticket to get me there ($2500; that comes out of my pocket, not what you donate).

Even if I don't reach my fundraising goal all of your donation will go to getting the bike to Mongolia. You can rest assured that the bike will get to Batdorj — no matter what.

How Does the Project Work?

Here are more details of the project:

  • The Mongol Ecology Center is the registered non-profit behind this project
  • Check out their website and see pictures of last year's successful project!


  • last year 15 rangers got bikes; 20 will get bikes this year!
  • the bikes are shipped from Yamaha Japan to the capital of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar
  • We’ll ride the bikes clear across Mongolia to the parks in the North West of Mongolia, directly south of Siberia
  • We'll cross rivers, climb hills and every night we'll sleep in tents
  • I'll personally give the dirt bike's key to Batdorj this July!
  • But only after training like crazy with Nate over at Kokoda Fitness to be able to ride on dirt for 1500 miles (check out Nate's perk!)

Here is the route:

Why Am I Doing This?

I'm passionate about the environment, I love camping, and I’m committed to helping protect the environment by participating in projects around the world. I have been a member of organizations like the Sierra Club and the National Parks Conservation Association for years. I’m also an experienced speaker and educator on the topics of climate change and oil depletion.

Another passion I have is motorcycles. Recently, something clicked for me: I could join my passion for the environment with a dirt-capable motorcycle! Recently, I bought a dual-sport motorcycle (an F800GS for those who know bikes) and embarked on this journey of a lifetime.

Let's Talk Perks!

Some friends have donated some awesome perks to the project! Everyone who contributes will stay up-to-date with the project as I send out updates.

Remember that your donation is completely tax-deductible in the U.S., so you'll get a great perk for not a lot of bucks. And if your company offers charitable contribution matching, you can double your donation. Cool!

Watch for an email from FirstGiving...that will be your tax receipt so that you can write off any size donation. Check your spam folder then contact me if you don’t see the email.

I really appreciate your time and consideration. If you choose to donate in any amount — THANK YOU!

— André

(You and your friends spending an afternoon or early evening on the Blue Note, below, is just one of the perks available.)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute with dollars, please consider telling people who love the environment about the project and help get a bike for Batdorj!

story:
Short Summary

Alaska Natives living off the land in Bristol Bay depend on the region's wild salmon runs for survival. Our documentary opens a window to Alaska Native communities facing the Pebble Partnership's plans to develop North America's biggest open pit mine at the headwaters of the world's largest salmon spawning streams. The film will premiere at the Finger Lakes Environmental Film Festival in April, 2013.

Traveling off the road system in small boats, the film explores how Alaska Native communities have lived symbiotically with the land, depending on the salmon for over 1,000 years. Our feature length documentary examines the current and potential future impacts of the Pebble Mine as President Obama and the Environmental Protection Agency prepare to decide on whether or not to permit the mine. They may decide as soon as November 2013.


What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money to share our environmental documentary with tribal schools and communities facing the impacts of mining. We Can't Eat Gold is beginning a rigorous season of film festivals to spread Alaska Native voices around the world.

After spending thousands of dollars of our own money to fund the film’s production, we are asking for support to rapidly distribute the film so that Alaska Native voices can be heard around the world before others decide the fate of the land they have called home for over 350 generations.  

All funds raised on Indiegogo are routed directly to the designated Josh and Gigi Productions bank account, which is managed according to nonprofit accounting standards.


Comment on our theatrical poster.

The Impact

The EPA could decide on blocking the proposed Pebble Mine in 2013. For President Obama, whether to permit excavating the largest open pit mine in North America among the headwaters of the world's richest salmon spawning streams will be one of the major environmental questions of 2013.

We Can't Eat Gold opens a space for Alaska Native elders and youth to share their subsistence ways of life and perspectives on the proposed Pebble Mine in advance of the president's decision. 


As we continue to screen We Can't Eat Gold around the country, it is important that we raise the funds necessary to support this project to empower indigenous voices. Our documentary is an independent production. We need your help to send hundreds of DVDs to share these stories of Bristol Bay's 'salmon way of life.' 


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donations, there are many ways you can help Alaska Native voices be heard! 

  • Research Pebble Mine on your own and be in touch with people involved with the issues.

  • Contact us at WeCantEatGold@gmail.com and volunteer to host or help organize a screening.
  • SHARE THE TRAILER on facebook and other social media sites to raise awareness and help more people get involved in supporting the film.
  • SHARE THE INDIEGOGO. Crowdsourcing requires enthusiastic networking. Even if you can't give money, please share this page and our website.


About The Filmmakers

Joshua Tucker is an Alaskan journalist and filmmaker, recently graduated from the University of Alaska Anchorage with a degree in Journalism. He has covered Alaska Native and environmental issues for Alaska Public Radio Network, The Anchorage Press and National Native News.

View his portfolio here.

Giovanna Marcantonio is a recent graduate from Ithaca College, with a degree in Environmental Studies concentrating on Law and Policy. In addition to her work as Executive Producer in We Can't Eat Gold, Giovanna works as an environmental educator and photographer. Seeking to illuminate indigenous voices in environmental justice issues, We Can't Eat Gold is Giovanna's debut in environmental filmmaking.

View her portfolio here.

SHARE THE INDIEGOGO. Crowdsourcing requires enthusiastic networking. Even if you can't give money, please share this page and our website.


About The Filmmakers
Joshua Tucker is an Alaskan journalist and filmmaker, recently graduated from the University of Alaska Anchorage with a degree in Journalism. He has covered Alaska Native and environmental issues for Alaska Public Radio Network, The Anchorage Press and National Native News.
View his portfolio here.
Giovanna Marcantonio is a recent graduate from Ithaca College, with a degree in Environmental Studies concentrating on Law and Policy. In addition to her work as Executive Producer in We Can't Eat Gold, Giovanna works as an environmental educator and photographer. Seeking to illuminate indigenous voices in environmental justice issues, We Can't Eat Gold is Giovanna's debut in environmental filmmaking.
View her portfolio here.

story:
Strawberry Moon Festival

Cliquez ici pour une version et vidéo francophone!

Kwe, Kway, Hello, Bonjour, Ainngai, Tansi!

50$ Early Bird tickets for sale in Perks section!  Get them while they are hot! 

June 21 - Solstice 2015 - Website

Can you remember going out to harvest strawberries in the late spring, early summer, plucking the ripe red berries from the plant, and biting into a juicy perfect piece of paradise?  Do you remember coming home, fingers stained and belly full, to make pies and jams or freeze some for winter to have them for later?  I can.

For many people including the First Nation people, the strawberry harvest signifies the coming of summer a cause for celebration, and the time to harvest this important fruit and medicine.    For the Mohawk people, it represents the first fruit of year, a fruit they ask the creator for during their Mid-winter ceremony.  It also holds a sacred place in all ceremony as it represents the heart of the creator.   For the Abenaki, the June moon is the nokahigas (the moon of hoeing), or depending on the year, the solstice could fall within temaskikos (the cutting grass moon).  Either way, the moon is central, for so many of us.

This solstice, our festival will bring together Elders and Indigenous teachers that carry with them the history of their people and the history and traditions revolving around indigenous foods & medicines, the harvest and spirit.    These teachers will generously share their knowledge from the past to create visions of a future where we care for the earth, it's food sources, it's medicines and people while still harvesting abundance from our food systems. 

Permaculture has now taken a large place in my family's life.   Many of the theories in permaculture and herbal medicine are based on traditional Indigenous knowledge.  This knowledge must be celebrated with the greater public and that is why we are looking for supporters like YOU to help us make this very first festival a huge success. 

With your contribution, we will:

  • Raise funds for the logistics of the event 
  • Pay many of the teachers for the sharing of this knowledge. 
  • Launch a long awaited and need festival!

Financial Breakdown

Here is what we will rent with your $$ :

  • Tents,  sound equipment, toilets, First Aid medicines, Cisterns for drinking water, Strawberries, Coffee & Tea = 3000$
  • Honorariums for the Elders and Teachers - 3000$
  • Administration & Volunteers - 2000$

Why are we doing this?

  • Share the vibrant knowledge and wisdom that is vibrant within the First Nation communities
  • Improve gardening, harvesting, agricultural and wildcrafting techniques
  • Exchange seeds
  • Foster discussion on food security, permaculture, First Nation knowledge and plant medicine
  • Eat those wonderful strawberries at the same time.

A challenge is nothing but success waiting to happen!

  • In community work we often spend more time than we are paid to ensure that our goal is reached.  One challenge that we face is not paying our staff what they deserve because our financial goal has not been met.
  • The solution to this is to ensure that we raise funds here and that the festival reaches a maximum amount of people - especially those willing to pay sponsorship prices (100$) to support the initiative. 

Other ways to help!

  • If you cannot support us financially, there are many other ways to help us out!  We will need volunteers for the event!   We need 13 volunteers for 4hrs each before during and after the event and you get a ticket!  Please contact Teprine Baldo at teprine76@yahoo.ca if you are interested. 
  • And you can share this with all your friends, family, lovers and strangers to on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram... to ensure that we can surpass our goal and raise money for this awesome festival.

Thank you, Nia:wen, Meegwetch, Wliwni, Têniki, Nakurmiik

Français

    FESTIVAL LUNE DES FRAISE




    Kwe, Kway, Bonjour, Ainngai, Tansi!

    Le dimanche 21 juin – solstice d’été 2015 - Siteweb

    Billet de lève-tôt à 50$ dans section Contrepartie!  Acheter dès maintenant!

    Vous souvenez-vous être allés, à la fin du printemps ou tôt en été, cueillir des fraises, ces petits fruits rouges, juteux, bien mûrs et les déguster avec la sensation d’être au septième ciel? Vous souvenez-vous être revenus à la maison les doigts tachés et l’estomac bien rempli rêvant d’avance aux tartes et aux confitures sans compter en congeler pour l’hiver suivant? Moi je m’en souviens!

    Pour plusieurs personnes incluant les autochtones, la récolte des fraises, premier petit fruit de l’année, marque l’arrivée de la saison estivale, une bonne raison pour célébrer et cueillir ce fruit aux propriétés médicinales. Pour le peuple Mohawk, c’est le premier fruit de l’année, fruit qu’ils ont dans toutes leurs cérémonies car elle représente le cœur du créateur. 

    A l’occasion du solstice d’été, notre festival va rassembler les Ainés et les enseignants autochtones qui perpétuent l’histoire de leur peuple ainsi que les traditions et les connaissances entourant les plantes médicinales, la récolte et les préparatifs pour la saison des semences. Ces enseignants vont partager généreusement leurs connaissances du passé pour créer une vision d’un futur où tous se soucieraient de la terre, des plantes médicinales et des gens tout en bénéficiant de récoltes abondantes.

    La ‘’permaculture’’ a maintenant prise une place importante dans la vie de ma famille. Plusieurs des théories en ‘’permaculture’’ et plantes médicinales sont basées sur les connaissances et traditions ancestrales des autochtones. Ces connaissances gagnent à être célébrées avec l’ensemble de la population et c’est pour cette raison que nous recherchons le support de personnes comme VOUS pour nous aider à faire de ce premier festival un grand succès.

    Avec votre support, nous pourrons :

    • Lever les fonds nécessaires aux besoins logistiques de cet événement
    • Rémunérer les enseignants pour le partage de leurs connaissances
    • Lancer un festival qui est en grand demande!


    Modalités financières :

    Avec les argents amassés, nous prévoyons :

    • Louer tentes, système de son, toilettes portables, trousses de premiers soins, réservoirs d’eau potable et aussi acheter fraises, thé et café, le tout pour une valeur totale de $3,000.
    • Rémunérer les Invités $3,000
    • Couvrir les frais d’administration $2,000

    Buts de ce festival :

    • Partager les connaissances et la sagesse qui sont vibrantes dans les communautés autochtones et ‘’permaculture’’.
    • Améliorer et approfondir les techniques de jardinage, d’agriculture et de 'wildcrafting' i.e. la pratique de la récolte des plantes dans leur habitat naturel comme nourriture ou à des fins médicinales.
    • Échanger des semences.
    • Favoriser le dialogue en matière de sécurité alimentaire, de permaculture, des connaissances des gens des Premières Nations et des plantes médicinales.
    • Savourer des fraises !

    Un défi n’est qu’un succès en devenir !

    • En travail communautaire, les personnes travaillent fort et souvent bénévolement pour atteindre leur objectif. Un défi auquel nous faisons face est de ne pas pouvoir rémunérer correctement notre personnel parce que notre objectif financier n’a pas été atteint.
    • L’objectif principal à ce stade-ci est d’amasser suffisamment de fonds, ici, dans notre milieu et de faire en sorte que le festival rejoigne le plus grand nombre possible de personnes – particulièrement ceux prêts à parrainer cette initiative avec un don de $100.

    Autres façons d’aider !

    • Bénévolat : nous aurons besoin de plusieurs volontaires il va sans dire, pour la mise en place et le bon déroulement de l’événement.  Nous avons besoins de 13 bénévoles pour l'événement - 4 hrs chaque et vous auriez un billet!  Si vous voulez, contacter Teprine Baldo à teprine76@yahoo.ca.
    • Partage : vous pouvez également partager la tenue de ce festival avec vos parents, vos proches, vos amis, et même des inconnus sur Facebook, Twitter, Instagram…. dans le but de surpasser nos objectifs et de récolter le plus de fonds possible pour ce fabuleux festival.

    Merci, Nia:wen, Meegwetch, Wliwni, Têniki, Nakurmiik

Thank you, Nia:wen, Meegwetch, Wliwni, Têniki, Nakurmiik

story:
Empower over 14,000 refugees across Greece! 


Elpis means hope. Our mission is to provide refugees with free solar-power to charge their mobile devices on Greek islands and mainland. 


Greece is struggling with an influx of over 850,000 refugees, with more than 155,000 arriving this year. Imagine leaving behind all you have ever known, and being left with only one way to contact your family, transfer money and access key information. Suddenly what just seemed like a phone has become a lifeline. 


 Nowadays almost everyone owns a smartphone, but for refugees access to electricity can be limited, especially on arrival. 


Access to electricity is very limited in camps and while travelling. Refugees are faced with little choice but to continue to look for alternatives, not hesitating to take dangerous risks in order to do so.


              This is how refugees need to charge their devices right now:                                           

A dangerous example of refugees hacking into a light-pole and exposing themselves to high current electricity in order to charge their mobile devices in the Kara Tepe camp, Lesvos, Greece (Credit: Georgios Makkas)

Syrian refugees using a television station's satellite truck to charge their mobile phones outside the Keleti train station in Budapest (Credit: Mauricio Lima, The New York Times).       
                                                                            

Together we can change this! 

We have designed a solar-charging station that will provide refugees with a sustainable source of electricity.

The Solar-Charger will be built in collaboration with Entec, a Greek solar technology company and its partners; Solar World, Steca Elektronik and Viosy S.A. This unit is configured to generate electricity for 12 plugs per hour using only the sun. We are aiming to run the Solar-Charger for 10 hours a day, delivering electricity to 3600 refugees in just 1 month. Due to its scalability, Project Elpis has the potential to expand to different locations in Greece, Europe and the Middle East.       

We showcase a fully sustainable model by addressing social, economic and environmental issues as we bring green electricity to refugees in Greece. 


Society: Refugees can live more independently from community resources, improving coexistence with locals and reducing tensions between the two. 

Economy: The solar-unit does not connect to the electricity grid, reducing energy expenditures while providing free and accessible energy to all who need it.

Environment: People need to communicate with family and access information. Our design offers a renewable and environmentally viable way of doing so.



With your help we can make this happen!


Your contribution will allow migrants to access a much-needed opportunity to seek out travel advice whilst also enabling communication with family and friends back home.


Dependable information empowers people in crises and aids in clarifying rumors, reducing confusion, stress and susceptibility to fraud.  


Therefore refugees will be able to make better-informed decisions for themselves and their families for a better chance of resettlement.   


You will also help refugees in safeguarding their most cherished memories that are often documented on their mobile phones; offering them hope in the darkest moments.      
                                       



 


                              Alexandros Angelopoulos & Samuel Kellerhals
                                             Students & Founders of Project Elpis              






                               Part of the Team!

               

                                                                                                   

                               

                            



                                 Good Samaritan

                 


                                Corporate Sponsor

                   



Help us by making a donation or by sharing with your friends and family!




If you cannot donate, there are still ways in which you can help us reach people and let them know about Project Elpis. Make a non-financial contribution by following the steps outlined below.
