                                 Good Samaritan

                 

                                Corporate Sponsor

                   


Help us by making a donation or by sharing with your friends and family!
If you cannot donate, there are still ways in which you can help us reach people and let them know about Project Elpis. Make a non-financial contribution by following the steps outlined below.

story:
Summary

I feel lucky to have been selected to participate in the Homeward Bound initiative. 2016 is the first year of a ten year program to build a 1,000 strong global collaboration of women in science. 

When I went to Antarctica 20 years ago to lead a civilian cleanup we knew Antarctica was significant as it regulates global climate and contains the majority of ice, fresh water and our climate history in its ice cores. But we didn't foresee the massive climate crisis and opportunity to change how we live with each other and on our planet.

My fellow participants and the faculty are incredible with rich experiences and specialties. They hail from around the world and cover a wide range of science professions and career stages. 

collage: Niina Kautto

Who am I?

I'm a social scientist, activist, humanitarian, writer and explorer; someone who likes to get things done. I'm optimistic in the face of challenges. I love collaboration. I feel I'm a witness and documentarian of our time - and I will speak, share and advocate for and with people near and far. 

I'm a Canadian and global citizen with wanderlust and a passion for social justice and equality for fellow human beings. 

It was a dream come true for me when I took groups to Antarctica in 1995/6 to give teeth to the Antarctic Treaty dedicating the continent to peace and science, as well as its Environmental Protocol urging better ecological practices. With the Russian Antarctic Expedition and a Canadian non-profit, we led the first civilian cleanup. It was a humble effort but there was a collective consciousness that solutions aren't only in policymakers or scientists' hands; we all play a part in a multitude of ways; our voices and actions matter.

I'm lucky to work for a respected humanitarian organization that gives independent medical care and advocates when those responsible cannot or will not provide care.

I've had the opportunity to help amplify the voices of young Congolese, Somali and other refugee girls in Kenya and to interview and write about Tibetan women in the diaspora on their struggle for rights in their home country. In Canada we still have work to do to right wrongs and protect nature including the 'refrigerator' in the Arctic, its peoples and ecosystem. 

image: Jjumba Martin

infographic: UN Women

Why is this campaign important for me? 

I see the links and relationship between global and earth health. 

I've seen firsthand how women's involvement in science, politics and community responses matters. I want to champion girls and women's rights and to help improve their visibility in science and leadership. Women's equality in health, education, the workforce and society is good for all. We can do this together, men and women.

Gender equality and climate change are intimately connected and can be tackled simultaneously. Recent studies have shown women are more affected by climate change and extreme weather events than men but also that women are more aware and responsive to climate change. Our planet and its biodiversity are being destroyed at an unprecedented rate, we need a new dynamic in both high impact climate science and critical environmental political decisions. 

The brightest minds can help solve the biggest global challenges, and this requires collaboration from diverse teams where there are no boundaries on gender, culture, age or discipline. Gender equality helps, among other things, enhances economic growth, ensures more durable peace agreements and make better science. When women have leadership and strategic skills, they are able to take on leadership roles affecting decision making for the sustainability of our world.

My track record, a few highlights

-I led a civilian cleanup expedition as Executive Director of the VIEW Foundation, a Canadian non-profit with the Russian Antarctic Expedition in 1995/6 at Bellingshausen research station and a pilot project at the Henryk Arctowski Polish station with the Polish Academy of Sciences. Our work was recognized at Antarctic Treaty meetings, the Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition and was shortlisted for the Condenast Traveler Environmental Award 1997. I wrote about the project in The Antarctic Book of Cooking and Cleaning with Wendy Trusler, expedition cook and artist.

design: The Office of Gilbert Li, HarperDesign 2015

-I did humanitarian work for a reputed emergency humanitarian organization in Rwanda, South Sudan, Peru, East Timor fighting for access to medicines and respect for humanitarian principles and access to medicines. I've spoken before Canada's Parliament, the World Trade Organization, university courses, and to major media on behalf of the organization advocating for patients.

-I set up a roundtable with multi-sector actors (legal, medical, judiciary) who respond to sexual gender based violence in Malawi for Dignitas International. This led to a network of responders who met to improve the response in two districts in Malawi. 

-I helped manage the launch of Museum of AIDS in Africa and its Virtual Memorial for this premier institution to collect, preserve, remember, interpret, share and exhibit the history of the origins, spread, and impact of AIDS in Africa as well as the past and present experiences of AIDS in Africa. 

image: Kirstin Gollings, International AIDS Conference, Melbourne 2014 Museum of AIDS in Africa

-For Voices of Positive Women, I set up dialogues between women living with HIV/AIDS in Canada and their doctors in 1991/2 at a time women were diagnosed later and had poorer health outcomes than men in Canada.

-I trained human rights advocates in the Asia-Pacific region for the Diplomacy Training Program in the Faculty of Law, University of New South Wales, Australia. It's a hands-on diplomacy program started by Dr. José Ramos Horta, former President of East Timor and Nobel Peace Prize recipient.

-In 2015 I  joined a cleanup expedition "Clean Up Svalbard". We collected debris in the most remote islands of the world above the Arctic circle. I photographed a survey of the trash, Aquamess, now collected at the Canada Science and Technology Museum and exhibited at the New York Hall of Science 2016. I research and write about Arctic marine debris. 

from Parley for the Oceans interview

-Member of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) Expert Group on History, Humanities and Social Science. Presented in the US and Malaysia on Mapping women and the Antarctic Wilderness: appearance and disappearance. I created a map of female place names in Antarctica named after women patrons, family, explorers and scientists.

-Fellow at the Arctic Summer College in 2016, selected to present my paper on circumpolar health in the Arctic and innovative responses at the Arctic Circle Assembly in Iceland, October 2016. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution of any size is so appreciated. You will help me be a better leader, collaborator, advocate, actor. I will be grateful to tell you more about what I, we learn and do. 

  • Each participant must raise US$ 15000 (not including flights, insurance and accommodation en route). I'm contributing minimum $5000. Significant in-kind contributions have been made and underwritten by Dattner Grant (management consulting company organising this program) and its partners. Full program cost per person is A$40,000.

  • The perks are varied and customized for you! Pitch me a perk and I'll consider too! Want me to speak to your group? A postcard from the end of the world? In-kind donation?

  • If I don't reach my entire goal, the costs will offset a portion raised towards to cost. 

The Objectives & Impact

Project Objectives:

•To elevate each participant’s leadership capabilities.

•To educate the team on the science of what is happening to our planet.

•To refine participants’ skills to design and execute strategy, and to create plans for future collaborations as women working towards a sustainable future.

•To enhance these skills, over 10-years, with 1000 women networked and skilled to affect change.

•To create active, non-hierarchical collaborations among women in small groups and as a collective.

To have a global focus

To contribute to and elevate the broader societal conversation (see it written up in New York TImes) about the role of women in leading the world toward a more sustainable future.

Why Women:

•Globally, women are underrepresented in leadership positions and change has been incredibly slow, despite increasing dialogue and process/systems changes

•Women are emerging from college degrees as significant percentages of graduates and they take up a significant percentage of our workforce. However, they are in the profound minority globally when it comes to executive decision-making roles.

•By giving women the leadership and strategic skills, a sound understanding of the science, and a strong purposefully developed network they will be able to impact policy and decisions towards a sustainable future.

How: 

•At sea for twenty days, led by Greg Mortimer OAM, sailing from Ushuaia Argentina on Dec 2nd, 2016

•Twelve days of state of the art leadership and strategic planning training 

•Six days of a cutting edge science education program incorporating the most up to date and relevant research about the state and functioning of our planet delivered by leading academics.

Homeward Bound benefits from globally recognised people of influence, including Dr Jane Goodall, Primatologist and environmental activist, Franny Armstrong, one of the world’s 100 most influential women, Sylvia Earle, famous marine ecologist and celebrated activist with Mission Blue, Dr Susan David, Co-Founder and Director of the Institute of Coaching, Harvard A-lister, Dr Robert Kaplan and Dave Norton – developed strategy mapping, balanced score card.

It's not only leadership learning and work in Antarctica: Since late last year, we have worked projects such as education outreach, climate science communication and women as changemakers . We have also explored leadership to promote transformational change.

•A documentary (60 minute multi media release) is being made, following the journey and exploring the role of women in our world.

Homeward Bound is the brainchild of renowned leadership expert Fabian Dattner, a magic collaboration with Dr. Jess Melbourne‐Thomas from the Antarctic Climate and Ecosystems Cooperative Research Centre.

Risks & Challenges

I risk not raising the full amount to offset my costs to participate but I will persevere as I'm committed to being on Homeward Bound. I have the potential to extend this campaign if required.

The weather in Antarctica may be a barrier to accomplish all we hope such as visits to scientific stations but having led expeditions before, I know that mother nature rules and you  be adaptive, sensible and lateral in your approach to do what you need to do. I trust the highly experienced Homeward Bound leader Fabian and ship expedition leader Greg Mortimer.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, but you can still help:

  • Please help get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Get or keep involved however you can with initiatives to use carbon-alternates, to reduce plastic use and footprint
  • Learn or share more about the value of supporting women in STEM and leadership, protecting our planet, the poles 
  • Keep being a great neighbour!
story_txt:
Summary
I feel lucky to have been selected to participate in the Homeward Bound initiative. 2016 is the first year of a ten year program to build a 1,000 strong global collaboration of women in science. 
When I went to Antarctica 20 years ago to lead a civilian cleanup we knew Antarctica was significant as it regulates global climate and contains the majority of ice, fresh water and our climate history in its ice cores. But we didn't foresee the massive climate crisis and opportunity to change how we live with each other and on our planet.
My fellow participants and the faculty are incredible with rich experiences and specialties. They hail from around the world and cover a wide range of science professions and career stages. 

collage: Niina Kautto
Who am I?
I'm a social scientist, activist, humanitarian, writer and explorer; someone who likes to get things done. I'm optimistic in the face of challenges. I love collaboration. I feel I'm a witness and documentarian of our time - and I will speak, share and advocate for and with people near and far. 

I'm a Canadian and global citizen with wanderlust and a passion for social justice and equality for fellow human beings. 
It was a dream come true for me when I took groups to Antarctica in 1995/6 to give teeth to the Antarctic Treaty dedicating the continent to peace and science, as well as its Environmental Protocol urging better ecological practices. With the Russian Antarctic Expedition and a Canadian non-profit, we led the first civilian cleanup. It was a humble effort but there was a collective consciousness that solutions aren't only in policymakers or scientists' hands; we all play a part in a multitude of ways; our voices and actions matter.

I'm lucky to work for a respected humanitarian organization that gives independent medical care and advocates when those responsible cannot or will not provide care.
I've had the opportunity to help amplify the voices of young Congolese, Somali and other refugee girls in Kenya and to interview and write about Tibetan women in the diaspora on their struggle for rights in their home country. In Canada we still have work to do to right wrongs and protect nature including the 'refrigerator' in the Arctic, its peoples and ecosystem. 

image: Jjumba Martin

infographic: UN Women
Why is this campaign important for me? 
I see the links and relationship between global and earth health. 
I've seen firsthand how women's involvement in science, politics and community responses matters. I want to champion girls and women's rights and to help improve their visibility in science and leadership. Women's equality in health, education, the workforce and society is good for all. We can do this together, men and women.

Gender equality and climate change are intimately connected and can be tackled simultaneously. Recent studies have shown women are more affected by climate change and extreme weather events than men but also that women are more aware and responsive to climate change. Our planet and its biodiversity are being destroyed at an unprecedented rate, we need a new dynamic in both high impact climate science and critical environmental political decisions. 
The brightest minds can help solve the biggest global challenges, and this requires collaboration from diverse teams where there are no boundaries on gender, culture, age or discipline. Gender equality helps, among other things, enhances economic growth, ensures more durable peace agreements and make better science. When women have leadership and strategic skills, they are able to take on leadership roles affecting decision making for the sustainability of our world.
My track record, a few highlights
-I led a civilian cleanup expedition as Executive Director of the VIEW Foundation, a Canadian non-profit with the Russian Antarctic Expedition in 1995/6 at Bellingshausen research station and a pilot project at the Henryk Arctowski Polish station with the Polish Academy of Sciences. Our work was recognized at Antarctic Treaty meetings, the Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition and was shortlisted for the Condenast Traveler Environmental Award 1997. I wrote about the project in The Antarctic Book of Cooking and Cleaning with Wendy Trusler, expedition cook and artist.

design: The Office of Gilbert Li, HarperDesign 2015

I've spoken before Canada's Parliament, the World Trade Organization, university courses, and to major media on behalf of the organization advocating for patients.

-I helped manage the launch of Museum of AIDS in Africa and its Virtual Memorial for this premier institution to collect, preserve, remember, interpret, share and exhibit the history of the origins, spread, and impact of AIDS in Africa as well as the past and present experiences of AIDS in Africa. 

image: Kirstin Gollings, International AIDS Conference, Melbourne 2014 Museum of AIDS in Africa
-For Voices of Positive Women, I set up dialogues between women living with HIV/AIDS in Canada and their doctors in 1991/2 at a time women were diagnosed later and had poorer health outcomes than men in Canada.

I photographed a survey of the trash, Aquamess, now collected at the Canada Science and Technology Museum and exhibited at the New York Hall of Science 2016. I research and write about Arctic marine debris. 


from Parley for the Oceans interview
-Member of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) Expert Group on History, Humanities and Social Science. Presented in the US and Malaysia on Mapping women and the Antarctic Wilderness: appearance and disappearance. I created a map of female place names in Antarctica named after women patrons, family, explorers and scientists.

story:
Haz clic aquí para leer la historia en Español

Lots of cell phones in Mexico, few places where to charge them.

According to the National Institute of Statistics and Geography in Mexico (INEGI), 80% of the households in that country have at least one cellular phone. It is expected that by the year 2020, 62% of the total cellular phone lines in Mexico would be assigned to a smart phone device (1).

64% of the population uses the public transportation system on a regular basis (2). In average, the commuting time in Mexico City ranges from 1 hour and 47 minutes to 2 hours and  48 minutes depending on the origin and destination points (3). 

All this produces an increasing need of having mobile charging stations publicly available all around the country. 

Overweight and obesity are huge problems in Mexico

Mexico has the highest overweight ratio of  the countries that are part of the Organization for Economic Co­operation and Development (OECD). 70% of adults are overweight and about 32% are obese (3). Poor diet choices and lack of exercise are the main reasons for these health problems.

To make things worse, almost 1 in 3 children is overweight in Mexico. Nationwide, only 3% of the children reported intense physical activity (4).

It is imminent the need to provide ways to motivate people to exercise and to have good eating habits. 

Green Energy pedaling mobile device chargers

We would like to help people stay connected and healthy via our green energy pedaling stations. Each station would help reducing our annual carbon footprint in 120kg of CO2.

I have had this dream since January 2014. My father was very sick, and had to be hospitalized. My family and me spent several days at the ER's waiting room.

We had to make and receive several phone calls, to and from other members of our family that couldn't be there with us, like my wife and my son and, of course, from my work. There is no battery pack that can keep up with this amount of use.

I couldn't connect my cell phone anywhere in the hospital due to internal policies and that was when I got an idea. Why couldn't we generate green energy to recharge our mobile devices by doing exercise, using a pedaling device for example?

Year and a half later, we were fortunate to discover that in another part of the world, they had already created such a device. We contacted them immediately to find out how we could import the machinery.


Charles de Gaulle railway station (France)


Amsterdam Airport (The Netherlands)

With this machinery, we will be able to charge all types of mobile devices, such as laptops, tablets, cameras and cellphones. You actually have a normal electricity plug of 112V/230V.  White colored LEDs light up when pedaling starts, and green LEDs show when green energy is available. 

We need your help

As you can imagine, there are a lot of things that we need to pay to start up our project.

  • The kiosk design. We want to create few alternatives so that we can easily adapt the charging station to different environments.
  • The kiosk development. We want to construct the kiosks with resistant, durable materials and, if possible, with recycled ones.
  • Green energy generators' costs. Including delivery and importing fees.  
  • Logistics to distribute them. The cost of placing the charging stations at strategic positions to maximize impact.

We want to locate these devices where they are needed the most. For example at:

  • Schools and universities, and in other education related locations, like museums and libraries.
  • Outside the cities, like in parks, archaeological sites and other tourist destinations. 
  • Specially in far and poor regions of the country, where there is not easy access to electricity, and having a device like this could have a huge positive impact in people's lives.
  • The airports, while waiting for your departure, or for the arrival of a family member or friend.
  • Malls, auditoriums, expos, you name it... the opportunities are limitless!
  • ER's waiting rooms, to help people that are currently facing the same challenge I faced almost 2 years ago.

 

We know that conscious people like yourself can help us, so we want you to be part of this experience.

Please select the kind of perk you want to receive, and make a donation to make this enterprise a reality.

We want to thank you in advance for all your help! We know that our green energy project will benefit thousands of people in our country and are very excited to have you as part of our team.

Receive the warmest regards and blessings from Mexico, and let's go green!


Historia en Español

Recarga tus dispositivos móviles con energía verde


 

Queremos ayudar a que la gente mantenga sus dispositivos mobiles cargados y mientras se mantienen saludables. 

Chorros de celulares en México, pocos lugares para cargarlos.

De acuerdo al Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía en México (INEGI), 80% de los hogares de ese país tiene por lo menos un teléfono celular. Se espera que para el año 2020, 62% de todas las lineas de teléfonos celulares en México estarán asignadas a un teléfono inteligente (1).

64% de la población usa regularmente el sistema público de transporte (2). En promedio, el tiempo de traslado en la Ciudad de México oscila entre 1 hora con 47 minutos y 2 horas con 48 minutos, dependiendo de las ubicaciones de origen y destino (3).

Todo esto produce una necesidad creciente de tener estaciones de carga de teléfonos móviles disponibles a lo largo de la república.

Sobrepeso y obesidad son un gran problema en México

México tiene el índice de sobrepeso más alto de los países que pertenecen a la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económico (OCDE). 70% de los adultos tienen sobrepeso y cerca del 32% son obesos (3). Selecciones incorrectas en la dieta diaria y falta de ejercicio son los principales problemas para estos problemas.

Para agraver la cosas, así 1 de cada 3 niños tiene sobrepeso en México. A nivel nacional, sólo el 3% de los niños reportó actividad física intensa (4).

Es inmiende la necesidad de proveer vías alterna que motiven a la gente a ejercitarse y a tener buenos hábitos alimenticios.

Generadores a pedales de energía verde para cargar dispositivos móviles

Nos gustaría ayudar a la gente a permanecer conectada y saludable a través de nuestras estaciones generadoras a pedales de energía verde. Cada estación ayudará a reducir nuestra huella de carbono anual en 120kg de CO2.

Tengo este sueño desde enero de 2014. Mi papá estaba muy enfermo y fue hospitalizado. Mi familia y yo pasamos varios días en la sala de espera de urgencias.

Tuvimos que hacer y recibir varias llamadas telefónicas de otros miembros de la familia que no podían estar con nosotros, como mi esposa, mi hijo, y por supuesto, de mi trabajo. No existe una batería que pueda durar por tanto tiempo bajo este uso constante.

No pude conectar mi celular para recargarlo en ningún lugar en el hospital debido a que estaba prohibido en el hospital. Fue entonces que se me ocurrió una idea. ¿Por qué no generamos energía verde para recargar nuestros dispositivos móviles haciendo ejercicio, usando un dispositivo de pedales?

Año y medio después, tuvimos suerte de descubrir que en otra parte del mundo ya habían creado ese dispositivo. Los contactamos inmediatamente para saber como podríamos importar el generador de energía verde.


Estación de tren Charles de Gaulle (Francia)


Aeropuerto de Amsterdam (Holanda)

Con esta maquinaria, podríamos recargar la batería de cualquier tipo de dispositivos móviles, tales como laptops, tabletas, cámaras y teléfonos celulares. De hecho tienes un enchufe tradicional de 112V/230V. LEDs de color blando se prenden cuando comienzas a pedalear, y LEDs verdes se encienden cuando la energía verde es disponible.

Necesitamos tu ayuda. 

Como podrás imaginarte, hay muchas cosas que tenemos que pagar para comenzar con nuestro proyecto.

  • El diseño del kiosco. Queremos crear algunas alternativa para que las estaciones de carga se puedan adaptar a distintos ambientes.
  • El desarrollo del kiosco. Queremos construirlos con materiales durables, resistentes y ,si es posible,reciclados.
  • Los costos de importación de los generadores verdes. Incluyendo los costos de transportación y los de importación.
  • Logística de su distribución. Los costos de ubicar las estaciones de carga en localidades estratégicas para maximizar el impacto.

Queremos ubicarlos donde más se necesitan. Por ejemplo en:

  • Escuelas y universidades, y en otras localidades relacionadas con la educación, como museos y bibliotecas.
  • Fuera de las ciudades, como en parques, sitios arqueológicos y otros destinos turísticos.
  • Especialmente en regiones lejanas y pobres, donde no se tiene acceso fácil a la electricidad, y el tener un dispositivo como este tendría un impacto muy positivo en la vida de la gente. 
  • En aeropuertos, mientras esperas tu partida, o la llegada de un miembro de tu familia o a un amigo.
  • En centros comerciales, auditorios, expos, ¡tu escoges... !¡las oportunidades son ilimitadas!
  • En salas de espera de urgencias, para ayudar a gente que actualmente enfrenta desafíos como el que yo enfrenté hace casi 2 años.

Sabemos que gente consciente como tú nos puede ayudar, y queremos que formes parte de esta experiencia.

Por favor selecciona los beneficios adicionales que quieres recibir, y realiza tu donación para que esta empresa se haga realidad.

¡Queremos agradecerte de antemano por toda tu ayuda! Sabemos que nuestro proyecto beneficiará a miles de personas, y estamos muy emocionados de tenerte en nuestro equipo.

Recibe los más cálidos saludos y bendiciones desde México, y ¡vayamos verde!


(1) Estadísticas sobre disponibilidad y uso de tecnología de información y comunicaciones en los Hogares 2011. www.inegi.org.mx. INEGI. 2012.

(2) "El 68% de la población usa el transporte público". www.razon.com.mx.   Notimex/La Razón. Dec. 2014.

(3) Millán-Bojalil, J. "Un tráfico paralizante en la Ciudad de México". www.consutoresinternacionales.com. Consultores Internacionales. Apr 2011.

(4) "Obesity and the economics of prevention: fit not fat". www.oecd.org.  OECD. May 2014.

(5) Jiménez-Cruz, A., Bacardi-Gascon, M. (2004) The Fattening Burden of Type 2 Diabetes on Mexicans. Projections from early growth to adulthood. Diabetes Care.  27(5). 1213-1215.

ER's waiting rooms, to help people that are currently facing the same challenge I faced almost 2 years ago.
 We know that conscious people like yourself can help us, so we want you to be part of this experience.Please select the kind of perk you want to receive, and make a donation to make this enterprise a reality.We want to thank you in advance for all your help! We know that our green energy project will benefit thousands of people in our country and are very excited to have you as part of our team.Receive the warmest regards and blessings from Mexico, and let's go green!Historia en EspañolRecarga tus dispositivos móviles con energía verde Queremos ayudar a que la gente mantenga sus dispositivos mobiles cargados y mientras se mantienen saludables. Chorros de celulares en México, pocos lugares para cargarlos.De acuerdo al Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía en México (INEGI), 80% de los hogares de ese país tiene por lo menos un teléfono celular. Se espera que para el año 2020, 62% de todas las lineas de teléfonos celulares en México estarán asignadas a un teléfono inteligente (1).64% de la población usa regularmente el sistema público de transporte (2). En promedio, el tiempo de traslado en la Ciudad de México oscila entre 1 hora con 47 minutos y 2 horas con 48 minutos, dependiendo de las ubicaciones de origen y destino (3).Todo esto produce una necesidad creciente de tener estaciones de carga de teléfonos móviles disponibles a lo largo de la república.Sobrepeso y obesidad son un gran problema en MéxicoMéxico tiene el índice de sobrepeso más alto de los países que pertenecen a la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económico (OCDE). 70% de los adultos tienen sobrepeso y cerca del 32% son obesos (3). Selecciones incorrectas en la dieta diaria y falta de ejercicio son los principales problemas para estos problemas.Para agraver la cosas, así 1 de cada 3 niños tiene sobrepeso en México. A nivel nacional, sólo el 3% de los niños reportó actividad física intensa (4).Es inmiende la necesidad de proveer vías alterna que motiven a la gente a ejercitarse y a tener buenos hábitos alimenticios.Generadores a pedales de energía verde para cargar dispositivos móvilesNos gustaría ayudar a la gente a permanecer conectada y saludable a través de nuestras estaciones generadoras a pedales de energía verde. Cada estación ayudará a reducir nuestra huella de carbono anual en 120kg de CO2.Tengo este sueño desde enero de 2014. Mi papá estaba muy enfermo y fue hospitalizado. Mi familia y yo pasamos varios días en la sala de espera de urgencias.Tuvimos que hacer y recibir varias llamadas telefónicas de otros miembros de la familia que no podían estar con nosotros, como mi esposa, mi hijo, y por supuesto, de mi trabajo. No existe una batería que pueda durar por tanto tiempo bajo este uso constante.No pude conectar mi celular para recargarlo en ningún lugar en el hospital debido a que estaba prohibido en el hospital. Fue entonces que se me ocurrió una idea. ¿Por qué no generamos energía verde para recargar nuestros dispositivos móviles haciendo ejercicio, usando un dispositivo de pedales?Año y medio después, tuvimos suerte de descubrir que en otra parte del mundo ya habían creado ese dispositivo. Los contactamos inmediatamente para saber como podríamos importar el generador de energía verde.Estación de tren Charles de Gaulle (Francia)Aeropuerto de Amsterdam (Holanda)Con esta maquinaria, podríamos recargar la batería de cualquier tipo de dispositivos móviles, tales como laptops, tabletas, cámaras y teléfonos celulares. De hecho tienes un enchufe tradicional de 112V/230V. LEDs de color blando se prenden cuando comienzas a pedalear, y LEDs verdes se encienden cuando la energía verde es disponible.Necesitamos tu ayuda. Como podrás imaginarte, hay muchas cosas que tenemos que pagar para comenzar con nuestro proyecto.

El diseño del kiosco. Queremos crear algunas alternativa para que las estaciones de carga se puedan adaptar a distintos ambientes.


El desarrollo del kiosco. Queremos construirlos con materiales durables, resistentes y ,si es posible,reciclados.


Los costos de importación de los generadores verdes. Incluyendo los costos de transportación y los de importación.


Logística de su distribución. Los costos de ubicar las estaciones de carga en localidades estratégicas para maximizar el impacto.

Queremos ubicarlos donde más se necesitan. Por ejemplo en:

Escuelas y universidades, y en otras localidades relacionadas con la educación, como museos y bibliotecas.


Fuera de las ciudades, como en parques, sitios arqueológicos y otros destinos turísticos.


Especialmente en regiones lejanas y pobres, donde no se tiene acceso fácil a la electricidad, y el tener un dispositivo como este tendría un impacto muy positivo en la vida de la gente. 


En aeropuertos, mientras esperas tu partida, o la llegada de un miembro de tu familia o a un amigo.


En centros comerciales, auditorios, expos, ¡tu escoges... !¡las oportunidades son ilimitadas!


En salas de espera de urgencias, para ayudar a gente que actualmente enfrenta desafíos como el que yo enfrenté hace casi 2 años.

Sabemos que gente consciente como tú nos puede ayudar, y queremos que formes parte de esta experiencia.Por favor selecciona los beneficios adicionales que quieres recibir, y realiza tu donación para que esta empresa se haga realidad.¡Queremos agradecerte de antemano por toda tu ayuda! Sabemos que nuestro proyecto beneficiará a miles de personas, y estamos muy emocionados de tenerte en nuestro equipo.Recibe los más cálidos saludos y bendiciones desde México, y ¡vayamos verde!(1) Estadísticas sobre disponibilidad y uso de tecnología de información y comunicaciones en los Hogares 2011. www.inegi.org.mx. INEGI. 2012.(2) "El 68% de la población usa el transporte público". www.razon.com.mx.   Notimex/La Razón. Dec. 2014.(3) Millán-Bojalil, J. "Un tráfico paralizante en la Ciudad de México". www.consutoresinternacionales.com. Consultores Internacionales. Apr 2011.(4) "Obesity and the economics of prevention: fit not fat". www.oecd.org.  OECD. May 2014.(5) Jiménez-Cruz, A., Bacardi-Gascon, M. (2004) The Fattening Burden of Type 2 Diabetes on Mexicans. Projections from early growth to adulthood. Diabetes Care.  27(5). 1213-1215.

story:
Short Summary

Athletes For Clean Air  (AFCA) is a non-profit Utah entity comprised of athletes and outdoor professionals dedicated to cleaning Utah's dangerous and polluted air.
Our #365DaysOfEarth campaign is geared towards making everyday Earth Day by promoting and instituting healthy, simple lifestyle practices that will benefit Earth and her environment.  This campaign is a multi-pronged approach at raising  public awareness about environmental responsibility and action.
The Tree Planting Project will enable the purchase and installation  of hundreds of trees and planting materials  throughout Salt Lake City to help combat the insidious carbon dioxide-laden air and our dangerous levels of ozone pollution that exist inside of our basin-structured geography. 
The trees planted will also serve as a reminder to citizens, corporations and government that action can be and is being taken; every single person can make a difference. 

What We Need & What You Get

We're asking for $5000 as a watermark for funding. Is it a lot? Yes. Because we need more trees! Every penny will go towards trees and planting material, and not a penny less. In fact, our founders have already started the effort by purchasing and donating their own equipment  to move forward. 
By donating to our fundraising campaign, you enable the purchase and planting of more than 100 trees, and help ensure cleaner air for Utah and her citizens, as well as better health for the environment and its many creature residents. 
No matter how much we raise, every penny will go towards the tree project and planting as many trees as possible... Every cent. So whether it's $50 or all $5000, we're hell bent on clearing our air! Whatever you donate will be used solely for trees and planting material, and in exchange for your generous donation, we'll put your name on our list of 'Game Changers' on our #365DaysOfEarth page as a thank you! 
The Impact

New trees now, clean air forever... And an impact to last just as long. By donating to our Tree Planting Project now, you're creating a better future not just for today, but for years to come. Every single day, these trees will provide lasting benefits to neighborhoods and cities that will inspire and motivate  those who see them into building a better Earth. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Volunteer to help us plant the trees! Strong bodies will be needed, and the more, the merrier! All of the labor is being donated, and we'd love to have your help!  Contact us at info@athletesforcleanair.com for more information!.
  • You can help us get the word out and make some noise by sharing our fundraising link across social media and email, as well as showing us how YOU #365DaysOfEarth by using the hashtag to share your efforts! 
  • Follow us on Facebook at Facebook.com/AthletesForCleanAir, on Instagram at @athletesforcleanair and on Twitter at @athleteair.

story:
"We love Roșia Montană" project ( 1st July 2013 – 12th August 2013)

The “We love Rosia Montana” project is an adventure trip of two Europeans from completely different countries – Germany (Louisa Hoppe) and Romania (Tica Darie). When we have first met, at the FanFest 2012 – we promised to “make the world a better place and to begin with the salvation of Rosia Montana”.

Now words become action: This summer we will cross Europe on a tandem bike – from Copenhagen to Rosia Montana. During the trip we will organize events in Copenhagen, Hamburg, Berlin, Leipzig, Chemnitz, Dresden, Prague, Vienna, Bratislava, Budapest, Cluj Napoca and Rosia Montana.

We want to draw attention internationally towards the protest of the Save Rosia Montana cause and help the locals and the activists to gain more support through networking. We want to inform the European public about what is really happening locally.

More info: http://weloverosia.eu

 

About Roșia Montană

Located in a green valley in the Carpathians, in the Transylvania region, the village tells a more than 2000 - year history, as it is the oldest documented mining settlement in Romania. And the history continues to be written today. Not only beauty and age characterizes this place – but it’s also one big treasure: Europe’s largest gold reserve.

The Transylvanian village is placed in an incredibly valuable gold mining area, and therefore the right for exploitation of the gold reserve of Rosia has been concessioned by Rosia Montana Gold Corporation (RMGC) since 1997. RMGC represents a joint venture between the Canadian mining company Gabriel Resources as major shares holder (80%) and the Romanian state (20%). The plan of the company is to destroy 4 mountains and a large part of the village in order to establish a cyanide lake & mining waste deposits – with massive and not foreseeable consequences for nature and people.

The Romanian state claims that this project – at a time of global economic crisis - will bring thousands of jobs and immediate gains of up to 4 billion US dollars.

On the other hand, a part of the local community opposes this project for over 10 years – in the firm belief that the true treasure of the region is not its gold.

In the year of 2000 about 40 Romanian NGOs gathered for the first time in Rosia Montana and issued a joint statement against the proposed project.

This was the birth of the “Save Rosia Montana” campaign – today the strongest civic protest movement in Romania. This opposition is based on diverse cultural, social, environmental and economic arguments. 

More info: http://weloverosia.eu or http://rosiamontana.org

 

GOAL

The main goal of this solidarity tour is to open people’s minds and hearts – on the one hand for Rosia Montana – on the other to connect people with environmental and social consciousness from the countries where we’ll travel in Europe.

Besides the cultural exchange, the focus of our project is clearly the promotion of democracy, civic education and civil society networking.

With the tour we pursue:

- to affirm the idea of Europe with a bottom up approach
- to create awareness of environmental issues
- to spread of information about the proposed gold project
- to actively support the Save Rosia Montana Campaign

We want to get the ball rolling, to take a stand, gain international attention and thus boost the tourism in the area.
It is not only the problem of a small village somewhere in the Romanian Apuseni mountains. It’s about human rights, environment protection and democracy. Especially since Romania is part of the European Union, it is the responsibility of each of us to show solidarity.

To make this dream come true, we need you! 

Our own savings and help from friends is unfortunately not enough to cover the costs for the equipment we need. For this reason we ask you to help us!

We want to buy the following equipment:

Ortlieb front panniers - 77 euro

Vaude back panniers - 85 euro
1 - Bike trailer - 41 euro
2 - Eagle Creek Pack  - 50 euro  
2 - isomatte - 70 euro

2 - shoe bike short 40 euro

1 - sigma cycle computer - 30 euro

 

maps and food :)

Other ways you can donate: 

Directly through PayPal: tica.darie@gmail.com

---------------

Danske Bank  

Reg. nr. 3361
Konto nr. 3361621735
DUMITRU VARZARIU DARIE 

---------------

Banca Transilvania

Swift Code: BTRLRO22SVA
Account:RO48BTRL03401201467771XX
DUMITRU VARZARIU DARIE

---------------

Sparkasse
Kontonummer: 1620040375
bank code/ BLZ: 82056060
IBAN: DE60820560601620040375
BIC: HELADEF1MUE
LOUISA HOPPE

In case you can't contribute please share this link, we are very thankful!

 

Thank you very much,
Louisa and Tica

story:
"LAVADORA EFICIENTE"

Soy Gustavo Peña Salvadó, vivo en Valencia y he patentado un invento que consiste en un nuevo concepto de Lavadora doméstica. Esta lavadora te permite ahorrar tiempo a la hora de lavar tu ropa, ya que dispones de 2 tambores donde podrás lavar simultáneamente y en un mismo proceso de lavado, diferentes tipos de ropa, según sea de color, blanca o negra, así como separar diferentes tipos de prendas que, en ocasiones, deseamos lavar de forma individual, como ropa de trabajo, zapatillas, ropa delicada, sábanas, toallas, etc.

Con esta campaña se pretende financiar este proyecto y crear una pequeña empresa que será la encargada de desarrollar el proyecto y así lograr los objetivos planteados. Después de los costes del registro de una patente, es necesario invertir en varios estudios como son: el "Estudio de Viabilidad",  "Estudio de Mercado" y el "Plan de Negocio", así como el desarrollo del diseño y la fabricación de un prototipo. Finalmente el objetivo de nuestro proyecto será la fabricación y distribución de la "Lavadora Eficiente" en el mercado nacional e internacional. De esta manera y gracias a tu colaboración en este proyecto, pretendemos conseguir la creación de nuevos puestos de trabajo y fomentar el I+D+i en nuestro país.

La financiación requerida aproximada es de 350.000 euros, con los cuales, se formalizará una pequeña empresa que se ocupará del desarrollo del diseño y de la fabricación de un prototipo, con la contratación de personal cualificado que se encargue del desarrollo del diseño e ingeniería, así como del desarrollo de la parte de marketing y comercialización del producto. El objetivo de la empresa será llegar a un acuerdo de colaboración con una empresa fabricante de electrodomésticos, para la fabricación  y distribución de su "Lavadora Eficiente", generando y fomentando el desarrollo de empleo.

Tu aportación y colaboración será fundamental para llevar a cabo la realización del proyecto, materializando una idea que ofrece a la sociedad una serie de ventajas, como es ahorrar tiempo en el lavado de la ropa y la reducción del consumo de electricidad y consumo de agua, disminuyendo por tanto los costes en las facturas de agua y luz, ya que a lo largo de 1 año el número de lavadoras que se ponen es notablemente inferior.

El uso de esta "Lavadora Eficiente" en nuestros hogares estará contribuyendo a la reducción del gasto energético, con lo que se obtiene una clara ventaja medioambiental, la reducción de las emisiones de CO2 a la atmósfera.

ENGLISH VERSION

My name is Gustavo Peña Salvadó, I live in Valencia and I have patented an invention that consists of a new concept of household washing machine. This washer saves you time when washing your clothes, since you have 2 drums which can be washed simultaneously and in the same washing process, different clothes, as color, black or white, and separate different types of garments that sometimes wish wash individually, as work clothes, shoes, delicate clothes, sheets, towels.This campaign is intended to finance this project and create a small business that will be responsible for developing the project and achieve the objectives. After the costs of registering a patent, it is necessary to invest in several studies including: the "Feasibility Study", "Market Research" and "Business Plan" as well as the development of design and manufacture of a prototype. Finally, the aim of our project is the manufacture and distribution of the "Efficient Washer" in the national and international market. In this way and with your help on this project, we aim to achieve the creation of new jobs and encourage R & D in our country.The approximate funding required is 350,000 euros, with which a small business that will continue to develop the design and fabrication of a prototype, with the recruitment of qualified personnel in charge of design development and engineering, and will be formalized and the development of marketing and product marketing. The aim of the company will reach an agreement with a manufacturer of appliances for the manufacture and distribution of its "Efficient Washer" generating and promoting the development of employment.Your contribution and collaboration will be essential to carry out the project, materializing an idea that offers society a number of advantages, such as saving time in the laundry and reduced electricity consumption and water consumption, thus lowering costs in water and electricity bills, since over 1 year the number of washing machines are set is considerably lower.Using this "Efficient Washer" in our homes will help to reduce energy spending, with a clear environmental advantage is obtained, reducing CO2 emissions to the atmosphere.

Finally, the aim of our project is the manufacture and distribution of the "Efficient Washer" in the national and international market. In this way and with your help on this project, we aim to achieve the creation of new jobs and encourage R & D in our country.The approximate funding required is 350,000 euros, with which a small business that will continue to develop the design and fabrication of a prototype, with the recruitment of qualified personnel in charge of design development and engineering, and will be formalized and the development of marketing and product marketing. The aim of the company will reach an agreement with a manufacturer of appliances for the manufacture and distribution of its "Efficient Washer" generating and promoting the development of employment.Your contribution and collaboration will be essential to carry out the project, materializing an idea that offers society a number of advantages, such as saving time in the laundry and reduced electricity consumption and water consumption, thus lowering costs in water and electricity bills, since over 1 year the number of washing machines are set is considerably lower.Using this "Efficient Washer" in our homes will help to reduce energy spending, with a clear environmental advantage is obtained, reducing CO2 emissions to the atmosphere.

story:
Archo was born and lives in the forest.  He is a simple, kindhearted soul and lives a simple life.  He loves his forest, and wants to keep it clean.  But then one day he sees Arsho dancing in a traveling circus with her friend Titer the butterfly fluttering around her, and everything changes.  Archo's sidekick Meghu whispers well intention-ed advice in his ear, but he has his own ambitions, too!

Gargar the dirty crow likes garbage, but soon his life, too, is turned upside down when he stumbles across Archo, Arsho and their friends.

This film is to be sculpted in Armenia, where few educational animated TV series have been produced since independence in 1993.  We have pulled in Vrej Kassouny, one of Armenia's foremost animators to do this groundbreaking work in order to help the smallest kids of the world learn to keep the environment clean.

The goal of the project is to produce a 9 minute TV episode that will serve as a springboard for a series of 24 episodes to be produced and broadcast later.  The interest for the series is already high around the world.  This first episode will open the flood gates, breaking into international markets and festivals. 

Homegrown Armenian animation, environmental awareness and imagination that will reach out to the world.

Archo the Bear wants a clean environment!
Arsho is a dancing bear in the traveling circus
Meghu the Bumble Bee is Archo's best friend!
Titer is Arsho's sidekick!
Gargar likes his garbage!
 
and Djandj, the camera shy fly!  Djaaaandj, where are you?
 
You can secure one, two or ALL of these characters as perks during this campaign.  Each of them is handcrafted by the ladies of the Berd Women's Resource Center Foundation in Berd, the setting of the animated series.
 
So get the word out!  Archo and Arsho with friends need to shape a young Armenian generation to take care of the incredible natural beauty of their homeland.  Share this campaign with all your friends!

story:
Farmer Seeking Roots

      

About Me: 

My name is Joneve Murphy. I am an organic farmer. I started my career over 11 years ago, and never looked back.  There is no feeling like expending your energy and labor to nourish others.  My first farming position was at Green Meadows Farm in South Hamilton, Massachusetts. We ran a CSA and I started a wholesale business, selling food to restaurants in the greater Boston Area.  I then moved on to manage 6 acres for The Inn at Shelburne Farms in Shelburne Vermont.  After that I moved down to the DC area and grew for Ayrshire Farm in Upperville Virginia.  I am now the farmer for The Inn at Little Washington; a double 5 star restaurant in the foothills of the Blueridge mountains in Virginia. 


Throughout my career I have spent the off seasons traveling in Asia.  While there I have spent time volunteering on farms, wandering through agricultural areas and markets, soaking up the knowledge that I found.  I have learned so much from these excursions over the years.  I have found new varieties of produce, new techniques and new passions. I have worked with farmers growing rice, turmeric and other spices, fruit and vegetables. These excursions were always something that I just did for myself, a way to take a break from the responsibilities of my own land, but still engage in growing food.  That is about to change.

About My Project:

I am launching a new project in June called Farmer Seeking Roots. I plan to travel through Europe, Asia and South America for one year volunteering on farms and following the food home with a consumer to cook, eat and share recipes. I will explore many avenues of sustainable agriculture; family farms, cooperatives, school gardens, community gardens, pastured animals, urban farms and many more. I want to labor alongside the multitude of ardent family farmers in both developed and developing nations. I hope to share growing techniques, new varieties, and recipes, but also I want to share their passion.  I want to highlight these farmers and consumers for the important decisions they make about food every day. I want to have a conversation with both farmers and consumers about their choices to support sustainable agriculture from either side of the plate. 


    

Tea Plantations in Munnar, India

Tumeric Harvest, Navdanya Farm, Uttaranchal, India

Rice Paddies, Sapa, Vietnam

Why This Project is Important and What I Hope to Achieve:

I hope that through sharing these conversations I can inspire others to grow and eat organically and sustainably. I hope to share techniques that I find with other farmers, in an effort to further their food enterprises. I want to encourage others to support their local farmers and food producers, to grow something towards their own nutrition and the nourishment of their community. We live in a world dominated by Industrial agriculture, environmental degradation, and chemically laced foods. A world where the act of going to the grocery store has become an act of fear and guilt for many. We live in a world where the “experts” say that this monoculture cropping, antibiotic plumping, industrialized, polluting, chemical and factory based farming is the only way we are going to feed the growing population of this planet.  I want to prove them wrong.  I want to highlight farmers that are growing food in such a way so as to rebuild their soils, improve the local environment and engage with their communities. I want to highlight farmers and consumers that are creating and contributing to a movement much larger than themselves. Organic, sustainable, family farming is what is going to feed our world. People that engage with their land, that work to see it and the land surrounding flourish.  Our personal health is dependent on the health of the soil, the forests, the oceans, the animals and people that surround us. We can no longer be insular in our decisions about food.  We vote with our dollars more often and more impactfully than any of our votes at the ballot box. We, as a global community must support enterprises and people that are furthering the sustainable food movement.

I will share this journey; the triumphs, struggles and the people that I find through a photo journal and blog on my website: http://www.farmerseekingroots.com . I invite you to follow me.

Where Your Contribution Will Go:

I have saved 10K towards this project, and I am going to go, regardless of what I raise here.  However that 10K is not enough to do the trip that I really want to do.  Your contributions will help me to include Europe on this journey.  It will also help me to travel for the entire year.  There are many costs to consider; plane tickets and overland travel, food in between farms, health insurance, maintaining and updating the website, data charges, hiring translators and much more.  I am doing everything I can to do this on the cheap.  I’m hoping that most farms will trade me room and board for my labor.  I will use couchsurfers, friends (old and new), and hostels for places to stay in between farms.  I am all in on this project. I am selling everything I own, and I am putting my entire savings account into this. Please consider donating and helping me to bring this important project to light.

We can change our food system.  We can vote for what we want our future to be. 

Thank you for your interest in my project. Please remember that no contribution is too small! If you cannot contribute financially, please help by sharing, tweeting and generally spreading the word about my project to anyone that may be interested. If you can contribute, Great! Please share my project with your friends and tell them why you were motivated to donate. 

Perks:

Included in every perk is a huge debt of gratitude from me. Without your donation and support this project would not be possible. Thank you 


1.  The Farmer's version of a recipe card: I will send you a postcard with a copy of my potting soil, and compost tea recipe.  Good soil and happy microbes are the backbone of a plentiful garden.

2.  Exotic Postcard: I will send you a personal postcard from somewhere in the world. I promise to make it a good one!

3.  Prints: My photographs from both my previous journeys in Asia, and the farms I have worked on during my career. There are more than 30 to choose from.  All prints will arrive matted with backing and printed on professional quality paper. There will be no watermark on the image, but I will sign the mat (unless you specify that you would like it unsigned). Choose yours from the Gallery here,or from the prints available page on my website. 

After you have made your contribution, I will email you to find out which print you want.

4.  Gardening Guide: A PDF download of a gardening guide I've been writing over the past few years. It includes full growing instructions for over 100 different veggies, herbs and micro greens, as well as lists of my favorite varieties, tips on container gardening, space maximization, planting structures, trellising techniques  and much more.

5.  One on One Skype Sessions.  You can choose what we do here.  

We can have 1 session and spend a half hour discussing your gardening questions. 

We can have two sessions: during the first session we will discuss your family's needs, garden starting tips and other questions.  I will then use this information to create a crop plan for your garden.  This plan will include succession planting plans to keep your family table lush with produce throughout the spring, summer and fall. During the second session I will explain your plan and answer any further questions.

We can also add a third and follow-up session. During this session we will discuss how your season is going and any questions that may have come up. This session will of course be while I am traveling so you pick the date and we shall see where I am!
      I will start consulting sessions after April 1st on a first come first serve basis.
     
 6.  In Person Consulting.  I would love to help you with choosing your site, designing your space, drawing up time saving irrigation plans and drafting a crop plan to suit your needs.  After the visit I will write your best plan for gardening success, and we can follow up on Skype with any questions or concerns you may have. I can do in person consulting for both families and businesses.  I am an expert in succession planting and plans that utilize all four gardening seasons and maximize your yields. Please let me help you with your projects large or small.
       I will start consulting sessions after April 1st on a first come first serve basis.

 I will be in the DC area and available for onsite visits until the beginning of May, and in the North East early to mid May. Outside of these locals I may be able to come to your property, but you will be responsible for travel expenses. Please email me at farmerseekingroots@gmail.com with dates and location before donating to make sure that an on-site visit is possible. I look forward to meeting you and making your gardening/farming dreams come true.

**Have some consulting needs that you don't see listed here? Please email me and I will try to accommodate your needs. farmerseekingroots@gmail.com


I hope you will enjoy following my journey over the next year through my blog at 

www.farmerseekingroots.com

If you are a farmer, artisanal food producer or food cooperative interested in hosting me and sharing your story, please get in touch. 

Contact: farmerseekingroots@gmail.com

Video Credit: Produced by Joey Walker withwww.dccameracars.com

                     Shot and edited by Ivan Kander withwww.lucky9studios.com

Profile photo credit: Molly Peterson. find her atwww.mollympeterson.com

All other images are my own

story:
Short Summary

Do you enjoy the Blue Hills Reservation and its 125 miles of trails and 7,000 acres of forest?  While the Reservation is free to enjoy, maintaining it and keeping its forests healthy are not.  Please help us reach our goal to make sure people will continue to enjoy the Blue Hills. 

Your donation to this 'On the Trail' Campaign will help the Friends of the Blue Hills engage hundreds of volunteers who devote over 1,700 hours each year to maintaining the park.  Your support will pay for the tools we need to cut brush, the shovels to dig out ditches for water to travel off trail and the refreshments to sustain tired volunteers.

For 35 years, the Friends of the Blue Hills, a non-profit organization, has engaged thousands of volunteers to maintain the trails, keep the forests healthy and protect the land from unwise uses.  Your donation will make sure we can continue to recruit, train and manage volunteers to take care of the Reservation’s trails and forests.

Our goal for this campaign is $10,000.  With your help, we will raise at least $3,000 online and raise the balance off-line.  Please help maintain the trails and help us reach our goal!

Campaign update:  A generous donor has offered a match to help us reach our $10,000 goal!  Donate today - and your gift will go even further!

We will thank you with great perks!  (Remember, no perks will be sent out of the country.)

What Your Donation Will Support

Your donation of any amount will help provide the needed resources for maintaining the trails.  Here are example of how your donation will help support our trail maintenance efforts.

     $35 –  large clippers (loppers)

     $50 –   2 pick-mattocks (Like a pickaxe – it’s perfect for the Blue Hills’ rocky soil)

     $150 -   6 entrenching tools (a collapsible spade for trail ‘Adopters’ who
     maintain a particular trail throughout the year

    $250 –   refreshments for one trail event with volunteers after devoting a
     total of 100 hours to maintaining the trails

   $500 –   Services and tools required for maintaining the chainsaw

No matter how much you give, your donation will support the on-going needs of the Reservation’s trails and forests.

Your Impact

For 35 years, the Friends of the Blue Hills has helped protect and maintain the Reservation.  We have engaged thousands of volunteers who have maintained the Reservation’s 125 miles of trails and helped control invasive species.  Every time you walk, bike or run the trails, you can appreciate over 1,000 hours of work devoted by hundreds of Friends of the Blue Hills’ volunteers each year.  Please help us continue to clear the trails and keep the forests healthy.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out about this campaign – through Twitter, Facebook, email and – yes – in person!

We also encourage you to attend a trail maintenance event or organize a stewardship day at your company to help clear the trails or keep the forests healthy.

story:
A Himalayan Backpacking Adventure

Hey everyone, Caleb here. Make sure to watch the video first before you read this.

Life update, I have enrolled in a 35 day Himalaya backpacking course with the National Outdoor Leadership School (NOLS), and I need some help covering the cost of the tuition. 

I know that I have asked for money in the past, previously raising money for Invisible Children's Schools for Schools program in 2011, and when I became a full-time volunteer with Invisible Children in 2012; and I am incredibly grateful to the many people who have given funds in the past. I was very cautious about asking for funds for my next adventure, and honestly feel very awkward doing so because of all the amazing support I have received; but I am only doing so because without your help this won't be possible.

When I enrolled into this program I knew that I would be able to make enough money over the course of the summer to fund the tuition but I didn't know that the tuition is due 75 days in advance and now I've hit a bump in the road. This course will be challenging but the backpacking and mountaineering training that I receive will be vital to film projects that I plan to do in the future. Now I was almost about to ditch the idea and give up on this trip until next year but after talking to a few friends I have decided to open an invitation to friends and family who would like to support me.

I realize that not everybody will get the chance to backpack through the incredible Himalaya Mountains in India, so I decided to put this up because I want to share this experience with as many people as possible. I have set up a reward system so that you can be involved in my adventure, and I will be setting up a blog to document my journey every step of the way.

What I Need

Alright, I am a planner, so this is going to be very detailed... here we go.

The cost of my tuition is $7,759.40 (this includes tuition, equipment deposit and tuition protection)

  • I have received a $1,000 scholarship bringing my total to $6,759.40.
  • Tuition is due July 8th, 2013, which only gives me two and a half months to earn money. I am estimating that I will be able to provide $4,000 by July 8th so that means I need $2,759.40 by the deadline.
  • Now there are many expenses on top of this tuition. There is the cost of plane tickets, round trip estimated to be $1,300-$1,600 depending on when I buy them.
  • Actual equipment costs (I plan to rent a majority of it) will range from $1,200-$1,800.
  • Then there is the cost of miscellaneous items such as a Passport ($180), Rosetta Stone for Hindi ($180-$320) visa fees (estimated $200), GoPro camera ($200-$400) and small Nikon camera ($150) to document the trip as well as a small portable backpack solar panel so that I can keep these things charged ($60).
  • *I am still checking on which ones I need to update* Vaccines and immunizations are optional but highly recommended and crazy expensive. Hepatitis A ($282), Hepatitis B ($381), Japanese Encephalitis ($600), Typhoid ($86), Polio vaccine ($74), Yellow Fever (TBD) and optional recommended Rabies ($900) and $50 consultation. For a total of around $2373, yikes.
  • After almost everything (not including tuition and vaccines) my expenses will come to $3470-$4530. The money that I make between July 8th and the course start date on September 21st will pay for these expenses. I am cutting this budget very close so any money raised over my goal of $2,759.40 will go towards these additional expenses.
  • Special note on my budget, if I don't raise enough funds I have worked it out with my bank to be able to take out a loan so even if the project is only half funded I will still make the trip. If India becomes dangerous to travel to or if something causes me not to go I will either re-schedule the trip for next year or refund the money 100% via check or PayPal.

What You Get

I don't know how many of you will ever be able to backpack through the Himalayas so I want to bring this experience as close to your life as possible. This is why I chose to do a reward system; each reward is meant to be very intentional, and I'm excited to share them.

I will also be documenting my journey through a blog. I've got to start training for my 120-mile hike, and that starts now. Expect to see the blog up and running very soon which will show my preparations and cover my hike (updated after I return).

*The thank you notes will ship before my trip but all other rewards will be sent after my return in Octobor.

My Hike

This hike is actually going to be pretty crazy. During the hike we will cover 95-120 miles while carrying 40%-45% of our body weight. We will be camping for over two weeks at an altitude of over 10,000 ft. and will attempt crossing of snow covered passes over 13,000 ft. gaining and losing 3,000 ft of elevation on some days.. We will cross whitewater river, scramble across teetering boulders and sweat our way up mountain passes. Between New Delhi and the mountains temperatures can vary from 100 to 0 degrees Fahrenheit.
 
It starts with an overnight train journey from New Delhi, followed by a three-hour Jeep ride to reach NOLS India Base at Ranikhet. We will rest, pack up and continue by bus to the village of Lohajang. We have two choices in routes, which will be determined by the weather. We might enter the Milam Valleys and continue to the roadhead Munsiari along well traveled trails which was an important link in the ancient trade routes between India and Tibet. Along that route we will pass deserted 300-year-old villages that stand in history to show the once thriving business between the two countries. The alternative route from Lohajang traverses around the west side of the Trishul massif before crossing Kuari Pass. Pilgrims on their way to pay respect to Nanda Devi have historically used that area.
 
 
We will be hiking through forests of Maple, Oak and Rhododendron and pass villages 
where cattle-and-water-buffalo-powered agriculture is still the main way of life. It's going to be super remote, something rarely seen by western visitors and is the home of the Himalayan black bear, Himalayan tahr, fox, bharal (blue sheep) and snow leopards.
 
Hindi is the national language of India, English is spoken mostly in the cities and is recognized as the second national language. About one-third of our course will be spent in close contact with porters, tea stall owners, bus drivers and the local hill people of northern India so basic Hindi is going to help me out a lot. 
 
We will return to NOLS India base by the evening of the third to last day to clean and store equipment. The next day will be spent de-issuing gear and packing personal bags. In the evening we will have one final chance to go shopping in the local market and the next morning we catch a train back to Delhi. After graduation dinner the course is over but I will plan on staying two extra days in India to travel to Agra and see the Taj Mahal. Then back on a plane to the US on the 27th-ish to get ready for my 21st birthday on the 31st here in the states, woohoo!

The Impact

There are so many different reasons why I'm choosing to take on this experience.

I have had some incredible opportunities in life to explore new things and push myself outside my comfort zone. This is a unique opportunity that is unlike anything I have done before. This experience will immerse me into a lot of the culture; it will allow me to learn the language, eat the food, live with the people and learn their way of life. NOLS is the only organization in the world that takes students to the Himalayas, and I don't think there will be any other opportunities in my life that will lead me to the Himalayas, which makes this so exciting.

The other major motivation behind this is for the backpacking and mountaineering training that I will be receiving. As many of you know I have a passion for film and I have also always had a passion for the outdoors. As I venture further into independent filmmaking I would like to make the subject of my videos the pure beauty of nature. I want to showcase what this world has to offer for a worldwide audience. My NOLS training will give me the education, knowledge and ability to safely travel and hike to any spot so that I can get the perfect shots that will hopefully inspire people to spend more of their time outside. My biggest inspiration has come from a Youtuber named Devin Graham http://www.youtube.com/user/devinsupertramp. If you check out his channel you will get a better idea of what I mean. He also posted a fantastic video explaining what he does which I will link here http://youtu.be/62CUg45lMtQ

Also here is a small peek into the Overview Effect as mentioned in the video (this will influence a lot of the blog) http://ekostories.com/2013/04/11/planetary-collective-overview/

Last but not least I will be receiving 6 semester credit hours from the University of Utah, yay education!

Other Ways You Can Help

This campaign will be up and running for a little over a month, so if you can't contribute now but can later that is totally fine.

If you aren't able to contribute, you can also help by sharing it with some of your friends and Indiegogo makes it super easy.

Thank You!

A Himalayan Backpacking Adventure
Hey everyone, Caleb here. Make sure to watch the video first before you read this.
Life update, I have enrolled in a 35 day Himalaya backpacking course with the National Outdoor Leadership School (NOLS), and I need some help covering the cost of the tuition. 
I know that I have asked for money in the past, previously raising money for Invisible Children's Schools for Schools program in 2011, and when I became a full-time volunteer with Invisible Children in 2012; and I am incredibly grateful to the many people who have given funds in the past. I was very cautious about asking for funds for my next adventure, and honestly feel very awkward doing so because of all the amazing support I have received; but I am only doing so because without your help this won't be possible.
When I enrolled into this program I knew that I would be able to make enough money over the course of the summer to fund the tuition but I didn't know that the tuition is due 75 days in advance and now I've hit a bump in the road. This course will be challenging but the backpacking and mountaineering training that I receive will be vital to film projects that I plan to do in the future. Now I was almost about to ditch the idea and give up on this trip until next year but after talking to a few friends I have decided to open an invitation to friends and family who would like to support me.
I realize that not everybody will get the chance to backpack through the incredible Himalaya Mountains in India, so I decided to put this up because I want to share this experience with as many people as possible. I have set up a reward system so that you can be involved in my adventure, and I will be setting up a blog to document my journey every step of the way.
What I Need
Alright, I am a planner, so this is going to be very detailed... here we go.
The cost of my tuition is $7,759.40 (this includes tuition, equipment deposit and tuition protection)

I have received a $1,000 scholarship bringing my total to $6,759.40.

Tuition is due July 8th, 2013, which only gives me two and a half months to earn money. I am estimating that I will be able to provide $4,000 by July 8th so that means I need $2,759.40 by the deadline.
Now there are many expenses on top of this tuition. There is the cost of plane tickets, round trip estimated to be $1,300-$1,600 depending on when I buy them.
Actual equipment costs (I plan to rent a majority of it) will range from $1,200-$1,800.
Then there is the cost of miscellaneous items such as a Passport ($180), Rosetta Stone for Hindi ($180-$320) visa fees (estimated $200), GoPro camera ($200-$400) and small Nikon camera ($150) to document the trip as well as a small portable backpack solar panel so that I can keep these things charged ($60).

Hepatitis A ($282), Hepatitis B ($381), Japanese Encephalitis ($600), Typhoid ($86), Polio vaccine ($74), Yellow Fever (TBD) and optional recommended Rabies ($900) and $50 consultation. For a total of around $2373, yikes.
After almost everything (not including tuition and vaccines) my expenses will come to $3470-$4530. The money that I make between July 8th and the course start date on September 21st will pay for these expenses. I am cutting this budget very close so any money raised over my goal of $2,759.40 will go towards these additional expenses.
