story:
Paraguay Verde: A National Environmental Youth Camp

Empowering Youth Leaders in Environmental Conservation

The Challenge:

Paraguay is a nation rich in environmental resources, notable especially for migratory bird populations, diverse wildlife and some of the last remaining stands of tropical Atlantic Forest. Yet much of the country's environment is under threat by development, deforestation, over-hunting and grazing, and other environmentally damaging practices. Many Paraguayans recognize these problems and are seeking ways to take action to preserve, replenish, and sustainably manage their country's natural resources.


The Opportunity:

While Paraguay is environmentally rich, its best resource is its people. With over half of the population under the age of 25, Paraguayan youth are shaping the future of their country and its impact on the world. By providing young Paraguayans with the tools and guidance, we can foster a new generation of informed and dedicated young leaders to pioneer and inspire a movement of environmental sustainability and stewardship across the country.




The Plan:

A Todo Pulmon, a Paraguayan NGO, and Peace Corps Paraguay will host the third Paraguay Verde National Youth Camp in February 2014. By bringing together over 70 youth from across the nation, young Paraguayans will have the opportunity to learn more about environmental problems in Paraguay, share ideas and collaborate on solutions for their respective communities. The camp provides a national platform for young Paraguayans to discuss local issues and share strategies for solutions in a fun and empowering atmosphere. Youth return to their communities capable of starting or enhancing an environmental youth group or implementing an action plan. Paraguay Verde also provides the opportunity for youth to develop a dialogue on environmental themes, promoting their inclusion in the local and national discourse around Paraguay’s sustainable future.


                                 

Successes:

The fantastic successes of the past three Paraguay Verde youth camps, held in February 2012, October 2012, and May 2013 has led to a network of youth leaders already hard at work across Paraguay.  New environmental youth groups are being formed and many communities are organizing environmental events, such as tree plantings. Over 200 Paraguayan youth attended the past two camps where they strengthened leadership skills, met other young environmental leaders from across the country, learned about global and national environmental issues, and developed action plans to tackle these issues in their own communities.


During the past three camps Paraguayan youth planted over 200 native tree species, participated in youth leadership panels, practiced worm composting, and made eco-bricks, plastic bottles filled with inorganic waste like plastic bags and Styrofoam, to demonstrate more sustainable and economically beneficial methods of waste and resource management.


After attending a Paraguay Verde camp, one group carried out a campaign to collect 100 kilos of batteries at their schools while educating their peers about the potential contamination caused by disposing the batteries in the nearby wetlands. Another group used the eco-bricks they learned to make during a Paraguay Verde camp to build wall out of eco-bricks outside the community’s health post.


How you can help:

We need your support to put our plan into action! Your contribution will go directly towards funding the fourth Paraguay Verde camp for the 70 youth expected to come. It only takes $75 to sponsor one youth for the duration of the camp, enabling young environmental leaders who may otherwise be unable to attend, to participate in this transformative experience!  The youth themselves will also be contributing to their experience by fundraising locally to cover transportation expenses to the camp.


You can also help us by sharing this campaign on social media and with your family and friends. Thank you for your support and for helping to promote a sustainable future, in Paraguay and beyond.

https://www.facebook.com/atodopulmonparaguay

https://www.facebook.com/CampamentoParaguayVerde



Paraguay Verde: Fortaleciendo Jóvenes Líderes en la Conservación del Ambiente.

El Desafío:

Paraguay es una nación rica en recursos naturales, por sus poblaciones de mamíferos, reptiles, peces, aves migratorias, más de 710 especies de aves, muchas de ellas endémicas a eco-regiones únicas en el mundo como es el Bosque Atlántico del Alto Paraná (BAAPA). Sin embargo, gran parte de la biodiversidad del país enfrenta muchos desafíos, como son:  cambio de uso de tierra, la caza furtiva, el pastoreo descontrolado y otras prácticas dañinas para el ambiente. Muchos paraguayos reconocen estos problemas y están buscando maneras de tomar acciones para conservar, reponer y gestionar de manera sostenible los recursos naturales de su país.

La Oportunidad:

Mientras que Paraguay es rico en biodiversidad, su mejor recurso es su gente. Más de la mitad de la población paraguaya es menor a 25 años, y ya jóvenes paraguayos están dando forma al futuro de su país y su impacto en el mundo. Al proporcionar a los jóvenes paraguayos  herramientas,  orientaciones y conectarlos en un encuentro nacional al menos una vez al año, hacemos posible la creación de una red donde más de 100 jóvenes tienen los mismas metas y deseos. Con ello, podemos fomentar una nueva generación de jóvenes líderes informados y dedicados a trabajar juntos y explorar e inspirar un movimiento de sostenibilidad ambiental, incentivando la administración sustentable de sus recursos a nivel local, regional y en el futuro de todo un país.    



                        

El Plan:

A Todo Pulmón, Paraguay Respira , una organización que tiene por objetivo reconstruir bosques, mejorar espacios públicos y recuperar la calidad de vida, y junto con Voluntarios del Cuerpo de Paz Paraguay lanzarán el cuarto Campamento “Paraguay Verde” en febrero de 2013, un evento nacional que apunta a reunir y conectar a jóvenes paraguayos que estén  interesados en el desarrollo sustentable de sus comunidades.

El evento pretende reunir a 100 jóvenes de todo el país que tendrán la oportunidad de aprender más sobre los desafíos ambientales del Paraguay, compartiendo ideas y experiencias, y colaborando con posibles soluciones para sus respectivas comunidades. El campamento proveerá una plataforma nacional para que jóvenes paraguayos puedan dialogar sobre problemas locales y para compartir estrategias de soluciones en un ambiente divertido y participativo. Los jóvenes regresarán a sus comunidades con un plan de acción y capacitados para empezar o fortalecer a un grupo juvenil ambiental e implementar su plan de acción. Paraguay Verde también proporcionará la oportunidad para que los jóvenes puedan desarrollar un diálogo sobre temas ambientales, promocionando la inclusión de los mismos en el discurso local y nacional con respecto a un futuro sustentable en el Paraguay.

Éxitos:

El fantástico éxito de los tres últimos campamentos juveniles de Paraguay Verde, realizados en febrero, octubre de 2012 y mayo de  2013, brindó la oportunidad de formar una red de jóvenes líderes que ya se encuentra trabajando en la promoción de mejor uso de los recursos naturales en el país . Nuevos grupos juveniles ambientales se formaron y muchas comunidades ya han organizado eventos ambientales, como la plantación de árboles en su comunidad y comunidades vecinas. Más de 250 jóvenes paraguayos participaron en los últimos 3 campamentos en los cuales tuvieron la oportunidad de fortalecer sus habilidades de liderazgo, conocer a otros jóvenes líderes ambientalistas de todo el país, aprender sobre asuntos ambientales a nivel global y nacional y desarrollar planes de acción para trabajar a favor del ambiente en sus comunidades.

Durante los tres últimos campamentos, jóvenes paraguayos plantaron más de 200 árboles de especies nativas, participaron en paneles de jóvenes líderes, practicaron lombricultura, y prepararon eco-ladrillos, botellas de plástico cargadas con residuos inorgánicos como bolsas de plástico e isopor, a fin de demostrar métodos más sostenibles y económicamente beneficiosos con respecto al manejo de residuos.

Después de asistir en el campamento de Paraguay Verde, un grupo organizó una campaña de recolección de pilas en sus escuelas, mientras educaban a sus pares sobre la contaminación potencial causada por desechar las pilas cerca de los humedales, logrando juntar 100 kilos de pilas en la comunidad. Otro grupo utilizó eco-ladrillos que aprendieron hacer durante el campamento Paraguay Verde para construir un muro de eco-ladrillos fuera del Puesto de Salud de la comunidad.

Otros de los logros incluyen:

  • La página de Facebook Paraguay Verde, como espacio para compartir proyectos, lecciones aprendidas y dialogar sobre estrategias locales.
  • El apoyo de la Entidad Binacional Yacyreta (EBY), en el último campamento
  • Varias empresas paraguayas han contribuido para cubrir la logística
  • La Secretaría de Turismo de Paraguay ha apoyado fuertemente las ediciones anteriores. 



Cómo nos puedes ayudar, una forma innovadora y donde todos podemos ser parte:

Todos podemos y debemos contribuir! Una forma es a través del apoyo financiero. ¡Necesitamos de tu apoyo para concretar en febrero de 2014 la participación de 100 jóvenes. Ayúdanos con tu donación haciendo posible la participación de jóvenes paraguayos.

Tú también nos puedes ayudar compartiendo esta campaña con tu familia y amigos en las redes sociales. Gracias por tu apoyo y por ayudarnos a promover un futuro sostenible en Paraguay y más allá.

https://www.facebook.com/atodopulmonparaguay

https://www.facebook.com/CampamentoParaguayVerde

de aprender más sobre los desafíos ambientales del Paraguay, compartiendo ideas
y experiencias, y colaborando con posibles soluciones para sus respectivas
comunidades. El campamento proveerá una plataforma nacional para que jóvenes
paraguayos puedan dialogar sobre problemas locales y para compartir estrategias
de soluciones en un ambiente divertido y participativo. Los jóvenes regresarán
a sus comunidades con un plan de acción y capacitados para empezar o fortalecer
a un grupo juvenil ambiental e implementar su plan de acción. Paraguay Verde
también proporcionará la oportunidad para que los jóvenes puedan desarrollar un
diálogo sobre temas ambientales, promocionando la inclusión de los mismos en el
discurso local y nacional con respecto a un futuro sustentable en el Paraguay.
Éxitos:

El fantástico éxito de los
tres últimos campamentos juveniles de Paraguay Verde, realizados en febrero,
octubre de 2012 y mayo de  2013,
brindó la oportunidad de formar una red de jóvenes líderes que ya se encuentra
trabajando en la promoción de mejor uso de los recursos naturales en el país .
Nuevos grupos juveniles ambientales se formaron y muchas comunidades ya han
organizado eventos ambientales, como la plantación de árboles en su comunidad y
comunidades vecinas. Más de 250 jóvenes paraguayos participaron en los últimos
3 campamentos en los cuales tuvieron la oportunidad de fortalecer sus
habilidades de liderazgo, conocer a otros jóvenes líderes ambientalistas de
todo el país, aprender sobre asuntos ambientales a nivel global y nacional y desarrollar planes de acción para trabajar a favor del ambiente en sus comunidades. 
Durante los tres últimos campamentos,
jóvenes paraguayos plantaron más de 200 árboles de especies nativas,
participaron en paneles de jóvenes líderes, practicaron lombricultura, y
prepararon eco-ladrillos, botellas de plástico cargadas con residuos
inorgánicos como bolsas de plástico e isopor, a fin de demostrar métodos más
sostenibles y económicamente beneficiosos con respecto al manejo de residuos.
Después de asistir en el campamento de
Paraguay Verde, un grupo organizó una campaña de recolección de pilas en sus
escuelas, mientras educaban a sus pares sobre la contaminación potencial
causada por desechar las pilas cerca de los humedales, logrando juntar 100
kilos de pilas en la comunidad. Otro grupo utilizó eco-ladrillos que
aprendieron hacer durante el campamento Paraguay Verde para construir un muro
de eco-ladrillos fuera del Puesto de Salud de la comunidad.
Otros de los logros incluyen:

La página de Facebook Paraguay
     Verde, como espacio para compartir proyectos, lecciones aprendidas y
     dialogar sobre estrategias locales.
El apoyo de la Entidad
     Binacional Yacyreta (EBY), en el último campamento
Varias empresas paraguayas han
     contribuido para cubrir la logística
La Secretaría de Turismo de
     Paraguay ha apoyado fuertemente las ediciones anteriores.  



Cómo nos puedes ayudar, una forma innovadora y donde
todos podemos ser parte:
Todos
podemos y debemos contribuir! Una forma es a través del apoyo financiero.
¡Necesitamos de tu apoyo para concretar en febrero de 2014 la participación de
100 jóvenes. Ayúdanos con tu donación haciendo posible la participación de
jóvenes paraguayos.
Tú
también nos puedes ayudar compartiendo esta campaña con tu familia y amigos en
las redes sociales. Gracias por tu apoyo y por ayudarnos a promover un futuro
sostenible en Paraguay y más allá.
https://www.facebook.com/atodopulmonparaguayhttps://www.facebook.com/CampamentoParaguayVerde

story:
Save B.C. Wolves

As you read this, wolves in British Columbia, Canada are being shot at by hunters in helicopters. 

This is an ill-conceived plan to save endangered caribou in B.C..  The wolves are not responsible for the dwindling caribou numbers; habitat loss and human encroachment are. But wolves are taking the blame and paying the price. 

You can help.

Pacific Wild Alliance, a leading wildlife conservation organization with a long track record of successful conservation achievements needs your support to put a stop to this barbaric wolf kill program.  We hope to raise $50,000 to provide a full-time campaigner with the resources to build local and international public pressure by exposing this wolf kill program as the unethical, inhumane and scientifically indefensible slaughter that it is through advertising, media and a host of other public outreach platforms. 

Funding will also go towards logistical support to document the current cull program directly - it is critical that the helicopter-based killing is recorded.

B.C. Wolves need your help.


The Issue

•  Decades of habitat destruction and human encroachment have left B.C.’s woodland caribou in serious decline. But instead of protecting critical habitat, such as lichen-rich high elevation forests, the B.C. government turned a deaf ear to scientific warnings and allowed logging, industrial exploration and other kinds of human encroachment to take place. Now that the caribou are almost gone, they’ve decided to scapegoat wolves. These highly social and intelligent animals, icons of B.C.’s natural heritage, should not be killed because of long-term government negligence in regards to habitat protection.

•   If the wolf kill program is allowed to continue, thousands of wolves will die a cruel and unnecessary death resulting in an ecosystem imbalance and loss of genetic diversity.   Don’t let that happen. Help us fight for the wolves' right to live.

What We Need 

•   With donated advertising space, we are bringing this issue directly to the streets of Vancouver and Victoria where the wolf kill decision is ultimately made.   Help us make use of this valuable space.  Your donation will go to increasing advertising exposure in addition to production and design costs. 

•   Your support will help fund a full-time wolf campaign team with the means to build local and international public pressure by exposing this kill as unscientific and ineffective through a variety of media, including film, and a host of other public outreach platforms. 

•  Your support will ensure that wolves currently being killed now do not die in vain and that a long term solution that addresses the fundamental issue of habitat loss becomes the solution for the future of caribou in British Columbia.

With the Save B.C. Wolves Indiegogo campaign funds, we are supporting ground crews in the field actively who are actively working to document the kill program.  We are designing ads for a new public campaign that will bring this issue front and centre to British Columbians.


The Impact

•   Your contribution can make a real difference to B.C's wolves. You can help shine a light on this wildlife tragedy and be part of the solution.  We have a team in place to tackle the front-lines of this issue, but they can only begin with your donations. 

•   There are solutions that do not result in intelligent, highly social animals being slaughtered in inhumane ways.  For example, winter-based motorized activity, one of the leading causes of caribou decline in the Selkirk mountains should be restricted from operating in endangered caribou habitat.  Traditionally, deep snow would provide security from wolves but the tracks made by vehicles allow wolves easy access to caribou. The B.C. government has known this for decades but has consistently capitulated to industry and recreational lobby groups who want access to this critical habitat.  Same story for logging, mining, and oil and gas companies - they continue to be granted access to lands that are critical for the survival of woodland caribou. 

•  If we are silent nothing will change.  The success of this fundraising campaign will allow us to  build enough pressure on government, through a concerted, strategic and informed public education campaign that the widespread killing of wolves will become a sad chapter in our history. 

Who Pacific Wild Alliance is 

Pacific Wild Alliance a B.C. non-profit organization committed to defending  wildlife and their habitat in Canada.  We work with a diverse array of communities, First Nations, groups and individuals to ensure that biodiversity protection is at the forefront of land and marine use decisions. 

•  Pacific Wild has a long track record of carrying out successful wildlife protection campaigns that involve science-informed, creative and result-based efforts.

•  Find out more about our initiatives and team at www.pacificwild.org

Want to learn more? Read these informative articles about the BC wolf cull

•     ‘Wolf cull will not save threatened Canadian caribou’ by Nature International Journal of Science 

•     ‘Canada has done little to protect endangered caribou population’ by The Globe & Mail 

•  ‘ ‘BC War on Wolves’ Interview with Ian McAllister' by CBC News 

Other Ways You Can Help

•     Visit Pacific Wild’s take action webpage to find out what you can do to help. 

•  Write a letter/send an email to the government voicing your opposition to the wolf kill program in British Columbia 

•  Sign the petition to Save B.C. Wolves 

• Donate to Pacific Wild research and educational work

  • Share this campaign and the petition on social media

•  Start a conversation with family, friends and everyone who can lend their support to end the wolf kill in British Columbia

Perks of Your Donations!

The more you donate, the better perks you receive! Check out our video to see images of these perks. These options are listed separately elsewhere on this page, but here’s some extra info on a few of them:

•     8 day Trip for 2 to the Great Bear Rainforest aboard the Great Bear II with Ocean Adventures. Find out more here… 

•  24.5” by 32.5”  Fine art print by Ian McAllister. Donate $500 and we will email you a selection of 10 wolf images for you to choose from, you will receive this print in the mail.

THANK YOU

For your donation to this important cause.

www.pacificwild.org

story:
My Story

I have been given the opportunity to join my church on a mission trip to Manila, Cebu, & Laoag along with a leadership development group I am a part of. The eight of us were tasked with adopting a cause, & thus, Project 20 was born. Based on the statistic that worldwide, a child dies every 20 seconds from a water-related illness, we began our clean water initiative from (nearly) scratch. It is still in the beginning stages, but I have been working away at it for the last few months in preparation for the trip in February.


During this initial trip, we will be bringing 9 water filters to slum villages in Cebu, where I, as the overseer of the project, will be teaching on proper hygiene, the use and upkeep of the filters, and about Jesus Christ. I am thrilled/nervous to be spearheading something that has the potential to change countless lives in the years to come!  

The Impact

This trip, we will be bringing simple yet life-changing technology to 45 families living in the slums. We are starting relatively "small" so that we can ensure the accountability and sustainability of our program this year before expanding at an ambitious but unwise rate. Our goal will then be to expand within the Philippines and to other countries in the following years. 


These filters remove bacteria that causes cholera, e.coli, etc. in the water, which cause sicknesses and deaths worldwide. While we have the ability to safely drink water straight from the tap at any time, it makes no sense that millions of people in the world have to drink disease-ridden water, if they have water to drink at all.


To see an example of the filters we are supplying, visit this link:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZG9HzhuzmHk&feature=related 


Ways You Can Help

Donate:
My trip expenses total to approximately $2,200, which I am in the process of raising right now. If you feel compelled, any amount of money will bring me closer to my goal. We are also raising money to front the cost of the filters, soap. teaching supplies, etc. at this point, before we are able to develop a sustainable source of profit through our project. 

Pray: 

You can pray for/with myself & my team in a variety of ways:

  1. For the preparation and execution of the trip, the water initiative as it takes off, as well as for the lessons I will be teaching.
  2. For God's continued blessings in our preparations, financially and otherwise.
  3. For safety as we travel.
  4. For the people of the Philippines, & that their lives will be changed.
  5. For people everywhere without access to safe water.

Learn & Do:
The clean water crisis is a severe, global issue. Over 4,000 children are dying daily simply from lack of clean water, and there are countless ways you can get creative and get involved to save lives. Don't underestimate the good that one person can be capable of!

Thanks for stopping by :)

story:
After years of research

Years ago, I was riding Ronin, the horse on which I take lessons, and I got thrown.  It was neither my fault nor Ronin's.  He'd gotten bitten by a nasty horsefly and he bucked me off his back.  The bruise from my ribs to my hip was excruciating.  After that, I decided it was time to get some bug repellant,

The commercial bug sprays, repellents and foams are all horribly toxic - to our bodies and to the environment!

So, I decided to try to make my own.  And after years of research, I now have a product that is made of organic essential oils (which means it's healthier than the current products on the market and it smells better!)

Everyone who has tried this product loves it.  AND...

What started as a product to repel horseflies, we have found, also repels other biting insects such as:

 

fleas, ticks, mosquitos, spiders, cockroaches, ants, many different biting flies and gnats, and even bed bugs!

Some of these insects spread disease, but if they cannot land on you and bite you, they cannot spread those diseases.  

WE CAN NOT CLAIM THAT KT BOOM DIAGNOSES, PREVENTS OR CURES ANY DISEASE

The ultimate goal will be soaps, shampoos and cosmetic-friendly products to work in tandem, as well as a product that protects suitcases from bedbug infestations.

"Our barn is surrounded on three sides by parkland.  Great for trail rides, but also a constant source for flies, gnats, mosquitoes and ticks.  With all my horses I need a lot of fly repellent.  I don't want to use any of the poisonous fly sprays because I treasure my horses, my grandchildren, my planet.

Eric's KT BOOM is the most effective and safest fly repellent I have tried.  I used to try every new product I could find.  I am now content that I have found the best." -Becky Duncan, riding instructor and avid horse & pet owner

story:
Context of Floresta de Iroko 

The Atlantic Forest of Brazil comprises one of the most diverse ecosystems on earth. It is a unique habitat that is home to thousands of endemic species of flora and fauna, provides goods and services to an estimated 100 million Brazilians, and contains 65% of the country’s population. Despite its invaluable role in the socioeconomic and environmental systems of the country, only 11% of the original forest remains due to commodity monoculture production, urbanization and other encroaching forces.[1] In early 2014, I joined with a group of 15 Brazilian friends to purchase 89 acres of land named Floresta de Iroko that encompasses a portion of this endangered forest. The greater vision of this project is to develop a community center that is based on principles of sustainability and conservation, unity and equity, and education about ecological alternatives.

This pond will serve as one of our sources of water for drinking, bathing, and irrigation.

The Atlantic Forest is in grave danger of extinction and requires the initiative of motivated individuals to incentivize conservation. One of the best ways to create these incentives is through the development of productive ecological landscapes.

            An area of new growth on previously disturbed soils. 

Greater Vision

Long-term objectives on land:

  • Implement ecological agriculture techniques (permaculture, soil conservation, agroforestry, seed saving);
  • Conserve a percentage of the land and work to repopulate beneficial plant species, and control harmful species.
  •  Establish communal spaces (space for children, artistic space for visual arts, dance and music, alternative healing and nutrition center, kitchen for communal meals);
  • Develop innovative waste treatment systems (dry toilets, compost, grey water)
  •  Use Bio-Construction techniques and materials sourced from the land to build structures (bamboo construction, super adobe, rainwater catchment, alternative energy)
  • Create educational spaces in which people can participate in and learn from activities within the community.
  • Develop community outreach programs to involve members of the surrounding region in the sustainable community.
  • Construct business cooperatives that generate an income for the local community.
  • Collaborate with US and local Brazilian educational institutions for research and development opportunities.

An example of the dense and lush rainforest flora that covers the majority of the land. There is an abundance of tropical fruit including bananas, acai, cacao, jaca, graviola, mango and much more!

Immediate Goals

This project is an evolving process that will require ongoing collaboration with community members for the realization of our vision. Many of our long-term goals can only be achieved after preliminary measures have been taken to ensure proper infrastructure and planning. With this in mind, this fundraiser aims to provide the means to carry out the following immediate project objectives for the Summer of 2014:

- Sustainable water systems ($3000)

  • Installation of a cistern
  • Rainwater catchment systems from roof-tops
  • Irrigation systems from water sources to agricultural areas

- Waste management systems ($1000)

  • Construct dry composting toilets

- Preparation of Agro-forest ($1000)

  • Purchase tools and propagation materials for research about pioneer species and production of Green Manure 
  • Use organic matter ground cover and nitrogen-fixing pioneer plants to build soil nutrients

Preparation of the soil for the garden beds where we will plant a variety of herbs and vegetables.

Description of Land and Resources

- Total Cost of land: $USD 269,400

- Total members: 15

- Total land area: 89 acres 

- Geographic coordinates (to locate on Google Earth): 14°21'9.29"S ; 39° 2'37.36"W

- Altitude: 330-500 feet
- Average rainfall: about 70 inches/year

- Average temperature: 68-77ºF

- Sources of water on site: Springs, streams, dams and plenty of rain!

- Surrounding Land: APA (Nationally recognized area of environmental protection) and     Serra do Conduru State Park

- Distance from Coast: 4.3 miles

- Distance from Main highway (BA-001): 2.17 miles

- Distance from Itacare: 7.4 miles

- Distance from Ilheus: 37 miles

- Distance from Salvador da Bahia: 260 miles

Who are we?

We are a group of fifteen people from 20-55 years of age from different regions of Brazil (I am the only person from the US). Each member has unique educational and occupational backgrounds including Oceanography, Biology, National Park management and Agroecology. We have all worked diligently to earn the money to purchase the land, and are now seeking outside funds to further advance the objectives of the project. We routinely gather on the land for planning and work sessions and each contribute unique skills and experiences to this effort.

Second meeting of some of the members of the project to begin planning the foundations for the community center.
The two original landowners, Dona Rosa and Seu Ze, who will continue to participate in the development of Floresta de Iroko. 

Why should you help out?

  • Help preserve a piece of precious rainforest of great biodiversity
  • Contribute to local food production methods that capitalize on harmony with natural systems, integrated pest management, and soil conservation.
  • Support a movement to educate the local community about how to live sustainably in this fragile environment.
  • Come spend time working and learning on the land.
  • Be a part of a community effort where you will be able to impart knowledge and learn from people in many different fields of study.
Donations of any amount are welcome, and will go directly to funding the immediate projects during the summer of 2014. You will receive periodic photos documenting the progress of this work. 

Please feel free to email me with any questions or comments at asmithha@uvm.edu

[1] Alvez, Juan P.; Schmitt, A.; Farley, J.; Alarcon, G.; Fantini, A.C. 2012. “The Potential for Agroecosystems to Restore Ecological Corridors and Sustain Farmer Livelihoods: Evidence from Brazil”. Journal of Ecological Restoration.

on land: 

Implement
ecological agriculture techniques (permaculture, soil conservation, agroforestry,
seed saving);
Conserve
a percentage of the land and work to repopulate beneficial plant species, and control harmful species.

 Establish
communal spaces (space for children, artistic space for visual arts, dance and
music, alternative healing and nutrition center, kitchen for communal meals);

Develop
innovative waste treatment systems (dry toilets, compost, grey water)

 Use Bio-Construction techniques and materials sourced from the land to build structures
(bamboo construction, super adobe, rainwater catchment, alternative energy)

Create
educational spaces in which people can participate in and learn from activities
within the community.
Develop
community outreach programs to involve members of the surrounding region in the
sustainable community.
Construct business cooperatives that generate an income for the local community.
Collaborate
with US and local Brazilian educational institutions for research and
development opportunities.
An
example of the dense and lush rainforest flora that covers the majority of the land. There is an abundance of tropical fruit including bananas, acai,
cacao, jaca, graviola, mango and much more!

Immediate Goals
This project is an
evolving process that will require ongoing collaboration with community members
for the realization of our vision. Many of our long-term goals can only be achieved after preliminary measures have been taken to
ensure proper infrastructure and planning. With this in mind, this fundraiser
aims to provide the means to carry out the following immediate project
objectives for the Summer of 2014: 
- Sustainable
water systems ($3000)

Installation
of a cistern
Rainwater
catchment systems from roof-tops
Irrigation
systems from water sources to agricultural areas

- Waste
management systems ($1000)

Construct
dry composting toilets

- Preparation of
Agro-forest ($1000)

Purchase
tools and propagation materials for research about pioneer species and production
of Green Manure 
Use organic
matter ground cover and nitrogen-fixing pioneer plants to build soil nutrients

Preparation of the soil for the garden beds
where we will plant a variety of herbs and vegetables.
Description of Land and Resources

- Total Cost of
land: $USD 269,400
- Total members:
15- Total land area: 89 acres - Geographic coordinates (to locate on Google Earth): 14°21'9.29"S ; 39° 2'37.36"W
- Altitude: 330-500 feet- Average rainfall: about 70 inches/year
- Average temperature: 68-77ºF
- Sources of water on site: Springs,
streams, dams and plenty of rain! 
- Surrounding Land: APA (Nationally
recognized area of environmental protection) and     Serra do Conduru State Park
- Distance from Coast: 4.3 miles 
- Distance from Main highway (BA-001):
2.17 miles
- Distance from Itacare: 7.4 miles
- Distance from Ilheus: 37 miles
- Distance from Salvador da Bahia: 260
miles
Who are we? 

We are a group
of fifteen people from 20-55 years of age from different regions of Brazil (I
am the only person from the US). Each member has unique educational and
occupational backgrounds including Oceanography, Biology, National Park
management and Agroecology. We have all worked diligently to earn the money to
purchase the land, and are now seeking outside funds to further advance the
objectives of the project. We routinely gather on the land for planning and
work sessions and each contribute unique skills and experiences to this effort.

Second meeting of some of the members of the
project to begin planning the foundations for the community center.

The two original landowners, Dona Rosa and Seu Ze, who will continue to
participate in the development of Floresta de Iroko. 

Why should you help out?
Help
preserve a piece of precious rainforest of great biodiversity
Contribute to local food production methods that capitalize on harmony with natural systems, integrated pest management, and soil conservation.
Support a movement to educate the local community about how to live sustainably in this
fragile environment.
Come spend time working and learning on the land.
Be a
part of a community effort where you will be able to impart knowledge and learn
from people in many different fields of study.
Donations of any amount are welcome, and will go directly to funding the immediate projects during the summer of 2014. You will receive periodic photos documenting the progress of this work. 
Please feel free to email me with any questions or comments at asmithha@uvm.edu


[1] Alvez, Juan P.; Schmitt, A.;
Farley, J.; Alarcon, G.; Fantini, A.C. 2012. “The Potential for
Agroecosystems to Restore Ecological Corridors and Sustain Farmer Livelihoods:
Evidence from Brazil”. Journal
of Ecological Restoration.

story:
My name is Bojan Madic, I am from Philadelphia, PA. I was born in Serbia and have been living in the US for about 7 years now. My goal is to raise money to help the families in need. Many Serbian families have suffered so much, with the war’s in 90’s, with the unstable economy that has been going on for many years since then. A lot of families depend on agriculture as a source of food and a source of income. With the flood happening basically everything they worked hard for is being washed away. I have created Indiegogo page to raise awareness of what is happening and to reach people who are willing to help. All money will be donated to the Red Cross Serbia and the collection will go towards the families that need it the most.

A state of emergency has been declared in several areas of Serbia after five days of torrential rain caused what has been described as the worst flooding in Serbian history. More then 20 people died including a brave firefighter who was trying to save helpless man from a wild river.The Serbian Army, Police and Firefighters with help from Russia and the European Union are using boats and helicopters to deliver food and drinking water and evacuate people, due to roads and bridges being submerged by water. People are in need of water, food, and clothes.

Let’s help the families in need, and any contribution makes a difference…

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Bojan

story:
Hey there! 

I'm Lenora, most of you know me as IcyPuma. Some of you may already know, but my lease is going to be up soon, and supporting two people and two cats hasn't gotten any easier. I can't stay in this apartment, it's just too expensive for me. While I'm paying for rent and utilities in this apartment, it's has been impossible for me to save any money for emergencies, much less a down payment and first month's rent on a new apartment.

I have maybe $200 in savings right now, but most of it will be going to bills, it's been a cold winter, and this apartment has sucked all the money it can from me. I have one door in my place, and as much as I've tried to weather-proof it, cold air just won't stop coming in, so my heating bill is through the roof, trying to just keep warm. 

I thought I could give it a chance here, and maybe I could find some people with kind hearts to help me out. 

When I moved from Florida to here, I had no choice in the apartment I chose, it was either the first one I could find, or the street. I didn't know anyone, and I had no where to stay. This was my last choice, and my only choice. Had I lived here previously, I would've realized how expensive this place is is compared to other places (not even 15 minutes away) in way better neighborhoods. I can't walk down the street without being screamed at. Leaving the house at night is out of the question.

Now that I've had a year to stay here, I know the prices and I can finally actually start looking for an apartment close by, as oppose to 930 miles away. In order to feel completely safe about how I'm going to get a new apartment, and turn on the utilities, I'm going to need $1000 by March. I know it's a lot to ask for, but I have no other way. I have nothing else to fall back on. And to be completely honest, I'm scared. 

Please help me out! Anything that you can spare is tremendously helpful!

story:
Summary

  • We are a group of concerned citizens who love Pelee Island and are coming together to raise money for this important cause. We are Kevin Ryersee- the president of the Pelee Island Co-Operative and its Board of Directors; Rick Masse - the Mayor of Pelee Island acting as a concerned property owner; Dave Dawson,  Pelee Island landowner; Margaret Atwood and Graeme Gibson, property owners and Suzanne Friemann, the Executive Director of The Pelee Island Bird Observatory. Our working group is assisting the Co-Op with the fundraising for the environmental study of the Scudder Harbour area. 
  • All funds raised through this initiative will be deposited in the Township of Pelee Island's bank account and used exclusively for the environmental study.  
  • Unfortunately, due to the nature of this project, CRA has ruled that tax receipts are not available.
  • The Scudder Harbour Area, which is located at the north end of the island, is contaminated with hydrocarbons, fuel and oils, from the industrial use of the area for the past 100 years. It was used as a ferry dock, grain elevator, a freshwater fishery, a fuel dispensing facility and a marina.  All this industrial use has contributed to making the Scudder Harbour area a Brownfield.  The Co-op has the only documented spill in the contaminated area of 680 Litres of diesel fuel.  Because of this fact, the Co-op is being held responsible by the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change, (MOECC) for the contamination and as a result, the Co-op is responsible for cleaning up their property and the surrounding properties.

  • In 2006, the directors of the Co-op had accepted the responsibility for the clean-up, and they made the required capital investment to bring the fuel dispensing facility to its current standards, as we see them today. The Co-op was successful in receiving a $600,000 provincially guaranteed loan and $140,000 from member loan debentures.  The Co-op had spent approximately $800,000 for the completed capital improvements and $250,000 for the clean-up of contaminated lands.  The MOECC approved the technology the contractor used, and this technique was proving effective in cleaning up the contamination, reaching a remediation level of 75%.

  • Unfortunately, there was a fire at the Co-op in 2009 which damaged the remediation equipment. The Co-op, through their insurance policy, received enough money to rebuild the building and replace some of their inventory.  The contractor came back three years later and installed the new treatment system.  They found that the hydrocarbon contamination had returned to their original levels.  After a couple of years of trying different technologies, the contractor determined that additional resources were required to identify from where the source of contamination was coming. 

 

What We Need

  • Because the Co-op used all of its resources and they were not making progress in the clean-up, MOECC ordered the Co-op to retain a new engineering firm to do a new study that would outline a plan of action to determine how the Co-op should proceed with cleaning up the site. The new study’s estimated cost is approximately $80,000.
  • MOECC had ordered the Co-op to complete the study by November 28, 2017, after being informed that the Co-op did not have the resources to complete this review.  The Co-op has asked the municipality for assistance in accessing a 50% grant from the Federation of Canadian Municipality’s, (FCM) Brownfield Fund.  The municipality had agreed to apply for this funding on behalf of the Co-op.  This grant application was put on hold because one of the requirements of the grant is securing the Co-op’s 50% of the funding at the time of application, which they were not able to do.
  • Therefore, the Co-op is asking for assistance to raise their 50%.  
  • We have commitments from individuals for the first $10K which will be matched by other private donations. We hope to raise the remaining $20K from this Indiegogo campaign.
  • The Co-op has obtained a municipal resolution asking the municipality to facilitate donations on behalf of the Co-op, restricting these funds to be used solely for Scudder Harbour Area Remediation study.  For every dollar received, they will be matched with the FCM Green Municipal Fund and be used to move forward with the MOECC ordered the survey of the Scudder area hopefully in the spring of 2018.

The Impact

  • We feel this is a community problem because, with the loss of the Co-op’s facility, our remote community risks losing our fuel dispensing facility, our grocery store, our post office and our hardware store. If the Co-Op is forced to close, this will damage Pelee Island's fragile economy.  Without a fuel dispensing facility, the Island’s drainage infrastructure will lose the fuel filling service and the ability to remove water from our marshes; this could cause the Island to flood and cause a state of emergency.

  • Margaret Atwood relays her experience with the Pelee Island Co-op: "Graeme Gibson and I have had a place on Pelee since 1987, and have spent as much as a third of each year there. It's a fine place to write. One year when we had flown over and spent March on the Island the ferry failed to start on April 1, and the winter plane service had ended. We and everyone else on-island were stranded, and we were running out of food. I took to foraging, and was digging up young dandelion greens on the lawn when the Vulture Migration came through. The vultures settled into the trees around me and watched in an interested manner: when was I going to keel over?In our food-scarce condition, we did luckily have the Co-Op. Things sold out quickly, but luckily they'd had a large shipment of bananas just before transportation failed. We ate a lot of bananas, but at least we ate. People rely on the Co-Op. It's a crucial part of Island life." 

Risks & Challenges

 

  • The risk is not being able to raise the matching funds and therefore not being able to complete the study. If we are unsuccessful in raising the full amount at this time,  the funds  will be held in trust until additional funds are raised and the study can be completed.
  • The challenge is in trying to raise funds during the winter when there are no tourists on the island. However, we know that there are thousands of Pelee Island fans who will want to help out. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, please share our story using the Indiegogo share tools. Or share on your social media outlets! The more people that read our story, the better!

Thank you Graeme Gibson, younger, Rick Masse and Kevin Ryersee for the photos.

Summary

We are a group of concerned citizens who love Pelee Island and are coming together to raise money for this important cause. We are Kevin Ryersee- the president of the Pelee Island Co-Operative and its Board of Directors; Rick Masse - the Mayor of Pelee Island acting as a concerned property owner; Dave Dawson,  Pelee Island landowner; Margaret Atwood and Graeme Gibson, property owners and Suzanne Friemann, the Executive Director of The Pelee Island Bird Observatory. Our working group is assisting the Co-Op with the fundraising for the environmental study of the Scudder Harbour area. 
All funds raised through this initiative will be deposited in the Township of Pelee Island's bank account and used exclusively for the environmental study.  
Unfortunately, due to the nature of this project, CRA has ruled that tax receipts are not available.
The Scudder Harbour Area, which is located at the north end of the island, is contaminated with hydrocarbons, fuel and oils, from the industrial use of the area for the past 100 years. Therefore, the Co-op is asking for assistance to raise their 50%.

The Co-op has obtained a municipal resolution asking the municipality to facilitate donations on behalf of the Co-op, restricting these funds to be used solely for Scudder Harbour Area Remediation study.  For every dollar received, they will be matched with the FCM Green Municipal Fund and be used to move forward with the MOECC ordered the survey of the Scudder area hopefully in the spring of 2018.

The Impact

We feel this is a community problem because, with the loss of the Co-op’s facility, our remote community risks losing our fuel dispensing facility, our grocery store, our post office and our hardware store. If the Co-Op is forced to close, this will damage Pelee Island's fragile economy.  Without a fuel dispensing facility, the Island’s drainage infrastructure will lose the fuel filling service and the ability to remove water from our marshes; this could cause the Island to flood and cause a state of emergency.
Margaret Atwood relays her experience with the Pelee Island Co-op: "Graeme Gibson and I have had a place on Pelee since 1987, and have spent as much as a third of each year there. It's a fine place to write. One year when we had flown over and spent March on the Island the ferry failed to start on April 1, and the winter plane service had ended. We and everyone else on-island were stranded, and we were running out of food. I took to foraging, and was digging up young dandelion greens on the lawn when the Vulture Migration came through. The vultures settled into the trees around me and watched in an interested manner: when was I going to keel over?In our food-scarce condition, we did luckily have the Co-Op. Things sold out quickly, but luckily they'd had a large shipment of bananas just before transportation failed. We ate a lot of bananas, but at least we ate. People rely on the Co-Op. It's a crucial part of Island life." 

Risks & Challenges

 

The risk is not being able to raise the matching funds and therefore not being able to complete the study. If we are unsuccessful in raising the full amount at this time,  the funds  will be held in trust until additional funds are raised and the study can be completed.
The challenge is in trying to raise funds during the winter when there are no tourists on the island. However, we know that there are thousands of Pelee Island fans who will want to help out. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate, please share our story using the Indiegogo share tools. Or share on your social media outlets! The more people that read our story, the better!
Thank you Graeme Gibson, younger, Rick Masse and Kevin Ryersee for the photos.

story:
Imagine This...

Imagine a map that is "live" with time lapse and video views of the North American continent playing inside of the map. Imagine being able to tap on any region in the map and dive into that area to fill the screen with what is going on in Nature in the part of the continent. You could see what is happening right now across the ecoregions. Or you could view a years worth of synchronized time-lapse playing across the map, and watch as the seasons change and migrations and life play out across the continent. That's the kind of glimpse of the continent that the Symphony of Life will show you!

The Bigger Picture

My name is Charles St. Charles and I'm a Nature and wildlife photographer.  In my life I've been blessed to see and photograph many amazing things and visit places that have left me breathless with their beauty. I know that the most important thing that I do is share Nature with people. I've been doing this through classes that I teach, volunteer work, work with 4-H, outings that I lead, and presentations and stories that I share.

Lately we've been working on projects to reach a wider group.  We want others to have a better understanding of the natural world around them, and through that understanding lead them to appreciate and protect Nature.  And we are trying to encourage them to visit these regions and experience Nature first hand.  We've started a free digital publication called Nature of the Wild. Each issue features a season in a different eco region in North America.

I've been visiting these eco regions, gathering content for issues, and at the same time I've been talking to people about hosting cameras to create a network of time lapse videos across the continent. These hosts are from state and national parks, nature centers, and sometimes people just like you. This network is the foundation of the Symphony of Life. We will have 6 or more cameras in each of the 15 major eco regions in North America, so eventually a total of at least 90 cameras across the continent. 

The First Time In History

This is the fist time in history that a project like this has been possible. As the network for these time lapse videos starts growing viewers will be able to experience and understand nature in new ways. They will not only see what happens in nature, but when it happens, how it is related to what goes on in the rest of the continent, and where they can go to see it first hand for themselves. 

Seeing The World in a New Way

Through the Symphony of Life project students and other people interested in Nature and travel will be able to see their world in a new way that has never been possible before. We'll be combining time lapse and normal video with maps to show the synchronization of the seasons and the lives of animals in the eco regions.

They'll see beauty and drama play out across the continent, for example, video and time lapse of Sandhill cranes arriving and leaving the Platte River in Nebraska,

they'll see video and time lapse of monarch butterflies coming and going from the wintering grounds in Mexico,

and they'll see video and time lapse of waterfowl hatching out and paddling away to explore the world. And they'll see exactly where and when Nature's dramas are playing out across the continent.

Each region plays its own brilliant notes in the Symphony of Life. Every season is a movement played as a crescendo, reaching a vivid, intense peak and then fading in a diminuendo into the next movement, the following season.

We will see fall recede as the snows of winter approach down mountain peaks,

and fan out from the north to the south.


 

Then we will see spring pushing winter out from the south to the north as a parade of wildflowers marches across the continent. It is a vast symphony that plays in a cycle with new variations each year.

Funding this project does more that put time lapse cameras in the hands of people who will show the visual tune of Nature playing in their region. It helps us see the big picture and gives us all a chance to celebrate life by experiencing this symphony of sight forever playing across the continent. You make possible a new way of seeing our home!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Where will the funding go?

The cameras used for the time lapse videos are modified sports cameras. Between the cost of the cameras, the specialized housings, the electronics, controllers, external batteries and chargers, the cost to deploy a camera is about $600. This year cameras will go into 4 eco regions with 6 cameras in each region for a total of 24 cameras. 

Twenty four cameras at $600 apiece comes to $14400. There is about an 8% cost involved in running the IndieGogo campaign that is split between IndieGogo and the processor of the transactions, so the total amount that we are looking to fund is $15,500. All of the funds we receive will go towards paying for hardware for this project.

That tells you financially where the funds would go, but how about where the cameras will go?

There are four eco regions where these cameras will go this coming year - 

six cameras go to Northern Forests and the Great Lakes,

six cameras go to Northwestern Forested Mountains (the Rockies),

six cameras go to North American Deserts,

and six cameras go to the Great Plains.

Perks!

Your generosity will make it possible for us to purchase the hardware that we need for the camera network, but what is in it for you? Show me the Perks!

Perk - Nature Of The Wild Publication

A beautiful, informative digital publication that features a different North American eco region in each issue. Video, interactive graphics, animations, photos, maps, time lapse and text grace the articles in each issue.

You will learn about both common and endangered animals, and fascinating subjects like the largest organism on earth, fish that live in the desert, and birds that dance to attract mates. You'll watch baby animals at play and the stars whirling across the sky. You'll learn about an incredibly cute little mammal  that is threatened by global warming and you'll find out about volunteer opportunities where you can make a difference. 

And as a contributor to the Symphony of life you will get access to an online personalized version of the Nature of the Wild publication where you can watch time lapse videos that YOU helped make possible!

Perk - Trumpeter Swan Video

"I'm haunted by the beauty of this video. It's wonderful!" - Judith Hainaut

This perk gives you access to a stunningly beautiful video about the return of Trumpeter Swans. This is one of the best conservation stories in North America. The video features life in the wintering grounds for the largest water fowl in the world. These birds were once widely thought to be extinct, then the efforts of conservationists, biologists, and every day people helped them recover and return to some of their traditional range. This is a story of hope and enlightened attitudes!

Perk - Eco Region Newsletter

The Eco Region Newsletter is where we keep you up to date on our most recent work. You'll get updates from the field, find out where we are currently shooting, what equipment we are using, and get early glimpses of time lapse, videos, images and articles before the the public gets to see them.

 

Perk - Nature Of The Wild Book

The digital release of the Nature of the Wild book is full of beautiful nature photos and in the back of the book are descriptions of how the photos were made.

Perk - 500 piece puzzle

Four Baby Squirrels                  Monarch Migration                   Trumpeter Swans

White Out - Snow Geese                                         Reflections of Fall          

We have a limited supply of wickedly difficult 500 piece puzzles!

Perk - 10x15 Print, Perk - 16x24 Print,

Perk 20x30 Print on Canvas

For the 10x15 print, 16x24 print or the 20x30 print you can pick an image from below. You can also go to the NatureOfTheWild.com web site and browse through the field notes and other pages and select an image from there instead if you choose. We'll get a hold of you and find out what your final selection is.

 Goose Island                                                        Franks Cosmos

Palms to Pines Rainbow                                          Fox Kit Duet                 

Daisy Dew Drop                             Deer Lake                            Enchanted Forest

Dragon Light                                                    Fox Kit Smooch

Lean on Me                                                              Fall at Night

Perk - 3 Foot Panorama, 6 Foot Panorama

For the 3 Foot Panorama or the 6 Foot Panorama you can pick an image from below. You can also go to the NatureOfTheWild.com web site and browse through the field notes and other pages and select an image from there instead if you choose. We'll get a hold of you and find out what your final selection is. Some of the images vary a little in size, but 3 foot panoramas are roughly 10x36 inches and 6 foot panoramas are roughly 20x72 inches.

Fall's Fireworks

God Rays

Sonoran Sunset

Trillions of Trilliums

Teton Lupines

Secret Garden

Summer Bouquet

On Earth as in Heaven

One, Two, Three, Four, Five

Blue Bonnets and Gold

Winter Dreams

Jasper Light

Sunset on a Northern Lake

View Across the Valley

The Start of Fall

Perk - Credit in Video

Your name in bright lights, you've made it! If you help fund a time lapse camera kit at the $300 level your name will show up in the credits in every single video that is made from that camera. Every time a new video is created you (and anyone else who watches) will get a pleasant reminder of how you made this project possible! 

Perk - Sponsor Credit in Video

Wow, you're now a star! When you contribute at $600 or above you'll receive sponsor credit in any videos made from the cameras that you sponsor. In addition to being touted as a generous sponsor you'll get additional credit as a Cameraman, Production Assistant, Assistant Producer, or even a Region Producer based on the level that you contribute at. So fire up the home theatre, make a bowl of popcorn, invite friends over and start the video. You are a person who makes things happen, and you have the credit to prove it!

These are great levels for corporations and organizations to sponsor, you'll receive ongoing attribution and recognition for your generosity well after the campaign is over.

Perk - Join Charles in an Eco Region

If you are contributing at the Eco Region Producer level you can join Charles in the field in an Eco Region. You'll have a chance to see time lapse cameras deployed and get involved in the articles that he is working on. 

What if we don't reach our goal?

What will happen if we don't reach the goal? The money will still go to purchasing cameras and hardware. We might not be able to place as many cameras and cover regions as quickly, but the project will still move forward. 

The Impact

There are two main impacts of this project, one has to do with visualization and learning, and the other has to do with conservation and preservation.

This project makes possible a new way of seeing the continent. You may or may not be in sync with the natural world around you, some people are deeply bound to Nature and some live lives where their spirits are drifting away from the natural world. But either way, it is extremely rare for a person to have connections to more than one eco region. This project makes it possible for people to experience a bigger world and more easily put their existence in context with life across the entire continent. 

It is not easy to visualize a continent throughout the year. This project will widen your world and expand your vision of where you are in it. The Symphony of Life also sits in the Nature Of The Wild project, which has videos, articles, maps and animations for each of the eco regions that these cameras are going to. The articles cover everything from endangered species to volunteer opportunities in the eco region. So the Symphony of Life fits solidly in a good learning experience for anyone interested in Nature.

Time lapse is about to come of age as a tool for conservation and preservation. When you contribute to a project like this you are doing more than help yourself and others see the different parts of the continent, you are also helping to document changes in the environment. This is going to become increasingly important as pressure increases on Nature. We will be able to see exactly what effects these forces are having. Its our hope that enabling a wide audience to view specific locations will lead to the same people caring about and protecting those areas. We want to increase the places that we all feel bound to!

Risks & Challenges

First the good news, unlike projects where the perks are in limbo because the product hasn't been developed, your perks are in the can, safe and sound and guaranteed to be available. Kind of takes the mystery out of whether we'll deliver, right?

But there are a few challenges in the deployment of the cameras. We currently rely on hosts to change batteries and pull data cards. The people that do this are our unsung heros! We are actively working on ways to make their lives a little easier. First by better management of power and second by remote delivery of data. 

There are all kinds of challenges that come up during the actual time lapses. 

One landscape time lapse ended unexpectedly when turtles started using the camera housing as a sunning platform, and then they kicked it into the water. 

Another time lapse that was running to capture images of maple leaves opening in the spring failed when a strong wind storm came through and actually disconnected the power supply cable. 

On another time lapse the camera was capturing a mallard hen incubating eggs in a nest, and after a month the power ran out the day before the eggs hatched. 

Unexpected things happen, but they are always learning experiences. They give us a better chance to setup the next time lapse in a better way so that we can anticipate problems. 

On one setup we were capturing wild trilliums blooming in the forest, we knew that morel mushrooms would be coming up at the same time and that mushroom hunters would be exploring the woods at the same time as the time lapse. We were worried that someone might go home with a camera instead of mushrooms. So we found a stump that could easily be moved, we used a chain saw to cut a slot into it for the camera, and then screwed moss around the camera and buried the power supply under the stump. It worked great, six mushroom hunters showed up in the time lapse but the camera was never discovered, and now the portable stump is part of our arsenal!

We actually plan for somethings to go wrong. There are multiple cameras in each region to let us cover both landscape and natural events in the region, but also to help us overcome problems that happen in the field. 

We are working on ways so that in the future we can monitor the cameras more closely. One of the advantages of time lapse is that even if something does go wrong, it can often be easily recovered from. If you lose a day or two in a time lapse you can still tell a compelling story, and sometimes the gaps are not even noticeable.

The challenges are there, but we are getting better at this as time goes on. And there are always other stories to tell on the other cameras...

 

Time

A very real limitation is time. Charles is sometimes on the road for 6 weeks to cover a season in one of the eco regions. That places a real limitation on how many eco regions he can cover in a year. We are covering four eco regions in a year. It is possible that more resources will come in for the project, but currently we can only do 4 eco regions a year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in our projects there are lots of other ways you can help! 

The easiest is just to share the project with your friends. You can do that by either clicking on one of the social media buttons on this page or sending the URL to friends in email.

If you know of an organization that would like to host a camera please put them in contact with us by having them send email to jennifer@natureofthewild.com .

The work we are doing is free to everyone. We are creating more articles all the time and building interactive interfaces to content. If you know a teacher that might be interested in using any of our material in the classroom we would love to help out, please send email to jennifer@natureofthewild.com .

If you, or someone you know would like to make an older GoPro available for this project please contact us.
story_txt:
Imagine This...
Imagine a map that is "live" with time lapse and video views of the North American continent playing inside of the map. Imagine being able to tap on any region in the map and dive into that area to fill the screen with what is going on in Nature in the part of the continent. You could see what is happening right now across the ecoregions. Or you could view a years worth of synchronized time-lapse playing across the map, and watch as the seasons change and migrations and life play out across the continent. That's the kind of glimpse of the continent that the Symphony of Life will show you!
The Bigger Picture

My name is Charles St. Charles and I'm a Nature and wildlife photographer.  In my life I've been blessed to see and photograph many amazing things and visit places that have left me breathless with their beauty. I know that the most important thing that I do is share Nature with people. I've been doing this through classes that I teach, volunteer work, work with 4-H, outings that I lead, and presentations and stories that I share.
Lately we've been working on projects to reach a wider group.  We want others to have a better understanding of the natural world around them, and through that understanding lead them to appreciate and protect Nature.  And we are trying to encourage them to visit these regions and experience Nature first hand.  We've started a free digital publication called Nature of the Wild. Each issue features a season in a different eco region in North America.
I've been visiting these eco regions, gathering content for issues, and at the same time I've been talking to people about hosting cameras to create a network of time lapse videos across the continent. These hosts are from state and national parks, nature centers, and sometimes people just like you. This network is the foundation of the Symphony of Life. We will have 6 or more cameras in each of the 15 major eco regions in North America, so eventually a total of at least 90 cameras across the continent. 
The First Time In History
This is the fist time in history that a project like this has been possible. As the network for these time lapse videos starts growing viewers will be able to experience and understand nature in new ways. They will not only see what happens in nature, but when it happens, how it is related to what goes on in the rest of the continent, and where they can go to see it first hand for themselves. 
Seeing The World in a New Way
Through the Symphony of Life project students and other people interested in Nature and travel will be able to see their world in a new way that has never been possible before. We'll be combining time lapse and normal video with maps to show the synchronization of the seasons and the lives of animals in the eco regions.

They'll see beauty and drama play out across the continent, for example, video and time lapse of Sandhill cranes arriving and leaving the Platte River in Nebraska,

they'll see video and time lapse of monarch butterflies coming and going from the wintering grounds in Mexico,

and they'll see video and time lapse of waterfowl hatching out and paddling away to explore the world. And they'll see exactly where and when Nature's dramas are playing out across the continent.
Each region plays its own brilliant notes in the Symphony of Life. Every season is a movement played as a crescendo, reaching a vivid, intense peak and then fading in a diminuendo into the next movement, the following season.

We will see fall recede as the snows of winter approach down mountain peaks,

and fan out from the north to the south.

 
Then we will see spring pushing winter out from the south to the north as a parade of wildflowers marches across the continent. It is a vast symphony that plays in a cycle with new variations each year.
Funding this project does more that put time lapse cameras in the hands of people who will show the visual tune of Nature playing in their region. It helps us see the big picture and gives us all a chance to celebrate life by experiencing this symphony of sight forever playing across the continent. You make possible a new way of seeing our home!
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Where will the funding go?
The cameras used for the time lapse videos are modified sports cameras. Between the cost of the cameras, the specialized housings, the electronics, controllers, external batteries and chargers, the cost to deploy a camera is about $600. This year cameras will go into 4 eco regions with 6 cameras in each region for a total of 24 cameras. 

Twenty four cameras at $600 apiece comes to $14400. There is about an 8% cost involved in running the IndieGogo campaign that is split between IndieGogo and the processor of the transactions, so the total amount that we are looking to fund is $15,500. All of the funds we receive will go towards paying for hardware for this project.
That tells you financially where the funds would go, but how about where the cameras will go?
There are four eco regions where these cameras will go this coming year - 

six cameras go to Northern Forests and the Great Lakes,

six cameras go to Northwestern Forested Mountains (the Rockies),

six cameras go to North American Deserts,

and six cameras go to the Great Plains.
Perks!
Your generosity will make it possible for us to purchase the hardware that we need for the camera network, but what is in it for you? Show me the Perks!
Perk - Nature Of The Wild Publication

A beautiful, informative digital publication that features a different North American eco region in each issue. Video, interactive graphics, animations, photos, maps, time lapse and text grace the articles in each issue.
You will learn about both common and endangered animals, and fascinating subjects like the largest organism on earth, fish that live in the desert, and birds that dance to attract mates. You'll watch baby animals at play and the stars whirling across the sky. You'll learn about an incredibly cute little mammal  that is threatened by global warming and you'll find out about volunteer opportunities where you can make a difference. 
And as a contributor to the Symphony of life you will get access to an online personalized version of the Nature of the Wild publication where you can watch time lapse videos that YOU helped make possible!
Perk - Trumpeter Swan Video
"I'm haunted by the beauty of this video. It's wonderful!" - Judith Hainaut
This perk gives you access to a stunningly beautiful video about the return of Trumpeter Swans. This is one of the best conservation stories in North America. The video features life in the wintering grounds for the largest water fowl in the world. These birds were once widely thought to be extinct, then the efforts of conservationists, biologists, and every day people helped them recover and return to some of their traditional range. This is a story of hope and enlightened attitudes!
Perk - Eco Region Newsletter

The Eco Region Newsletter is where we keep you up to date on our most recent work. You'll get updates from the field, find out where we are currently shooting, what equipment we are using, and get early glimpses of time lapse, videos, images and articles before the the public gets to see them.

 
Perk - Nature Of The Wild Book

The digital release of the Nature of the Wild book is full of beautiful nature photos and in the back of the book are descriptions of how the photos were made.
Perk - 500 piece puzzle

Four Baby Squirrels                  Monarch Migration                   Trumpeter Swans

White Out - Snow Geese                                         Reflections of Fall          
We have a limited supply of wickedly difficult 500 piece puzzles!

Perk - 10x15 Print, Perk - 16x24 Print, 

Perk 20x30 Print on Canvas
For the 10x15 print, 16x24 print or the 20x30 print you can pick an image from below. You can also go to the NatureOfTheWild.com web site and browse through the field notes and other pages and select an image from there instead if you choose. We'll get a hold of you and find out what your final selection is.

 Goose Island                                                        Franks Cosmos

Palms to Pines Rainbow                                          Fox Kit Duet                 

Daisy Dew Drop                             Deer Lake                            Enchanted Forest

Dragon Light                                                    Fox Kit Smooch


Lean on Me                                                              Fall at Night
Perk - 3 Foot Panorama, 6 Foot Panorama
For the 3 Foot Panorama or the 6 Foot Panorama you can pick an image from below. You can also go to the NatureOfTheWild.com web site and browse through the field notes and other pages and select an image from there instead if you choose. We'll get a hold of you and find out what your final selection is. Some of the images vary a little in size, but 3 foot panoramas are roughly 10x36 inches and 6 foot panoramas are roughly 20x72 inches.

Fall's Fireworks

God Rays

Sonoran Sunset

Trillions of Trilliums

Teton Lupines

Secret Garden

Summer Bouquet

On Earth as in Heaven

One, Two, Three, Four, Five

Blue Bonnets and Gold

Winter Dreams

Jasper Light

Sunset on a Northern Lake

View Across the Valley

The Start of Fall

story:
If you want change, you have to pay for it! 

If we want a clean country, we have to take the initiative ourselves, because no one else is going to do it for us. 

Lebanon is being held hostage by corrupt, ignorant politicians; while they are busy fighting about who will win trash recycling projects, our trash is filling the streets. Today the officials are throwing trash in the sea and forests, and this is unacceptable! 

We need your donations to help the legal #YouStink protests stay alive and become more organized. All donations will be sent to طلعت ريحتكم campaign orgnizers. 

 https://www.facebook.com/tol3etre7etkom

ACT TODAY!
