story:
In the summer of 2012, with your help, I will be boarding a flight to South Africa to join Operation Wallacea (www.opwall.com) in a unique opportunity to participate in elephant impact surveys on the Thanda Reserve. I will be joining a small survey team comprised of both academics and volunteers obtaining baseline data on the impact of the growth of elephant populations on their surrounding habitat. While on the reserve, I will spend half the time in the field and take part in an Africa Wildlife Conservation course learning in detail the intricacies of how wildlife resources are managed and the major conservation issues currently being faced in the region.

WORD FROM THE HERD…

  A majority of big game areas in South Africa are fenced in order to avoid conflicts between communities as well as dangerous animals. In turn, this restricts the movement of species such as elephants, potentially leading to excessive habitat damage within reserves where elephant feeding pressure is too high. One approach being used by reserve managers is to expand the areas accessible to elephants. In KwaZulu Natal, a project called Space for Elephants is trying to persuade private game reserves to drop their fences in order to create contiguous areas. Similarly, in the Thanda Reserve, they have done just that; and now there are parts of the reserve where elephants have inhabited for a long period, parts where elephants recently gained access in 2009, and new areas where elephants were introduced in 2011. Dropping fences allow elephants to expand their ranges, but also affects the distribution of other herbivores and predators. Private reserves constitute over 60% of the protected areas in South Africa, so projects such as these that encourage cooperation between the reserves through mutually beneficial practices are hugely important for conservation management within southern Africa. 

 

WHY YOU SHOULD GIVE TWO PEANUTS ABOUT OPWALL…

Operation Wallacea is a non-profit organization that operates biological and conservation management research programs in remote locations within Indonesia, Honduras, South Africa and Mozambique, Peru, Madagascar, Egypt, Guyana, Cuba, Mexico, and Romania. Opwall focuses on implementing socially and environmentally responsible programs through academic partnerships. These projects provide local communities with the education, training, and alternative sources of income they need to get out of poverty and conserve their environment.

Furthermore, their hard work has resulted in a great number of peer-reviewed publications each year and the DISCOVERY OF 30 VERTEBRATE SPECIES NEW TO SCIENCE! Not to mention the re-discovery of 4 “extinct” species! 

THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM…

Flights to South Africa are extremely expensive in the summer (equal to the amount of the total cost of the month long expedition!). So far, I have raised approximately $1,000 through savings and fundraising activities; but with being a new college grad, most of my hard-earned cash goes to student loans! Something many of us can relate to, right!?  I've set a fundraising goal of $3,000 to cover the cost of the expedition...WILL YOU HELP ME?

I need all the help I can get from passionate supporters LIKE YOU  who are concerned with the welfare of Mother Nature’s amazing creatures and their habitats. Let's continue efforts in effective wildlife research and conservation management! If not for me, for Dumbo J

story:
My Story

I'm a Haverford College senior interested in pursuing a career in conservation and environmental science. I became aware of the issue of snow leopard conservation in Central Asia and how this conservation directly and positively affects not only a highly endangered species, but the people who live in these areas as well. Through livestock vaccination, insurance and education programs, among others, this conservation is making a difference to people. There is also a potentially distructive natural gas pipeline being planed through a region of snow leopard habitat in the Altai Republic, part of which is a World Heritage site. I am volunteering to go to the Altai Republic this summer to see how I can be involved with the conservation challenges. My goal is to take a video camera with me when I go and record footage that can be put into a short video on the internet to spread the word about wildlife conservation in Central Asia and how it relates to local people and cultures.

I'll be helping with some local conservation education projects in the very south of the Altai Republic near Kosh-Agach and the Argut Valley. Local Altai conservation projects there include an eco-camp of educational materials for visitors to understand more about the importance of the ecological issues. I will hopefully be able to share my ideas on these museums and also be part of a workshop on the making of felt souvineers that raise funds for local people. I'm hoping to witness the second ever Snow Leopard Day festival in Gorno-Altaisk and I may also get to spend some time in some schools in Kosh-Agach or Inegen getting involved with some environmental education with the children there. It would be good to hear their perspective on the issues. In addition, I will also be participating in an expedition in the same region with wildlife biologists to study local wildlife and track numbers, distributions, etc as well as look for signs of the elusive ghost-cat. It will be exciting to learn methods of field conservation research. 

For now, this particular project will focus on the creation of a shorter video project, but I'm keen to take this farther. If I take subsequent trips to this area, a longer documentary is by no means out of the question!


The Impact

The snow leopard is a beautiful and highly endangered animal who in it's own right deserves our help, as do the many other threatened and endangered species of this region. Renown wildlife biologist George Schaller says it best in his wonderful book, Stones of Silence: "As we reach for the stars we neglect the flowers at our feet. But the great age of mammals in the Himalaya need not to be over unless we permit it to be. For epochs to come the peaks will still pierce the lonely vistas, but when the last snow leopard has stalked among the crags and the last markhor has stood on a promontory, his ruff waving in the breeze, a spark of life will have gone, turning the mountains into stones of silence." 

Snow leopards, recognized as a charasmatic face of environmental conservation in Central Asia and a vital keystone species in their ecosystem, are currently being exploited for their fur and their bones (used in some traditional Chinese medicines) and killed by local herders with whom they have historically had a negative relationship in conflict over livestock. There is no effective solution to these issues that does not address every aspect involved. Snow Leopard conservation organizations are taking a community-based approach to conservation through livestock vaccination programs, the development of alternative forms of income for herding families and the encouragement of eco-tourism, amoung others. 

But there is still a long way to go. Funding and personnel are limited and the regions in need of this conservation support are almost incomprehensibly vast. The BBC recently gave a World Challenge award to a snow leopard conservation program - Snow Leopard Enterprises - which works to build a program of alternative income for households through the creation of traditional felt crafts and it has been a huge success in Mongolia; success which could be duplicated in many other areas as well. 

The planned natural gas pipeline would cut a devistating swath accross an Altai World Heritage site of endangered species as well as the minority cultural group who would loose a part of their cultural heritage in this process. This is to say nothing of the additional damage done, were this pipe to be damaged by one of the earthquakes that are fairly frequent in this region. As a geology major, I would like to learn more about this particular type of threat from the pipeline. 

 

What I Need & What You Get

To break down the logistics: It's expensive to get to the Altai, but not unmanageable. With the online support of $3,000 for plane fare, in-country transportation, translators, food/lodging and an expedition fee, I can make this happen. I'm working hard to find multiple sources of funding, so there's no need to ask for everything here. 

I will do this project even if I don't reach the official goal stated here. Every little bit counts and as long as I secure some level of support, I'm going to do this project because I believe in it. And if I go, promotional video footage that I take WILL become available online. :)

I would like to involve supporters in this project as directly as possible. I would expect to encounter a large amount of interesting items on a trip to the Altai. There are projects similar to Snow Leopard Enterprises in this area and their handmade items are always absolutely beautiful. Who knows what I'll find for you! Maybe I'll be able to give you something handmade by local children or even a card from them to you! I'll also be handing out pictures that I take on the trip and handwritten thank you cards from me. For bigger donations, you'll get these things and more! There are so many wonderful organizations out there contributing a portion of their business to snow leopard conservation. From artwork to crafts to a very special brand of snow leopard vodka, I'll see about finding something cool for you!

If you're a Philadelphia area local, I would love talk in person about this project and about my goals for a career in environmental science. If you have ideas for an organization or girl scout troop, etc. that would like a visit, please let me know! 

With your help, the Ghost of the Mountain will live on for generations to come and the rooftop of the world will not turn to stones of silence.

story:
DONATIONS FOR CHILDREN UNDER FIRE IN ISRAEL ARE NEEDED!

My dear classmate in Israel is putting together a fund to purchase games for a children's day care in Sderot, a city close to the Gaza strip, suffering from terrible missile attacks. Sadly due to this situation, the children are forced to spend most of their time in bomb shelters. My friend and other volunteers are spending time & resources creating activities to ease their days. 

Your generous donations will help purchase games such as puzzles, toy kitchen sets, books, arts and crafts supplies,  theater toys etc. 
Most uniquely, these toys will be purchased from local vendors to help support the economy that has greatly suffered from the war. 
Every penny counts and will make a difference in these children's lives! 
Love, 
Anat

story:
Thailand Conservation Project

Hi. My name is Luke and last year I graduated from Hull University with a BS Hon in Environmental Studies. Those of you who know me will know I have always had the desire to travel and see other cultures and experience life in these different countries. However I also want to make a positive impact during my travels and have therefore decided to join an Elephant Conservation Project in Thailand for six months.

The Impact

The population of Asian elephants and their habitat is rapidly declining. With less than 1,000 left in the wild in Thailand and around 3,000 in captivity, we are one of very few viable alternatives to the unshakable reality of their domesticated future within tourist camps. The focus of the project is on ensuring that these captive elephants are successfully reintroduced into protected forest with the overall goal of the project is to have semi-wild herds of elephants living in their natural habitat, supervised by their mahouts.

The project I will be joining involves teaching English to local community members, assisting with plant biodiversity studies with a focus on elephant foraging, and contributing to the rehabilitation of elephants which have been rescued from tourist camps.

During your first 6 weeks I will work alongside other volunteers and learn about the day to day running of the project. The following six weeks involve training from previous interns/staff and learn about each of the 3 projects incorporated in the internship.  The final 12 weeks will be spent running and organising each aspect of the project for one month each. During this time I will work closely with our elephant herd, their mahouts, and the community in our effort to promote sustainable eco-tourism.

The Goal

The goal is set to £500 which I plan to use to buy kit for my time on the project. The total cost of attending will be in excess of £5000 without taking into account any spending money or additional travel whilst there. I have set the goal at the minimum possible so please consider donating just a few pounds to help me reach it. By donating you will know that your contribution is going to help the conservation of this beautiful animal species, by providing the funding for the hands-on support needed to keep this project going.

Risks & Challenges

I have a lot to organise from now until the 10th of January 2015 to prepare for the journey to Thailand but I am well on my way to managing all the forms. Before I go I am also planning on doing a fundraising walk from Scarborough to Robin Hoods Bay in the midst of December to prepare me for the daily hikes. 

 Whilst in Thailand we will be living with the local community in completely different standards to what People in the UK live like such as bucket flushed squat toilets so there is going to be a massive culture shock.

Whilst I am away I will use what time I have to keep people updated using pictures and writing updates via Facebook and or email.

Here is a Link to the project 
http://www.gvi.co.uk/programs/conservation-inte...

I understand if some people see this and don’t want to contribute but any help will be gratefully received. Thank you.

story:
Hi, my name is Jo-Anne McArthur and I'm a photojournalist and author. I'm reaching out to you  because Martin Rowe at Lantern Books and I are publishing another book together, entitled Captive. The book will be available in April 2017.

Perhaps you're already familiar with my photography and animal advocacy through the We Animals project, which is my life’s work documenting animal use and abuse around the globe. My first book, entitled We Animals, was published by Lantern Books in January 2014.

Lantern and I are very happy to be announcing this new and important project. In over one hundred photographs, Captive reveals the lives of animals in zoos and aquaria around the world. I've photographed animals in these situations for over a decade now, and the book will include images from over 20 countries on five continents, shot most recently in the last year while I was working with The Born Free Foundation in Europe. The final pictures have been chosen, the text has been written, and the design, by Paul Shoebridge of The Goggles, is on its way to completion.

Captive comes with essays by myself; by Virginia McKenna, co-founder of the Born Free Foundation; and by philosopher Lori Gruen, editor of The Ethics of Captivity, and author of Entangled Empathy.

I hope you'll watch the video we've made to get a sense of the images and purpose of this project, and then consider pre-ordering your copy and sharing this campaign. Doing so, will facilitate the production, printing, and distribution of this full-color paperback with flaps. The book will retail for $35, which means we're giving a $5 discount on one book, and more on multiple copies.

We’re at an important point in history right now. More than ever, ordinary people are thinking about the ethics of keeping animals in captivity for our entertainment. This reflection will help propel us into a new era of (re)considering our relationship with other animals. Captive aims to be a part of these important discussions.

Thank you for your continued support!

Warmly,

Jo-Anne McArthur

P.S. Please make sure to select your perk; don't just hit the pink "back it" button unless you only want to donate toward the project. Thank you!

story:
We Love Science!


The Tri-Cities Celebration of Science is being coordinated by a volunteer group of local scientists, engineers, and general science appreciators. Recent events made us realize that while we love science, our neighbors may not realize how much science impacts and improves their lives in the Tri-Cities. So … we decided to hold a Celebration of Science in conjunction with activities being planned for a local March for Science and a national March for Science.

The Celebration of Science will be April 22, 2017 from 11 am – 3 pm at John Dam Plaza, 1815 George Washington Way in Richland, Washington.

At the Celebration for Science, we hope to have community leaders talk about the importance of science in the Tri-Cities and booths with science-based activities for kids and families. We’ll have real, live scientists wearing “Ask Me Anything” buttons for you to find out the answer to a scientific mystery or try to stump the expert in their field. There will be food trucks on-site for fueling scientific curiosity or you can walk to nearby restaurants in the Parkway or on George Washington Way.

By sharing our love for science, we hope to see more support from our community for science that upholds the common good and for evidence-based policies in the public interest.

You love science too?
Here’s how you can help!

As organizers for this event, we are prepared to pass the hat to cover the costs for the event – renting the space, paying for insurance, getting the word out. Happily, others in the community have expressed interest in contributing, so we’re setting up this page to provide a means for others to contribute.

We estimate that our expenses will include:

  • $350:   Stage rental at John Dam Plaza for Community and Science presenters
  • $400:   Event insurance
  • $100:   Posters and buttons
  • $200:   T-Shirts
  • $50:     Clean up supplies
  • $340:   Yard signs
  • $50:     Photos, licenses

Your contribution will make the event possible and reduce the out-of-pocket expenses of the people who have worked over the last two months to organize the event.

Our goal is to break even for the event. Any funds in excess of expenses will be used to make more posters, buttons, or t-shirts to give away on the day of the event.

How will your contribution help?

While the Celebration for Science has been organized in response to recent events, we hope to share the day with others in the community who love science and who understand the importance of science funding and evidence-based policies. Our immediate plans are focused on the event this year, but we’d be thrilled if the turnout was large and enthusiastic – we’d like to celebrate science in our community every year!

Your bank account is low but you still want to help?

We understand! Here are some ways to help. Just contact us and we’ll get back to you about details!

  • Be prepared to help with clean up after the event.
  • Bring a booth with science activities!
  • Suggest a speaker who can talk to fun science in the community – or volunteer!
  • Come hang out with us, spend the day with fellow science lovers!
  • Spread the word about the event on social media. Here is a link to the event on Facebook.
    • https://www.facebook.com/events/1096467903814348

story:
Community Center

It would be an Eco Village where resource conservation and preventive wellness synchronize, promoting the mindfulness arts through Tai Chi, Meditation and Gardening, relying on broad-based support from individual members of the community or from various public or private sources.  Small, grassroots group for the advocacy of holistic wellness, and ecological sustainability practices.


This corporation is organized exclusively for a charitable, literary institution and a spiritual purpose center, including the purpose of making distributions to similar Nonprofit Organizations.

To obtain Public Charity Status, by receiving support mostly from individual contributions, government or other public sources.  Carrying on a broad based solicitation program for rehabilitation, counseling or similar services, and depending primarily on government grants or corporate donations.  It would be a publicly supported smaller nonprofit organization.

It would:

  • Receive revenue primarily from activities related to tax-exempt purposes.

  • Lessons and renting studio facilities to other related groups allows group to count income derived from the performance of exempt purposes as qualified support.

  • Be a wellness group that provides and facilitates complementary medical care, alternative medical education, and naturopathic medical research.

  • Have a training and research program that benefits the community, with a community-oriented board of directors specializing in working with youth, Veterans and the homeless.

  • Act as a supporting organization in connection with rehabilitation groups providing 12 step programs, positive mental attitude counseling, and spiritual guidance.

story:
A WORD ABOUT BEEKEEPERS

I am the founder of the Scotch Lake Beekeepers Academy, and a professional beekeeper, naturalist and researcher. 

To protect our future world we need new, young beekeepers. Our collective environment is under severe stress and one of the keystone species critical to our survival is the Bee. The better we understand and manage our bee populations, the greater the security will be for our long term health and stability. For my daughter and grandchildren I wish to convey my knowledge of beekeeping to as many deserving people as possible.

Your generous help will contribute to a new wave of dedicated beekeepers, an attitude of co-existence, and much needed research and development into the rehabilitation of our bees' health, populations and environment.

BEE-Sure to check out the gallery for images of the cool perks we have for you.



A Proper School

A school can not exist in a vacuum. In particular, a hands-on training school requires the infrastructure, materials, and operating supplies to function properly. 

I currently possess a number of active bee colonies for the needs of my honey business. In order to teach effectively many more beehives will be needed to provide a live workshop for each student. Also more bees will need to be produced for the successful student(s) to take with them upon graduation. New beehives with good colonies can be expected to cost in the $400 to $500 range. Supplemental costs in tools, clothing, books and other study materials can be expected.

The research and development division requires supplies and materials, laboratory equipment, resource access, and publication devices.

You can proudly display your support of the school with our logo emblazoned T-shirt.

We also offer tours of the apiary and accept new students to our waiting list.

Regardless of the campaign's total all funds will be directed to the expansion and functioning of the Scotch Lake Beekeepers Academy.

BEE-Sure to check out the gallery for videos from our school.


To Feed the World

This is a true "Green Revolution". When enough people are knowledgeable and skilled in the matters of bees, pollinators, the ecology and their environment the Earth will rebound and recover, and all its people will breath easy and well. 

And, remember, it is Your Contribution that is vital to this Recovery and Re-direction from the errors of the past. A new momentum is here -- with your help.

Please donate and pick up a really cool perk for yourself!




Other Ways You Can Help


  • Plant pollinator friendly gardens and landscapes.
  • Talk to your friends, family and co-workers about the environment and the school
  • Find and use safe alternatives to pesticides.
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
story_txt:
A WORD ABOUT BEEKEEPERSI am the founder of the Scotch Lake Beekeepers Academy, and a professional beekeeper, naturalist and researcher. To protect our future world we need new, young beekeepers. Our collective environment is under severe stress and one of the keystone species critical to our survival is the Bee. The better we understand and manage our bee populations, the greater the security will be for our long term health and stability. For my daughter and grandchildren I wish to convey my knowledge of beekeeping to as many deserving people as possible.Your generous help will contribute to a new wave of dedicated beekeepers, an attitude of co-existence, and much needed research and development into the rehabilitation of our bees' health, populations and environment.BEE-Sure to check out the gallery for images of the cool perks we have for you.A Proper SchoolA school can not exist in a vacuum. In particular, a hands-on training school requires the infrastructure, materials, and operating supplies to function properly. I currently possess a number of active bee colonies for the needs of my honey business. In order to teach effectively many more beehives will be needed to provide a live workshop for each student. Also more bees will need to be produced for the successful student(s) to take with them upon graduation. New beehives with good colonies can be expected to cost in the $400 to $500 range. Supplemental costs in tools, clothing, books and other study materials can be expected.The research and development division requires supplies and materials, laboratory equipment, resource access, and publication devices.You can proudly display your support of the school with our logo emblazoned T-shirt.We also offer tours of the apiary and accept new students to our waiting list.Regardless of the campaign's total all funds will be directed to the expansion and functioning of the Scotch Lake Beekeepers Academy.BEE-Sure to check out the gallery for videos from our school.To Feed the WorldThis is a true "Green Revolution". When enough people are knowledgeable and skilled in the matters of bees, pollinators, the ecology and their environment the Earth will rebound and recover, and all its people will breath easy and well. And, remember, it is Your Contribution that is vital to this Recovery and Re-direction from the errors of the past. story:
This year for my birthday I am asking you to join me in our Eco-Karma Yoga Campaign to save our beautiful yet imperilled oceans! Come celebrate my birthday and dive into the experience of a lifetime.  Our goal: to Redefine “Restorative Yoga:”  Restore your body while restoring our oceans.

The ocean is a shrine of interconnection and an essential source of life on this planet. As a surfer, I see first hand the detrimental effects humans are having on the ocean.

Especially now as I get older, I cannot spend another day without doing something about it.  My goal is to restore 2 sq. km of our imperiled coral reefs in Key Largo, Florida this year. 

That’s why on December 5th, 6th and 7th I am offering FREE daily Blissology yoga, meditation and philosophy in exchange for you helping me transplant coral for the Coral Restoration Foundations 

You can JOIN ME IN PERSON, roll up your sleeves to transplant coral in Florida OR DONATE HERE to become an “Eco Karma yogi.” 

Karma is the offering of unselfish service – our offering to the world. I want us to connect our love for ecology with both the physical yoga practice and selfless service of Karma yoga.  

We need your help to reach our goal of $15,000 to fund this Eco-Karma coral reef restoration projects.

To help us get there and make your contributions go a little further, Lululemon is generously matching every dollar raised by Eoin/Blissology up to $25,000CAD

Love is the Ultimate Renewable Resource!

Why the Coral Reefs?

We are so intimately connected to the ocean.  Every tear and every drop of sweat comes and goes from the ocean. Every second breath we take is produced by  plankton in our Oceans. It is the source of countless life forms. The Coral Reefs are like the rain forests of the ocean.  They cover a mere 1% of the ocean floor yet astoundingly they are home to approximately 25% of all marine life! Today coral reefs around the world are in danger.  Some estimates show how approximately 10% of the world's coral reefs are dead, and about 60% of the world's reefs are at risk due to human-related activities. By the 2030s, 90% of reefs are expected to be at risk from both human activities and climate change.

Let’s do something about this now! Let’s leave a legacy of positive change for the oceans of past and future generations. Connect to your Higher Porpoise! Let’s deepen our connection to each other and restore our bodies while restoring the ocean this December in Key Largo, Florida.

Blissology is about tuning into the the wisdom of our innermost heart so we can stay connected to not just our bodies but to our personal relationships and to our communities and to Nature.  We plan to celebrate Nature and community in a big way with this project

Help Us Reach $15,000!

We've put together some Limited Edition Blissology Ocean Karma Sticker Packs, + lululemon Tees & Tanks with a custom illustration hand drawn by Eoin Finn as a perk for your contributions.


  

Impact Change 

This funding will allow the Coral Restoration Foundation to transplant and maintain between 500 staghorn and 175 elkhorn corals.  Based on current transplant configuration techniques, if all these corals were planted on one reef site, it would occupy approximately just 1.5 square kilometres.

There is a still place within, a source of infinite joy, love and bliss. When we are in touch with this place life ceases to be merely about us and we feel deeply connected to the well -being of our body/mind, our personal relationships, our community and nature.  Blissology is about deepening our awareness of this place so we can be a positive force in the world.


The Coral Restoration Foundation Inc. (CRF) is a 501 c (3) non-profit conservation organization created to develop off-shore coral nurseries and reef restoration programs for critically endangered coral reefs at local, national, and international levels. Its mission is to develop affordable, effective strategies for protecting and restoring coral reefs and to train and empower others to implement those strategies in their coastal communities, restoring and preserving these aquatic treasures for future generations. 
In 2012, CRF received permits to transplant over 100,000 staghorn and elkhorncorals throughout the Florida Keys over the next 5 years.  In 2013 alone, CRF staff and volunteers transplanted almost 10,000 corals to 12 distinct reefs. 

    Join the Bliss Army In Florida
    Roll Up Your Sleeves & Help Initiate The Change Our Oceans Deserve 

    No matter if you are a seasoned diver or a first time yogi with a love for the environment, the Blissology team has partnered with breathtaking eco-resort Casa Morada to offer special packages for this weekend. In addition participate in daily free yoga with globally renowned yogi Eoin Finn, nightly dinners, and daily coral restoration dives.

    Join us from Dec 5-7 and come together as a community of yogis, "Ocean Worshipers" and Blissologists and help us raise awareness and funds to protect this fragile natural treasure.

    Group dinners with Eoin Finn will be held Dec. 5th and for his Birthday Dinner on Dec 6th at Casa Morada with proceeds going towards Coral Restoration Foundation. 


    Daily Schedule Dec 5, 6 + 7:

    Friday, Dec 5, 2014:

    4:30pm   Sunset Yoga at Casa Morada with Eoin
    Dinner at Casa Morada

    Saturday, Dec 6, 2014:

    Breakfast at Casa Morada
    9:30am Meet at the Coral Restoration Foundation
    Opening Ceremony, Partner Yoga and Meditation
    Ecology tour for Non-Divers

    4:30pm Sunset Yoga at Casa Morada with Eoin
    Eoin’s Birthday Dinner at Casa Morada

    Sunday, Dec 7, 2015

    7- 8:30am AM YOGA and closing ceremony at Casa Morada
    Breakfast at Casa Morada

    Please Contact Us for Dive specific schedule

    Photo: Coral Restoration Foundation

    Where to stay:

    Casa Morada We highly recommend staying here, it is an incredible eco resort close to the Coral Restoration Foundation. Checkout the Packages still available.

    The stunning Casa Morada

    DINNER & DIVE

    Community Dinners to support the CRF Dec 5th & 6th.

    Cost: $60 per person - Secure your seat today!

    Coral Restoration Dive Dec 6th

    Cost: $215.00 per day including scuba gear -Register Today!

    For more information please email Kristinann at Vanguard PR

story:
HELP THE RAIN FOREST

Since 1989, Itapoa has been working to prevent deforestation while replanting clear cut land and creating new patches of forest. Along with the reforestation efforts, aimed at preserving the unique plant and wildlife, Itapoa's goal is to educate native settlers about the dangers of logging. By training them to use cacao as a cash crop, natives are able to bring in income as an alternative to logging or selling their land, losing it forever and forcing them to migrate out of their homes and community. We courage neighbors to allow some part of their clear cut land to have the forest grow back with the plants we produce from seeds that are collected for the project. Growing these plants is a large effort we accomplish with the help of many caring and invaluable volunteers. Some of the native plants reintroduced to these area help repopulate species of trees which are almost extinct.

Itapoa Reserve is a rainforest research and conservation project in the northwest of Ecuador. It is located in The Chocó Region which is found in Colombia and the north of Ecuador, from the Pacific coast to the Andes - one of the most beautiful areas of the world. The Tumbes-Chocó-Magdalena region counts as one of the world's 34 biodiversity hotspots. A hotspot is a region that contains more than 1500 vascular plants as endemics, and that has lost more than 70% of its primary vegetation. (An endemic species or biologic group is one that has evolved within a restricted area - a unique species that can be found only in that geographical location).In the Chocó, up to now, more than 11,000 plants, of which 2,700 are endemic, have been listed. The fauna is also particularly rich. So far 285 mammal species (11 endemic), 890 bird species (110 endemic), 327 reptile species (98 endemic), 203 amphibian species (30 endemic) and 251 freshwater fish species (115 endemic) have been identified. This is truly an area full of unique and varied plant and animal life.

Itapoa itself has a botanical garden with more than 400 species of flowers, tropical fruits, orchids, palms. 300 acres of rainforest in the middle of the jungle, plus a smaller piece of land where the headquarters of the project is, the gardens and 20 acres of forest as well.We protect the jungle that we have and buy more for its conservation. We tell people about the importance of the forest and its future. We create biological corridors filled with native plant species hoping it will stay this way forever.We also train and educate concerned individuals and future field biologists who come to volunteer with us from all over the world. We want everyone to feel as passionate about preserving rainforests as we do and to help in any way they can.

Itapoa's founder Raul Nieto also give talks in the US and Europe about the future of the Rainforest, focusing mainly in the bio diversity of the region and the destruction occurring in the last 40 years, due to a law which mandated to clear cut 50% of the forest. Since the 70s, the Chocó has been exploited by forestry companies. Tropical rainforest have an impressive number of tree species. Particularly sought after for their diverse properties, its wood is used for floorboards, sculptures, plywood, posts, resin for rubber, and nowadays tourist souvenirs.Today, the deforestation continues exterminating thousands of species of plants and the animals that lived there. Once the forest was clear cut for the wood alone. Now the forest is disappearing faster as it is being converted to a huge mono culture of African palm to produce biodiesel = NECRO DIESEL and replace fossil fuels. BIODIESEL and the idea of replacing fossil fuels with agro carburants is sentencing to death the last jungles. Because of this, only 5 % of this forest remains in Ecuador.

"My dream is to live in a world in harmony with Nature. To leave clean water and pure air to the future generations. To use only what we need and to return ten times what we use. To bury consumerism and live in a sustainable way. To spend the rest of my life contemplating the wonderful world of nature without worrying about how long that beauty will last." ~Raul Nieto

http://www.itapoareserve.com/index.php
